DEBATE.TITLE: SIR HENRY PARKES: SPEECH ON FEDERATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that 24 October 1989 marks the cen- tenary of the delivery of Sir Henry Parkes' speech at Tenterfield, NSW, which constituted a major impetus for the federation movement and the eventual establishment of the Commonwealth of Australia; and
(b) believes that this outstanding speech constitutes one of the major documents in Australian political history.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of the speech of Sir Henry Parkes.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
PARKES AT TENTERFIELD

During 1889 Sir Henry Parkes, then premier of New South Wales for the fifth and last time, added greatly to his stature in the public estimation as the `Apostle of Federation'. Early in January, while holidaying in Melbourne, he often spoke on the question, and predicted that before federation was accomplished there would be a further division of South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia so as to make ten colonies instead of six. As the year passed, he frequently referred in public speeches to the pressing need for federation, and in May 1889 he made a strong speech on the subject on the occasion of the completion of the Brisbane-Sydney railway. In October 1889 he spoke at Tenterfield in northern New South Wales, after a visit to Brisbane; this speech was widely taken to be a direct appeal to the people to prepare for a federal constitution-making convention. He had kept New South Wales out of the Federal Council, believing that it did not represent colonial opinion, and because it had no real power to deal with such questions as federal defence. However, he was convinced that the time was now appropriate to replace the Council with a proper federal legislature and executive. Speaking at the official banquet, he said:

The Imperial General who had inspected the forces of the colony had recommended that the whole of the forces of Australia should be united into one army. It would have pleased him greatly if they could rely on being safe without taking warlike measures, but as this was impossible, they must take measures to defend themselves, and the knowledge of this fact would be spread all over the world and make them additionally secure. There were two very important questions towards which their intention ought to be directed. They must have heard something of the Federal Council, on which New South Wales had not yet taken a place, and which sat in Tasmania, and held sessions which never appeared to interest anyone; but if they were to carry out these recommendations of General Edwards, it would be absolutely necessary for them to have one central authority, which could bring all the forces of the different colonies into one army. Some colonial statesman had said that this might be done by means of the Federal Council; but this Federal Council had no power to do anything of the sort, as it was not an elective body, but merely a body appointed by the Governments of the various colonies. It was therefore necessarily weak, and under the Imperial Act which appointed it no such tremendous power was given as that of originating and controlling a great Australian army. The Federal Council, also, had no executive power. It could propose, but could not execute. He would like to know what was to become of an army without a central executive power to guide its movements. One way which had been suggested out of the difficulty was that the Imperial Parliament should be asked to pass a measure authorising the troops of the colonies to unite in one federal army, but still, even if this were done, there would be an absence of the necessary central executive government. The colonies would object to the army being under the control of the Imperial Government, and none of the other colonies could direct it. The great question which they had to consider was, whether the time had not now arisen for the creation on this Australian continent of an Australian Government, as distinct from a local Government and an Australian Parliament. (Applause.) In other words, to make himself as plain as possible, Australia had now a population of three and a half millions, and the American people numbered only between three and four millions when they formed the great commonwealth of the United States. The numbers were about the same, and surely what the Americans had done by war, the Australians could bring about in peace. (Cheers.) Believing as he did that it was essential to preserve the security and integrity of these colonies that the whole of their forces should be amalgamated into one great federal army, feeling this, and seeing no other means of attaining the end, it seemed to him that the time was close at hand when they ought to set about creating this great national government for all Australia. This subject brought them face to face with another subject. They had now, from South Australia to Queensland, a stretch of about 2000 miles of railway, and if the four colonies could only combine to adopt a uniform gauge, it would be an immense advantage in the movement of troops. These were the two great national questions which he wished to lay before them. He had just returned from Brisbane, and the object of his visit had been not to force his advice on the authorities there but to discuss with them these matters. Unfortunately, owing to the illness of the head of the Ministry, his communications were rather more of a private character than otherwise; but, without disclosing any confidences, he thought he must state that he understood both sides in politics sympathised warmly and closely with the views which had been expressed by him. As to the steps which should be taken to bring this about, a conference of the authorities had been pointed to, but they must take broader and more powerful action in the initiation of this great Council; they must appoint a convention of leading men from all the colonies, delegates appointed by the authority of Parliament, who would fully represent the opinion of the different Parliaments of the colonies. This convention would have to devise the constitution which would be necessary for bringing into existence a federal government with a federal parliament for the conduct of this great national undertaking. (Applause.) The only argument which could be advanced in opposition to the views he had put forward was that the time had not come, and they must remain isolated colonies just in the same way as they were now. He believed, however, that the time had come; and, in the words of Brunton Stephens, the Queensland poet: -
``Not yet her day! How long? Not yet!
There comes her flush of violet, and, heavenward faces all aflame
With sanguine imminence of morn wait but the sun-kiss to proclaim
The day of the Dominion born.''

(Applause.) He believed that the time had come, and if two Governments set an example, the others must soon of necessity follow, and they would have an uprising in this fair land of a goodly fabric of free Government, and all great national questions of magnitude affecting the welfare of the colonies would be disposed of by a fully authorised constitutional authority, which would be the only one which could give satisfaction to the people represented. This meant a distinct executive and a distinct parliamentary power, a government for the whole of Australia, and it meant a parliament of two houses, a house of commons and a senate, which would legislate on these great subjects. The Government and Parliament of New South Wales would be just as effective as now in all local matters, and so would the Parliament of Queensland. All great questions would be dealt with in a broad manner, just as Congress dealt with the national affairs of the United States, and as the Parliament of the Dominion of Canada dealt with similar questions. He, therefore, took advantage of the opportunity which had arisen for the consideration of this great subject, for he believed that the time was at hand when this should be done. One great thing to be accomplished was the massing together of their military forces, and this could not be controlled by any other power than one representing all the colonies. In conclusion, he thanked them for the kindness which they had shown him, and said that he had no fear but the Federal Parliament would rise to a just conception of the necessities of the case. The thing would have to be done, and to put it off would only tend to make the difficulties which stood in the way greater. In the meantime, there was this substantial work which they could not do by any other means to be carried out, and it could not be done by any existing machinery.
- Sydney Morning Herald, 25 October 1889. There is an edited version in H. Parkes, The Federal Government of Australasia, Sydney,

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 12 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That the Lotteries Ordinance 1989, as contained in the Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1989 and made under the Christmas Island Act 1958, be disallowed;

2. That the Determination of Australian Design Rules as National Standards Order, as contained in Determination of Motor Vehicle Standards-Order No. 1 of 1989 made under section 7 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, be disallowed.
Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Christmas Island Lotteries Ordinance confers a discretion on the Minister to approve, with conditions, commercially valuable public lotteries and betting schemes. There is no external right of review for a refusal or inappropriate approval, no criteria to control the exercise of the discretion and the Minister may apparently delegate the approval power to any person. The Ordinance also contains provisions empowering a somewhat unqualified access to information and property. The Committee has expressed its concern about these matters to the Minister and is awaiting his response.

SPEECH.PARA: The Determination of Motor Vehicles Standards confers a wide discretion on the Minister to deem that vehicles or components have complied with national standards even though those requirements have been met by a means other than those set out in the determination. This discretion is not limited by criteria and appears not to be subject to external review on the merits. The Committee is concerned that the exercise of an unreviewable discretion could have important commercial implications. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short description of the Committee's concerns about each instrument.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
LOTTERIES ORDINANCE 1989
Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1989
This Ordinance legalises approved public lotteries and approved betting schemes in the Territory of Christmas Island.

The core of the new arrangements is that the Minister may grant or refuse approval of lotteries and betting schemes subject to any conditions or requirements to ensure fairness and the interests of subscribers. There are no detailed criteria for the exercise of this power, nor any right of external review of the merits of a decision granting or refusing approval or imposing conditions. In addition, the Ordinance provides that the Minister may delegate any of his or her powers, apparently to any person.

The Committee is always concerned at provisions in delegated legislation which grant to the executive wide unreviewable and unstructured discretions in respect of any particular schemes that could have livelihood implications. In this case, the discretion relates to matters which the Committee believes could be of major commercial importance. The Committee believes that in such cases the question of creating a right of external review should always be examined. The Committee therefore raises the question and seeks the advice of the Minister. Where there are no objective criteria set out to guide the exercise of a discretion the need for external review of a decision will be stronger. In the present Ordinance, there are no objective criteria and there is a further provision for the Minister's power to be extensively delegated.

The Ordinance is also defective in that it provides for persons, authorised to audit material which may be demanded by a public official, to demand information themselves and to require the answers to questions. Although related provisions in the Ordinance only apply to ``reasonable'' requests, there is no such limit in this case.

There is also provision for a person authorised to supervise the conduct of a lottery to enter any place where the lottery is to be drawn. There appears to be no restriction on this power of entry, either on the basis of consent, a judicial warrant or at a reasonable time.
DETERMINATION OF AUSTRALIAN DESIGN RULES AS NATIONAL STANDARDS ORDER
Determination of Motor Vehicles Standards-Order No. 1 of 1989 made under section 7 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989

This Order, although only two pages long, effectively incorporates into Australian federal law the 2,900 (sic) pages of the ``Australian Design Rules for Motor Vehicles and Trailers-3rd Edition'', issued by the Department of Transport and Communications, as at 31 July 1989. These Rules created the motor vehicle standards for the purposes of the Motor Vehicles Standards Act.

The Committee has no difficulty as such with the length of the incorporation, as it is not concerned with the policy of a particular instrument. In this instance, however, the Order itself provides that where this national standard imposes a requirement for the performance of a vehicle or component, and a particular vehicle or component meets that requirement but does so by a means other than that specified in the Australian Design Rules, the Minister may deem the vehicle or component to comply with the national standard.

This wide discretion does not appear to be limited by criteria or to be subject to an external review of its merits. An adverse exercise of the discretion by the Minister could have important commercial implications, as the general legislation applies to ``all road vehicles'' supplied to the market for the first time, whether manufactured in Australia, imported new or imported second hand. Such vehicles are required to conform, and continue to conform, with the applicable national standards.
It may be that this discretion is covered by appeal provisions in the parent Act, although this is not immediately apparent and it is certainly not mentioned in the Explanatory Statement.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Walsh will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today and tomorrow because of illness. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Walsh in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Ray.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. We welcome him back.
—Oh, yes!

—Some of us welcome him back and some of us do not. I ask: Is it a fact that he has reprimanded the Australian Ambassador to Thailand, Richard Butler, over comments the Ambassador made in Bangkok over the weekend-specifically, that Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) proposals for a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia were a `sham' and `an excuse to avoid a settlement', that partial settlement should be a first step, and that the idea of a comprehensive settlement should be `taken off the table'? If the Minister has reprimanded Ambassador Butler, why has he done so when the Minister himself, in Brunei on 6 July at the post-ASEAN ministerial and in Paris on 28 August, argued that there was value in a partial settlement? What action has the Government now taken to minimise damage within ASEAN as a result of the Ambassador's comments? Is this another example of Australia conducting its diplomacy on the level of Sir Les Patterson?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Ambassador Butler's reported comments on Cambodia as they were originally published in the Bangkok Post on 21 October and as they were subsequently reported in the Australian media. As reported, those comments on the difficulties confronting the achievement of a comprehensive settlement to the Cambodian conflict were capable of being construed as a stepping away by Australia from our policy commitment to a comprehensive settlement. It is a policy commitment which we have always had and which I have certainly never resiled from. I do not know what Senator Hill is talking about in respect of either Brunei or Paris. I know that there was some misconstruction of something I said at the airport at Brunei in that respect, but there was no report at all which could possibly have lent credence to that coming out of Paris.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as Ambassador Butler's comments were concerned, he has subsequently assured me that his remarks were taken out of context; he had not suggested that there had been any change in Australian policy. In particular, he had emphasised in his interview something not reported at all in the media accounts; namely, that Australia had decided once again to co-sponsor the ASEAN resolution at the United Nations General Assembly this year, which decision makes very clear our support for ASEAN's commitment to a comprehensive settlement.

Let me say again for the record that Australia believes, on all the presently available information about the attitudes of those capable of influencing events in Cambodia, be they internal parties or external players, that the only way of securing a durable settlement and stopping the killing in that tragic country is for there to be a comprehensive settlement in which all sides make compromises and concessions and demonstrate a preparedness to contribute to a process of national reconciliation and reconstruction. I made that very clear in the Senate on 27 September, the last time I think I addressed this question here, and I do so again now. I said on that occasion that we support all efforts to achieve a comprehensive political settlement. I referred then particularly to Prime Minister Chatichai's efforts. Since then I have had an extensive round of discussions with other colleagues at the United Nations and am aware of other efforts being made by the co-chairmen of the Paris Conference, France and Indonesia, and by some of the five permanent members of the Security Council to find a comprehensive and durable way through the present impasse. I repeat that we will support all such efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister of that part of my question in which I asked whether the Government had taken action to minimise the damage within ASEAN as a result of the comments of Ambassador Butler.

—I think this statement on the record should make absolutely clear to the ASEAN countries that there has been no stepping back by Australia from the policy of a comprehensive settlement. Equally, it will be very clear to the ASEAN countries that that is so as a consequence of our support for the ASEAN-sponsored resolution at the United Nations General Assembly, of which they are already aware.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, also deals with the situation in Indo-China. Does the Australian Government accept that the Vietnamese troop withdrawal from Cambodia has been completed in the terms of the Vietnamese Government's promise that all its troops would be withdrawn from Cambodia by the end of September 1989? If the Australian Government does not accept that all the Vietnamese troops have been withdrawn, can the Minister indicate upon what basis the Australian Government reached such a conclusion? If the Australian Government does accept that all the Vietnamese troops have been withdrawn, does it believe that the withdrawal is a major step forward in achieving a peaceful settlement of the Cambodian dispute?

—So far as formed military units are concerned, it is Australia's assessment that the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops has been completed as scheduled. But there are still claims and counter claims, which we have found very difficult to verify, about residual Vietnamese military advisers and some claims as to Vietnamese troops now wearing the uniform of soldiers of the People's Republic of Kampuchea. It has to be recognised that, without an appropriate international control mechanism to verify the withdrawal issue, it is very difficult to be categorical and to confidently accept Vietnamese withdrawal as being now complete. Full Vietnamese withdrawal from Cambodia remains, as we have constantly said, one of the necessary pre-conditions for a resolution of the Cambodian conflict and it is one of the key elements in the comprehensive settlement to which we remain committed and which I have just made the subject of a reply to Senator Hill.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the statement on southern Africa issued this week by the Commonwealth heads of government in Kuala Lumpur. Will the Minister explain why, and at what cost, the Hawke Government committed itself to paying for a new international agency to monitor financial flows to South Africa? Will the Minister also inform the Senate which other countries have pledged funding and the amounts committed?

—The international agency to which we refer was originally the subject of a suggestion in the book commissioned by the Australian Government and entitled Apartheid and International Finance, written by Tony Cole, now Deputy Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Keith Ovenden, a consultant to the Government. That idea has been further fleshed out and was fully explained by the Prime Minister in his speech to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It is a relatively small-scale concept involving the location within a respected existing research institution in an international financial capital, possibly London, possibly somewhere in Europe, possibly in New York--
—The communique says `substantial'.

—I will get to the issues one by one in due course. I thought the honourable senator was still in New York. Why could he not have done us the benefit of staying there? The idea is to create a small unit in a respected and recognised international research institution in an international financial capital, as I indicated-small in the sense of probably involving one professional, perhaps one post-doctoral or graduate student and a secretary. They will be people with expertise in the operation of the South African economy but, more particularly, in the operation of international financial markets, capable of understanding and effectively analysing the very complex transactional flows that are involved in that international financial market as it affects South Africa these days and reporting effectively on just what is going on and the implications of the operation of restriction of financial flows to South Africa on the South African economy. All of those matters are obviously of very real significance and have a very real impact on the way in which the rest of the world views what is appropriate to apply by way of pressure on South Africa. The cost of this exercise as I have described it we assess to be about $200,000 to $225,000 a year in the first two years. Australia has pledged substantial initial support for that. It is not yet clear what will be forthcoming by way of financial contributions from the other countries, but the idea of establishing such an agency was warmly endorsed by 46 of the 47 members of the countries present in Kuala Lumpur. There, as elsewhere, Mrs Thatcher demonstrated her membership, as Neil Kinnock once very nicely put it, of the Greta Garbo school of diplomacy: `I want to be alone'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whether he has seen the article in the November issue of Portfolio in which Senator Newman is quoted as saying, among other things:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government should not be worrying about female participation in sport or how women are portrayed in advertisements. These matters are very much on the periphery.
Can the Minister say whether he agrees with these remarks and whether such comments should be directed to women only? Does he agree that funding for women in sport is misdirected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess to being somewhat surprised by Senator Newman's comments, even though they come from someone who over time has demonstrated a classic disregard for the interests of women. But to suggest that the participation of women in sport is not important is extraordinary even for her. I would have thought that almost anybody--
—You are desperate.

—How can Senator Hill call anyone desperate? He has been desperate for years. I find it extraordinary that Senator Newman, with all her experience in here, would have the gall to suggest that sport is not important to women and that the only things that are important are issues in the household. The sad thing--
—You deserve criticism for how little has been devoted to women's sport.

—The priorities for women should be their health, their well-being and their quality of life. The difficulty for Senator Newman is that by ignoring it she condemns herself in a way that surprises even us. The reality is that the participation rate of women in sport is very low indeed. Only a few months ago we allocated some $270,000 extra this year so that we could make sure--
—Tell us about participation on that love boat.
—We will raise that again. We have had it raised before. Senator Puplick has always lost on it, but then he is accustomed to losing.
—Will you go around and visit somebody?

—We will raise that too. I have been waiting for this. As I have said, I find it appalling that Senator Newman could ignore this very important area of women's health. This Government is doing something and will not ignore it. We will make sure that the participation rate rises. We will make sure that the health of Australian women remains a matter of Government priority. We will do that by remaining in government. The more the Opposition insults women, the longer we will remain in government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to Australia's international agreements with Japan and China relating to migratory and wetlands birds. Is the Minister aware of concern about the implications of a proposed transfer of public recreation land on the North Entrance peninsula of the central coast of New South Wales to commercial enterprises, especially as it would affect the protection of migratory birds and their environment and would potentially be in breach of our international obligations under treaty? Does the Minister consider it important enough to take action to prevent the transfer of this public recreation land? Have these concerns been discussed within the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM), which is the forum designated to consider such transfers? If so, what conclusions have been reached? If not, will the Minister raise the subject himself? Finally, if the convoluted workings of the various subgroups of CONCOM appear to be too slow to have any affect on the proposed transfer of this public land to private enterprise, will the Minister seek to have any transfer halted until it has been established that there will be no ill effects on migratory birds if the proposed development takes place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —On a visit to the area a couple of months ago-probably in July or August-I met with some representatives of community groups in the area who are concerned about the transfer of public land to private enterprise and, more particularly, in so far as my area of interest is concerned, about the potential destruction of the habitat of migratory birds. Australia has a number of agreements with other countries-Japan and China being those in point here-which oblige us to protect the habitat of migratory birds. The peninsula in question supports one endangered and 20 rare species of birds and 35 birds listed under the migratory birds agreements. I have already taken some action to consider the impact of the proposals on migratory birds. Australia's obligations under these agreements are administered through legislation and administrative arrangements in the States and Territories, and I would have thought that that would be the appropriate way for it to continue. CONCOM is the Council of Ministers under which this system works.

ANSWER.PARA: In August of this year, as a result of the representations I had received, I wrote to the Wyong Council and to the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Causley, seeking their assurances that there would be no destruction of the habitat of those migratory birds were this development to proceed. It is not surprising that I have not received any response from the New South Wales Government on this question. Its record on coastal development, which is fast becoming a scandal to rival that of Queensland's, would suggest that it will take no action. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has an overall coordinating role to coordinate our action under these treaties. It also convenes a working group set up amongst the States with the Commonwealth to assist in the legislation and administrative arrangements to which I referred earlier. If there is a prospect of the development proceeding and a prospect that the habitat of these birds would be endangered one would imagine that the New South Wales Government would have raised this question at the relevant CONCOM committee. It is my understanding that it has never raised it. Given that I have not received any reply to my inquiries, I certainly intend to have it placed on the agenda for that committee to consider.

The limited amount of information I have available suggests that the North Entrance peninsula may well be of national significance. If I can firm up that information I will look at what powers the Commonwealth has under those treaties to make sure that the habitat of those migratory birds is not destroyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of a claim by the Queensland Conservation Council that 28 animals and 1,000 plant species in Queensland face extinction? Is the Minister aware that this is claimed to be the result of the failure of the Queensland Government to enact legislation to guarantee the protection of endangered species? Can the Minister indicate whether there has been a lack of cooperation by the Queensland Government in assisting with the implementation of the Federal Government's new program for endangered species? If so, will the Federal Government continue in its efforts to persuade the Queensland Government to co- operate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements made by the Queensland Conservation Council. If anything, it may well understate the situation in Queensland. Certainly at the present time there are at least 28 endangered species of vertebrate animals in Queensland but, according to the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, a source that one would imagine not too many honourable senators-at least those on the other side of the chamber-would be willing to dispute, there may be 1,115 vascular plants endangered at present. That is a very serious situation indeed.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question sought to know whether I was aware that the situation is claimed to exist because of the failure of the Queensland Government to enact legislation. The reality is that the record of the Queensland Government on this and other environmental issues is by far the worst of any State in Australia. No other State could come close. The Queensland response, so far, has been that there are no endangered species in Queensland: that is, apart from the Ministers in the Cooper Government.

In contrast, Victoria recently passed flora and fauna legislation which incorporates not only protection of individual animals or plants but also strategies for the protection of habitat. Victoria has been prepared to go out and discover the problems; Queensland would simply prefer not to know.

It is too early to gauge the attitude of the Queensland Government to the Federal Government's endangered species program. I put out the strategy on, I think, 4 October and public comment is invited up till December, so it will be some time before we find out what Queensland thinks. Given that the date is 29 December, no doubt the response will come from the Goss Labor Government, and its response on endangered species will be a damned sight better than anything that has come before it. I would hope that, when we see that response, we will have a cooperative arrangement to ensure that endangered species of both flora and fauna in Queensland are protected. It is an area of immense national and international importance and one that has been very sadly ignored. This Government, and the incoming Goss Labor Government in Queensland, will make sure that the problem is rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —In asking the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question, I trust that he will recall last week giving the Senate figures about payments of taxpayers' funds to the airlines as part of the agreement forced on the Government by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to prevent stand-downs of other airline employees. Those figures show that the airlines had benefited to the tune of $3.8m of public funds in aggregate. Will the Minister now update those figures, given that they covered claims approved for Ansett Airlines of Australia only to 28 September and for Australian Airlines Ltd to 6 October? What will be the cut-off point for these payments? For instance, if Australian Airlines achieves its claimed 80 per cent capacity next month, will the Government consider that to be a sufficient level of normality to suspend the waiving of normal aviation charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked about these figures from time to time and I have provided the answers. I will seek to obtain an early answer for the honourable senator and provide an up-to-date figure. The honourable senator asked about the cut-off point for any payments to the airlines in respect of the staff who are retained in employment when they might otherwise have been laid off. He asked me this question essentially last week and I said at that time that the answer to that question really was that that was a matter to be determined by the Government at the appropriate time. I make no change to the answer that I gave last week.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator made his question slightly more specific this week by asking whether 80 per cent capacity by Australian Airlines would be a return to normalcy. I do not think that that judgment can be made first of all as to 80 per cent capacity and secondly as to whether that would be regarded as normalcy at this time. As the honourable senator knows, this dispute has been much more protracted than the Government or anybody else would have wished. It has been difficult to estimate from time to time how long it will go.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't count in this area either.

—The honourable senator was not capable of counting in this area either, judging by some of the questions he asked in the course of earlier discussions on this matter. The question is based on a somewhat ludicrous proposition, namely, that the Government has some sort of schedule set out of what is normalcy, when it occurs and what reductions will be made in payments at that time. That, of course, is absurd.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not have any difficulty accepting that the Government cannot recognise normalcy because the Government is so abnormal itself. Has there been any discussion with Mr Hawke's mates, Sir Peter Abeles and Mr Harris, as to what would constitute normalcy if no resolution has occurred? Furthermore, to save me asking this question every week, would the Minister consider giving us a running total every week of what subsidy the Government is giving the airlines?

—If I gave the honourable senator a running total each week it would deny him the opportunity of getting up and stunting at Question Time. I do not want to do that. Senator MacGibbon has been doing this every week and I provide him with the answers. That is the function of Question Time. The suggestion that it has anything to do with the Prime Minister's mates is totally irrelevant to the whole question.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of an article in the Australian Financial Review of 18 October entitled `Snowy scheme threatened by drought and political row'? Does the Minister agree with the statements in the article which suggest that, on the fortieth anniversary of the Snowy Mountains scheme, the future of the scheme is threatened by drought and by an inter-government dispute which is holding up refurbishment of the scheme's outdated equipment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday, 40 years ago, Sir William McKell, the Governor-General of Australia, detonated an explosive which commenced the construction of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme.

—It just so happens, Mr President, that the Snowy Mountains scheme is a major scheme for Australia and its fortieth anniversary ought to be properly recognised in this chamber. The scheme provides peak load electricity for New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory as well as irrigation waters for the Murray and Murrumbidgee rivers. The fortieth anniversary recognised the role of Nelson Lemmon, the Western Australian wheat cocky who was a Minister in the Chifley Government and who steered through the Parliament the legislation to set up the scheme, the role of Sir William Hudson, the first commissioner of the scheme, and the role of Major Clews, the person who surveyed the scheme. During the construction of the Snowy scheme, which concluded in 1974, 100,000 workers from 30 different countries participated in the construction of the scheme. Unfortunately, 121 of them were killed during the construction phase as they rushed to complete their project. The scheme cost about $400m. In today's money it would cost about $4 billion to replace. Those are some of the observations that I think it proper to make in recognition of one of the world's most significant hydro-electric schemes ever constructed.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the article in the Financial Review referred to by Senator Black which appeared at about the time the anniversary occurred. It made two points which I think, in the context of all the events, are a little unfortunate. The Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority, with the assistance of Victoria and New South Wales, has conducted a strategic maintenance review of the scheme. The scheme is mainly a civil engineering works but the moving parts of the scheme, the turbines and generators, have, over 30 years of operation, run down. A major refurbishment program is now necessary. It is suggested that the cost of replacing those moving parts will be about $400m spread over about 20 years. There is no conflict between the Commonwealth and the States about that. Indeed, the Prime Minister wrote to the Premiers of the two States and the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory recently, saying, `We are now in a position of scheduling negotiations to work out how we refurbish Snowy Mark II'.

On the question of low rainfalls, it is true that there has been something of a drought in the Snowy Mountains in recent years. The dams are now about 60 per cent full; a year ago they were 45 per cent full. If there is low rainfall for a few more years yet there will indeed be a problem for the scheme, but there is not one in the present circumstances. If there was a continued drought there would need to be an examination of options such as cloud seeding, which of course, could proceed only if a decision was made to go ahead with it on the basis of a full environmental impact statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that for the last five months the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has been conducting a campaign of rolling strikes affecting the Victorian export meat industry? Is he aware that this industrial campaign is causing serious damage to an industry which earns $500m in exports a year? Will the Government intervene before the Industrial Relations Commission and support the employers' application for the insertion of a bans clause in the union's award? If not, can the Government explain why it has not lifted a finger to assist employers in the Victorian meat industry when it has moved heaven and earth to assist the domestic airlines during the current pilots dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not personally aware of that dispute. However, I have a note that as a result of extensive hearings before the Commission a decision was handed down on 23 March. The awards regulate the meat industry in all States other than Western Australia and Tasmania and apply to all employees engaged in domestic abattoirs. The meat industry employers subsequently appealed against aspects of that decision. On 14 September the Full Bench of the Industrial Relations Commission handed down its decision in relation to the appeal. That decision set aside Deputy President Riordan's earlier decision. It amended the date of the effect of the 4 per cent second tier increase and the 10 per cent March 1989 increase to 14 September 1989, which represented a loss of 10 months retrospectivity compared with the decision of Deputy President Riordan. There has been a reaction to the decision of the Full Bench, and that is probably the principal concern in Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the ongoing nature of this dispute, which, as the honourable senator said in his question, has been of five months' duration-off and on again, as I understand it-and as to whether the Government will intervene with the Commission about that matter, I will speak to the Minister for Industrial Relations, pass on the honourable senator's suggestion and try to obtain an early answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the Senate of any progress that has been made in discussions among Lebanese members of parliament (MPs) in Saudi Arabia who are seeking national reconciliation in Lebanon? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the view of the Australian Government on the continuing political uncertainty in Lebanon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what was a very welcome and important breakthrough in the search for national reconciliation and the restoration of Lebanese sovereignty, on 22 October, just two days ago, a meeting of members of the Lebanese Parliament-which has been held for some time now in the city of Taif in Saudi Arabia-agreed on a new national charter, which aims at political reform, and other steps to resolve the underlying causes of the civil war in the Lebanon. There was also agreement on a framework for the withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon. That meeting of Lebanese MPs is scheduled to conclude today, after which it is anticipated that they will return to Beirut for a formal session of Parliament, which will endorse the agreement, although no date has been set for this session.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government, as I said, welcomes this as a major breakthrough. But we appeal to all parties involved in Lebanon to take advantage of it. In this context I am disturbed, as we all are, at reports that General Aoun on the Christian side has already rejected the Taif agreement. It is absolutely crucial that he and all other leaders in Lebanon act responsibly in the current situation. We urge him to do so.

Despite the progress that has been achieved so far, major obstacles remain. We certainly continue to urge all parties to respect the cease-fire in Beirut and to cooperate with all efforts to secure a peaceful and negotiated settlement and an end to the violence. As the Prime Minister emphasised when he last addressed this matter in a major way on 15 August, the Government is convinced that after 14 years of fighting it must be clear that no settlement in Lebanon can be imposed by force. Only compromise and accommodation by all parties can now bring the fighting there to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer the Minister to reports last week that the tourist industry will be asking Federal and State governments for $30m to help counter the damage caused by the pilots dispute. Has the Government agreed to provide direct financial help to the industry and, if so, how much? What is the Government's current estimate of the cost to tourism of the dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that the tourist industry, along with the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, has been looking at a package not so much to compensate the industry but to revitalise it. I have been told that that is about ready and that that package should be put to government fairly shortly. I have not seen the details of it but my understanding is that it will be dealt with in the next few weeks.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister two questions, including: what is the Government's current estimate of the cost to tourism? As he is the senior Minister for tourism I would have thought that he could have given us more details in his answer, which was particularly sketchy. If he is not able to give me an estimate of the losses of dollars and jobs, is he seriously indicating to us that he is not even attempting to monitor the situation as the senior Minister for tourism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that to attempt now to estimate the cost to the tourist industry across Australia of the pilots strike would be an enormous job. There are thousands and thousands of very small businesses as well as very large ones which are suffering. We have a very, very able Minister for tourism in Clyde Holding. It is his job to monitor the situation. In accordance with the portfolio arrangements which I have worked out with him, which may be of interest to the honourable senator, when he is ready with a Cabinet submission he will bring it to me, he and I will discuss it and we shall go forward.
—So you're not monitoring it?
—I do not need to watch over his shoulder. I have confidence--
—The Government isn't monitoring it?

—Senator Newman does not appear to be listening. There is a Minister working flat out on this matter. He is continuing to do that. That is his job. He will do it well. I only wish Senator Newman did her job nearly as well.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of the Sultan of Yogyakarta, Sri Sultan Hamengku Buwono X. On behalf of honourable senators I welcome him to the Senate and trust that his visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SHEEP AND GOAT EXPORTS TO MIDDLE EAST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Further to my questions of 26 September and 6 October I ask: Firstly, is it true that Mr Gardner Murray and Mr Robert Biddle of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy spent some time in Saudi Arabia and other Middle East countries following the rejection of Australian live sheep? Secondly, was this the so-called high level delegation referred to in media reports? Thirdly, will the Minister table the report or reports of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy officers Murray and Biddle? Fourthly, will the Minister table the report or reports of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy officers and/or other veterinarians and officers of statutory authorities relating to the rejection of Australian live sheep in the Middle East? Fifthly, what arrangements, if any, have been made to send a veterinarian experienced in communication with officials in Middle Eastern countries to resolve outstanding health and welfare concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Gardner Murray and Mr Robert Biddle, both of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, did visit Saudi Arabia and other Middle East countries after the initial rejection of a shipment of Australian live sheep to Saudi Arabia. Senator Jenkins's second question described the mission as a `so-called' high level mission. That may be a reflection on the officers concerned. They are senior officers of the Department. Mr Gardner Murray, for example, is the Director of the Bureau of Rural Resources, a former Director of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and a world ranking veterinarian in his own right, so I do not think `so-called' is a slur that I should allow to pass. Those officers were joined in the delegation by a Mr Charles Jamieson, the Minister Commercial of the Australian Embassy at Riyadh, and had discussions in Saudi Arabia.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jenkins asked two questions about tabling reports. I have replied to those questions previously by saying that we will not at this stage table any reports. The reports made by the high level mission were made by cablegram and orally to the Minister when the reporters returned from their mission. At this stage we do not think it is appropriate to table the reports, as the matters are of some sensitivity. Finally, Senator Jenkins asked why we do not appoint a veterinarian skilled in Arabic or things Saudi Arabian to operate in that country. We do have a veterinarian accredited to our Embassy in Riyadh as an officer of the Embassy, and he specialises in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the waterfront in-principle agreement statement by Mr Willis on 11 October, the thrust of which was that a pay-out of $300m from taxpayers, exporters and importers to remove featherbedding in the waterfront will result-the Minister's words were `will result', not `may result'-in a near 30 per cent increase in labour productivity. Can the Minister advise how this increase in productivity will be measured? What assurances can the Government give of achieving an increase of this magnitude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The in-principle agreement negotiated with stevedoring employers and unions represents the best opportunity that we have ever had for a substantial and lasting reform of the waterfront industry. It substantially meets the Government's criteria for an acceptable in-principle agreement that were set out in Mr Willis's statement to the Parliament on 1 June. We will ensure that the benefits of the reform process are achieved through the Government's control over redundancy funding.

ANSWER.PARA: The productivity increases to which Senator Parer referred and which are envisaged are dependent, of course, upon actions by all parties, including both unions and management. The improvements that are expected to flow from the enterprise agreements to be negotiated over the next 12 months will provide the basis for the introduction of new technology and changes to work and management practices necessary for this to occur. The Government contributions toward redundancy assistance will be conditional upon the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority being satisfied that these enterprise agreements will bring about the efficiency gains required. One cannot be more explicit than that about the precise content of the productivity gains that are anticipated, but the process that has been laid out and the sanctions available for ensuring that that process operates are sufficient to give us all confidence that major gains will now be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question: the Minister in his response pointed out that these so-called productivity gains would be dependent on all parties, but I again draw his attention to the statement by the Minister when he said that this in-principle agreement would result in a near 30 per cent increase in labour productivity. How does the Minister reconcile this assurance of productivity increases with comments by Mr Tas Bull, Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, that the union would not guarantee any particular level of productivity improvement?

—It is because the union itself does not have the whole burden of achieving the particular levels of productivity gains that were identified by the Minister. It is the joint responsibility of the unions and management to each contribute in their respective spheres to achieving that particular outcome. I thought I had made that clear in my response. But I will ask the Minister whether he is willing to add something more to the answer or give further elaboration.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen recent reports in the press which indicate that Australian iron ore producers are looking for substantial increases in the price of iron ore in 1990? Will the Minister or the Government take any action to assist the companies to achieve this objective?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me deal with the last part of that question first. We, of course, authorise exports out of Australia. I do that in the case of iron ore. But at this point there appears to me to be absolutely no reason why the Australian Government would interfere with the commercial workings of the international iron ore market. However, I can say in respect of the first part of Senator McKiernan's question that the annual Australian-Japan iron ore conference commenced yesterday in Japan. A number of newspaper articles have speculated about the price that might be settled on for iron ore for the year 1990. That is not surprising because obviously this central issue is being discussed at the conference.

ANSWER.PARA: We, as a matter of course, monitor the international market. We, as a matter of course, talk with our Australian producers. We are aware of what is being discussed by other iron ore producers who compete with our companies on the main international markets. There is a view that it may be possible to negotiate a 30 per cent increase in prices in the market for the 1990 supply year. I certainly believe that there is cause for expectations that there will be a substantial increase in iron ore pricing for the next round. I base that on some of the indications that I have had from yesterday's meeting of the Australian-Japan iron ore conference. I also base it on the fact that world steel production is projected to remain high in 1990-91 and that in Japan production will be at least 100 million tonnes. I also base it on the fact that the world iron ore supply at the present time is very tight. Last year there was a 15 per cent price increase but that followed seven successive years of low prices and, indeed, still left us 14 per cent below the prices that were achieved in 1982.

We have seen a major increase in productivity in Australian iron ore mines. We have seen the writing of long term contracts between the three major producers with Japanese steel companies involving between five and seven years for supply. We expect that this year Australia will attain 46 per cent penetration of the Japanese market and probably next year 48 per cent if the trend line continues. This is happening at a time when alternative markets away from Japan constitute about 52 per cent of the total overseas supply of Australian iron ore. We have seen Australia emerge in the eyes of the world as a reliable supplier. I think that is something for which workers in the industry need to be recognised.

The Australian-Japan iron ore conference which, as I said, commenced yesterday, is the scene setter for negotiations. —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What progress, if any, has been made in resolving this issue in discussions with Canada?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been ongoing discussions with the Canadians on this issue for a number of months involving the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and most recently me in Ottawa a few days ago with Canadian Trade Minister Crosbie, the issue being future terms of access for Australian canned fruit to the Canadian market with Australia very concerned not to be disadvantaged vis-a-vis the United States of America on tariffs, not least because of the advantage we have traditionally had under the explicit terms of the Canada-Australia trade agreement in Canada. The implications of the loss of that trade to Canada are very great indeed, as Senator Zakharov has indicated with those graphic figures.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased to be able to say against that background that the Prime Minister has just announced today in Kuala Lumpur that he has now reached agreement with the Prime Minister of Canada, Mr Brian Mulroney, on the resolution of this issue. The Prime Minister said that the agreement means that the Canadian tariff on Australian canned fruit can be phased down, in the context of the Uruguay Round, to a level which leaves the Australian industry competitive with other exporters. The Australian industry can now have the confidence that the tariff rate it faces will permit it to remain both viable and competitive. The precise rate of reductions in tariffs will be settled by our negotiators in the Uruguay Round. Negotiations are to commence forthwith and are to be completed within a year. We do not have to await the completion of the round to finalise this particular issue.

This is a very satisfying result, certainly for the Australian fruit growing and canning industry. It is yet another example of the very close cooperation that Australia and Canada have been able to enjoy on issues of mutual concern and interest-there have been some other topics of cooperation in the last few days as well-and it represents the commitment of both our countries to trade liberalisation, an important commitment to put on the record yet again in the context of the forthcoming regional economic cooperation meeting in Canberra in a couple of weeks time, quite apart from more generally.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen the article in the Weekend Australian which reports that a huge increase in government funding and widespread community support for environmental programs are necessary to save Australia's main river system-the Murray-Darling-from saline degradation? Is the Government concerned about this situation? If so, what is it doing about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen that article. In fact, it follows a report of last Friday's meeting of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council which occurred in the South Australian Riverland under the aegis of the host State, South Australia. The Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, a body comprising government representatives from New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the Commonwealth, is the intergovernmental agency through which we have developed an integrated plan for the management of the Murray-Darling Basin from an agricultural production, residential, social and environmental point of view. The article in the Weekend Australian identifies what we all know-that the significant problem in the Murray-Darling Basin is the high level of salinity that comes down the Murray River. The significant outcome of the Ministerial Council meeting last Friday was that all of those three States and the Commonwealth agreed on a $7.7m natural resource management strategy which will mean that all of the three States and the Commonwealth are coordinated in their activities around that strategy to cause a reduction in the significant problems of salinity, as well as waterlogging in parts of the catchment and on irrigation plots, and to improve the natural resources of the basin so that the agricultural, social and environmental values can be protected.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to that natural resource management strategy, the Council endorsed a community of common concern approach, to set up a series of community groups along the river systems which will take the task of managing the region in which they operate into their own hands and effect, hopefully, attitudinal change among land-holders about how to manage those land systems in concert with the natural resource management strategy that we have talked about. The major projects under that strategy are an acceleration of further ground water studies, the management of special projects on the environment concerning wetlands, fishing and forest management and the promotion and development of community land care groups on the land degradation front. The Council also agreed last Friday that it would commission a major report from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics into the cost of water as supplied to irrigation farmers along the river. It took that view because it felt that, in addition to these remedial programs that the strategy puts in place, there is a need to look at the economic costs of the development that goes on along the river. Water being the most cost sensitive input, that is an area for particular study. The Council will meet again in March and consider the activities that it should engage in from there.

The CAA is satisfied that the training course undertaken by the pilots in question has been consistent with the maintenance of normal safety standards. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October Senator Hill asked Senator Button a question about exported live sheep in Saudi Arabia. I am now in a position to give him a more detailed answer. The Government has made known its concerns to the Saudi Arabian authorities on a number of occasions. A high level delegation visited Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman and the United Arab Emirates in August. Mr Duffy wrote to the Saudi Arabian Commerce Minister on 23 August noting that Australia regarded the dispute as a major trade policy matter with potentially serious adverse implications for the bilateral trade relationship.

ANSWER.PARA: I took the opportunity of my presence at the Foreign Ministers meeting in Belgrade to clearly highlight the concerns of the Australian Government at the situation. I did this in a discussion with the Saudi Arabian Deputy Foreign Minister on 4 September. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has written twice to the Saudi Arabian Minister for Agriculture and Water, most recently on 7 September, when he proposed a range of cooperative technical measures to resolve Saudi concerns about the health of our live sheep exports.

The Government certainly welcomes the offers by the Australian-Saudi Arabia Business Council and the Australia-Arab Chamber of Commerce and Industry to use their good offices with the Saudi Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Riyadh to help resolve the dispute, an offer which was in effect supplemented in a very helpful discussion that I had in New York a couple of weeks ago with the Arab League Ambassador, Clovis Mahsoud, on the same subject.

The Government, in determining its overall approach to the dispute, accepted the offer of the Business Council to contact its Saudi counterpart and enlist its support. A further suggestion to hold an extraordinary meeting of the Australian Saudi Arabia Joint Commission is one of a range of options still under consideration should further measures be required. My Department has been in contact with the Australia-Saudi Arabian Business Council since the dispute began. I have also responded formally to the 12 October letter from the Australia-Arab Chamber of Commerce and Industry and thanked the Chamber for its offer.

The Government's current strategy in handling the dispute has been to develop a dialogue with the Saudi Arabian Minister for Agriculture and Water, Dr Al Shaikh. The Minister, who has only recently returned to Riyadh, met the Australian Ambassador on 18 October for what were, I understand, friendly and open discussions. The dialogue is clearly going to continue. We consider that it would not be productive to disclose details of the discussions at this stage. The Government's principal concern, obviously, is to resolve this matter as fast as possible and in the process continue the sound commercial relations that Australia and Saudi Arabia have enjoyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Let me start with some praise, by approving the fact that the nineteenth annual report of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is already in the Parliament. Let me also congratulate Mr Barry Ireland, who is the new managing director of this Corporation. Let me wish him well. I congratulate the retiring chief executive officer, Mr Doug Price, who has been associated with the Snowy scheme since January 1950 and with the Corporation since its formation in 1970. For the last 13 years he was its chief executive. I quote from the Chairman's foreword which says of Mr Doug Price:
. . . and not only played a key role in extending and enhancing its world-wide reputation but also in restoring its financial viability.

One would have to be somewhat tongue in cheek to talk of the `financial viability' of this organisation. I wish Mr Barry Ireland well because he has before him a massive task to restore the financial viability of this organisation. Let me give you an example, Mr President. During this year under review, the Government's contribution to this organisation of over $16m was converted into a share capital of $4m with reserves of $1.2m and retained profits, making the current shareholders' equity $5.345m. So in future when we read these reports it will appear as if the Government's contribution to this organisation was only $4m, whereas in fact it has been over $16m.
Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation

When we turn to the operating profit for the year we see that the organisation made the massive profit of $218,000. It is much more interesting to look at how that $218,000 is made up. It received income from short term deposits of $508,000. That would immediately indicate that its true position was a loss. Let me go a step further and say that the report also shows other revenue of $827,000. I have had this report since only 2 o'clock; so I have been unable to ascertain what that $827,000 of other revenue is made up of, but I presume that some of it is from the sale of assets and the so-called operating profit arising from those things. The director's statement says:
The net profit for 1988-89 was $218,000. the net profit after extraordinary items was $274,000, after having met incorporation costs of $66,000 and earned-
I would put that word in quotation marks-
$122,000 from the sale of assets.

However, its actual operating profit was $218,000, of which we have income from short term deposits. So if it had just closed down the operation and left the money in the bank, it would have made a profit of close on $508,000, which was its income from short term deposits. This other revenue took up what one might call extraordinary items of $1.335m. Yet notwithstanding that, it ended up with an operating profit of only $218,000. Clearly, this organisation continues to lose money. One wonders what the Government sees in this organisation and why it retains it. I urge the Government to adopt our policy and sell this organisation as soon as it can find a buyer. Mr Barry Ireland, the new managing director, the new chief executive officer, might find himself very fortunate because as soon as we get into government we intend offering this organisation for sale. We will start by offering it to the officers of the organisation. So Mr Barry Ireland might ultimately come to own an organisation which, on the basis of the report, has returned to financial viability.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Senate is aware that at the time the Education for Active Citizenship in Australian Schools and Youth Organisations report was brought down, several months ago, it was acknowledged generally as being an extremely important report. The reference was received most enthusiastically. It was a pleasure and a privilege to work on the reference over the months that we did and then to be a party to the report. I welcome the Government's response to the report although, in some respects, I am a little disappointed with that response. In essence it is a positive response, and for that we can be grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the public comments, and the comments made within this chamber, in relation to the report have acknowledged the fact that it focused on an aspect of Australian society which was absolutely vital to the survival of democracy as we know it. Democracy is about people participation. In other words, it is about active citizenship. The inquiry revealed that Australians are not well equipped, or well motivated to be active and effective citizens. In that respect, therefore, a true democratic process is denied us. There can be no true democracy without truly intelligent, active and informed citizenship. The Government, in its response to the report, acknowledges the essential validity of that observation. It commits itself to the recommendations of the report.

The one aspect of the Government's response which is probably a little disappointing is that the Government commits itself only indirectly. It commits itself by acknowledging the significance of this report, supporting the recommendations verbally and making suggestions and recommendations to States that certain actions should be undertaken, but abstains from committing itself in any truly effective way. In the final analysis, if this report is to be successfully implemented it is important that the Federal Government undertake the direct, active promotion of the type of citizenship which will maintain a vital democracy for us. It is important that the Federal Government be directly involved with and committed to the process. It is important that the Federal Government commit funds to the process. All that is contained within this Government response to the report is a commitment in principle. I believe that the Senate should press the Government for a commitment through action.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Policy Statement by the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make a few brief remarks concerning aspects of the reform of Commonwealth superannuation and, in doing so, draw attention to the fact that I am hopeful that this will go some way towards restoring morale in the Public Service, which under this Government has reached an all time low. The superannuation scheme as it has existed has been known for some time not to satisfy the needs of people who are genuinely in the scheme in that about only one-third of people actually receive benefits under it in a legitimate way. It was subject to great abuses by way of people retiring from the Service due to invalidity at a rate that is at least 10 times higher than that of the private sector. Following the creation of the new superannuation scheme, offers will be made to existing members to leave the existing scheme and to enter the new scheme; and additional benefits will make it attractive for them to so do. But the important question of the ability to leave the scheme due to being an invalid still will remain a problem.
An interesting statement appears at page 161 of Reform of Commonwealth Superannuation:

Invalidity rates for the CSS as a whole have in the past been up to 10 times higher than in the private sector. However, in 1987-88 data show considerable improvement, and when Telecom and Australia Post (which have higher invalidity rates) are excluded from the data, the rates are about 5 times the private sector average.

Very simply that means that the abuse by Telecom Australia and Australia Post has been in excess of 10 per cent and, indeed, the plan is for both Telecom and Australia Post to create their own schemes and funds and for employees to be offered membership of those funds. It is to be hoped that the terms of those funds will be such that the rate-and that rort, if you like-will be cut back. It is of concern that the Government has known of these statistics for so long and yet has not addressed them until now. The document goes on to say:

The costings assume that these improvements will be sustained in the current CSS, and that invalidity rates will be further reduced by about 40 per cent (to about three times the private sector average) in the new scheme.

That remains a matter of some concern. Why should the invalidity rate be three times the rate of the private sector? I cannot really believe that people in the public sector will remain three times as ill or infirm as those in the private sector just as it was untenable to say that they were likely to be 10 times as ill or infirm under the previous scheme. The major mechanism which the Government is using to curtail these rorts is that no longer will it be the employer who will make the decision about whether someone can be invalided out; it will be the trustee. So the criterion will be much stricter. I hope that one would aim to have the rate of people retiring due to illness being on a par with the private sector and not three times that rate, as the reform document predicates.

Several other initiatives which are part and parcel of this new scheme are to be commended including the introduction of competitive attitudes. The fact that the fund, however, is still not to be fully funded is to be deplored and, indeed, is disappointing. Whereas various State superannuation funds were moving to become fully funded until the last superannuation changes when various State funds decided they could not afford the additional 15 per cent tax that would be imposed on them, nonetheless, one State, New South Wales, has still decided--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
