SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have pleasure in moving that the Senate take note of the first annual report of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission; and I wish to refer to the Commission's role. The document says that the role is one of coordination rather than direct management. The Commission works in conjunction with four governments, which is in itself a great achievement. All governments involved in this cooperative approach to the problems of the Murray-Darling should be congratulated, because it is vital that the four States involved work in unison.

A council has been established to develop and implement an integrated management plan for long term sustainable development of the basin's resources. The Murray-Darling basin encompasses most of New South Wales, a portion of Queensland, all of northern Victoria, and some areas east of Adelaide in South Australia; a total of 1.06 million square kilometres, or 14 per cent of Australia's land mass. We are talking about an area that is very large and that produces the bulk of Australia's agricultural and horticultural products. It supports one-half of the country's sheep and crop lands and a quarter of its dairy farms and cattle. Of the 1.6 million hectares of land irrigated in Australia, 1.2 million hectares are located in this basin. The Commission's activities, therefore, are wide reaching.

The most critical problem to which a solution must be found is the salinity management of the two rivers. It is tackling this problem on a number of fronts: through salinity and drainage strategy, a natural resources management strategy, a Murray-Darling basin hydrology study and various conferences that provide a forum for an exchange of ideas and publicity for the Commission's work.

It is pleasing to read that salinity mitigation schemes kept 191,000 tonnes of salt from entering the Murray in 1987-88. The Commission's objectives are to improve water quality in the river for all uses: agricultural, environmental, urban, industrial and recreational. It also aims to control land degradation and to rehabilitate existing degraded lands to ensure sustainable utilisation of the lands in the area.

The report will provide a useful resource document on issues such as salinity levels and water flow levels at various points along the river system. It also lists fauna and flora in the region and various land degradation problems found in the region.

I pay tribute to the work of Professor John Burton, who was the first person appointed to the community advisory committee of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. I commend the report and congratulate the Commission on the job it has done so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should also like to speak to the first report of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. I welcome the initiative of the governments concerned to come together and consider more than the old River Murray Commission, which simply determined the distribution of water between the States but was not able to determine the quality of water. This Commission goes a great deal further than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot help but note that many of us in the conservation movement worked for many years before governments in various States responded and created this Commission. It has been clear for a very long time that the Murray-Darling basin was being degraded, particularly with the rising salt levels in much of the soil. The report points out that much of the area has been under the sea in times past, and there is an extremely saline aquifer underlying the area. The combination of irrigation and clearance along the Murray has led to very serious problems of salinisation and rising salt water tables.

I am concerned that, until quite recently, in South Australia the clearing of much of the Murray Mallee lands was continuing. Colleagues of mine who work in the Engineering and Water Supply Department in South Australia have drawn my attention to the fact that much of the fairly recently cleared land is underlain with salt and that the salt table has risen. It has created a large salt wedge which in some places runs back from the Murray River as much as 50 kilometres, and that wedge is slowly moving towards the river. Virtually irrespective of what is done now, the levels of salt are likely to rise as a consequence of that. The problem is one of very long term management.

We have been slow in instituting proper management. In recent years we have seen some rather undesirable plans for managing this problem by engineering. In the early 1970s I remember that a report by engineers Gutteridge Haskins and Davey Pty Ltd suggested that the solution to the problem of salinity was to dig a drain parallel with the river, to send the fresh water down the drain, put all the salt water drainage back into what remained of the river, and essentially turn the river into a drain. We have moved on from that, but I am concerned when I read that the salt interception schemes are not designed to remove the salt from the area, but only to move it away from the direct areas of irrigation. I wonder about the long term consequences of leaving the salt in the area.

I must also reflect on the fact that much of the irrigated area, particularly in South Australia, is used for the growing of citrus. At present we have a system in which the importation of orange juice is severely undercutting the production of orange juice from that indigenous source. It seems that on the one hand we may well have severely compromised an environment, and on the other hand we are adopting economic and trade policies which are likely to destroy the very industry that we have established as a consequence of this irrigation program.

The work that has gone on in the Murray has severely interfered with a number of native species. The Murray cod is in dire straits. I noted also, rather surprisingly, a press report the other day which said that the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has gone so far as to introduce the Murray cod into the Cooper River. I would have thought, at a time when we know a lot about the transfer of species into alien environments, that that should have been given a great deal more thought. The Murray-Darling basin is clearly an important catchment. It is being managed now as a total catchment and that is desirable. But the Murray-Darling basin will require very careful and long term management and I hope it gets it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to speak to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody report on the death of John Raymond Pilot. John Raymond Pilot died in the Brisbane city watch-house on 25 January 1987. Unfortunately, I have not had time to read the whole of the report as it was tabled only a short while ago. But the parts of the report that I have been able to read arouse a great concern and follow a pattern that has already been established in previous reports into Aboriginal deaths in custody. In fact, one must ask oneself, `When will they ever learn?'.

Aboriginal people are concerned that, although we are told in reports such as this one that the death is a consequence of official neglect, no charges are being laid and everything seems to be proceeding as usual. Only in yesterday's edition of the Canberra Times an article stated:
A coronial inquest will be held into the death of a 17-year-old Aboriginal youth found dead yesterday-
that should read, `on Saturday'-
in his cell at Maitland gaol in the NSW Hunter Valley.
Dermot Pidgeon was found hanging by a sheet from the bars of his cell door when cells were being opened at 7.15 a.m. . . . the time of death was estimated to be around 9 p.m. on Saturday night.

I would also like to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that yesterday the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody began an inquiry at Wiluna in Western Australia into the death of Robert Anderson who died in the Wiluna police lock-up somewhere between 12 noon on 27 February and 7 a.m. on 28 February 1983. There was no report in the newspapers and there was no State inquest into that death in custody. No cause of death was recorded and an attempt was not made to explain it.

It we look at the report on John Raymond Pilot we find that Commissioner Wyvill describes Pilot as an Aboriginal who had died alone-a 33-year-old unemployed homeless Aboriginal man with a serious history of alcohol abuse. He describes the cause of death as `asphyxia brought about by a fit following a complete withdrawal of alcohol'. Commissioner Wyvill states that Pilot died in the Brisbane watch-house, which is run by the Queensland Police Force, as a consequence of official neglect. He went on to say:
The place where he was incarcerated, the system of purported checks on prisoners and the neglect by senior watchhouse staff all contributed.

The five recommendations of Commissioner Wyvill are in keeping with recommendations made in previous reports. First, he recommends that a log or record should be completed by an officer before he finishes his period of duty. Secondly, he recommends that where, in the course of an investigation, an explanation is required of a police officer's conduct, that officer should immediately provide such an explanation in the form of a signed statement. Thirdly, he recommends that a police investigation of a death in custody should be conducted by a commissioned officer who should make a full inquiry. Fourthly, he recommends that a police officer whose conduct is likely to be the subject of inquiry should not under any circumstances take an active part in the investigation. Fifthly, he recommends that no prisoner should be so isolated from his gaolers that neither he nor those nearby can summon their assistance.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present the twelfth report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the thrust of the report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. Once again, there has been an unsatisfactory resolution between the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, appointed by this chamber, and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in respect of the appropriations for the funding of the Department of the Senate for the forthcoming financial year. The President says in the report:

In its Eleventh Report to the Senate, presented on 1 September 1988, the Appropriations and Staffing Committee reported that the procedures laid down by the Senate in its resolution of 2 December 1985 for the determination of appropriations for the Senate had not been followed, in that appropriations determined by the Committee had been reduced by the Minister for Finance without the required consultation shortly before the introduction of the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89.

The Appropriations and Staffing Committee met and, within the terms of the resolution, determined the funding requirements that it judged would be required for the efficient administration and the discharge of duties and responsibilities of the Department of the Senate. The Minister for Finance responded arbitrarily at the eleventh hour-dare I say he responded capriciously to the President, as Chairman of the Committee-to say that he had unilaterally taken it upon himself to determine that the funding would be decidedly less that what was determined by the Committee.

On 2 December 1985, Estimates Committee A, which at that time was chaired by Senator Richardson, agreed to a resolution which was adopted unanimously by the Senate. That resolution provided that the level of funding for the appropriation for the Department of the Senate shall be determined by the Senate on the advice of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. That was a sensible resolution in terms of arriving at a solution to the funding requirements of parliamentary departments. Quite obviously, if it is left exclusively in the hands of the government there is no separation between the Executive and the Parliament and the Parliament has, in an obsequious way, to go to the government cap in hand, begging for adequate funds to allow it to fulfil its obligations, which include proper examination and scrutiny of the conduct of the government.

Senator Walsh himself voted for that resolution, the motion having been carried more than once. Last year when I asked Senator Walsh why he had not chosen to raise his hand or signal his dissenting voice in the face of an affirmative vote by his own Party and the Government, he said that he treated the resolution with the same contempt then as he did at the time I asked him the question. In more recent times, on 26 October 1988, Senator Walsh tells us, he wrote to the President as Minister for Finance, stating:

As you would be aware it is the Government's prerogative to advise the Governor-General with respect to his recommendations concerning Appropriation Bills, pursuant to Section 56 of the Constitution. And, of course, it is the Government's responsibility also to raise the associated revenue. Given these responsibilities of the Executive, as Minister for Finance, I could not agree to a process whereby the Parliament was able to determine aggregate funding for its own purposes, particularly in the absence of adequate external consideration.

In other words, Senator Walsh was saying, `I have total and absolute disregard and disrespect for the resolution and for the proposition that the Parliament appropriate its own funding'. Senator Walsh seems to ignore the fact that the appropriations are passed by the Parliament, not by the Executive. They may be brought into the Parliament by way of legislation, but they can be passed only with the approval and the vote of the Senate. Senator Walsh telling us that it is the responsibility of the Executive demonstrates or highlights in a subliminal way the attitude of the Executive, particularly Senator Walsh, towards the functioning and the processes of our system of government.

So the President was obliged to report to the Senate last year that the due processes as set out in the resolution had failed. They covered a number of steps. In the event that the Minister for Finance did not agree with the Appropriations and Staffing Committee there were to be mechanisms to overcome those problems. There were solutions by way of meetings, arrangements, discussions and negotiations and it is set out very clearly how the problems would be overcome. Senator Walsh put that all aside, as did the Government, and chose at the very last minute-notwithstanding the belief of officers of the Department of the Senate that they had had meaningful and realistic discussions with officers of the Department of Finance; they believed that they had an understanding as to what the level of funding ought to be-to send a letter in the mail to departmental officers which said, `All bets are off. This is what I have decided you can have for the functioning of the Department of the Senate'.

Perhaps I would have slightly less pain if I had not heard Senator Walsh say in this Parliament on one occasion, when there was a suggestion of a new select committee to inquire into a certain matter-as I recall it was a matter which arose as a result of legislation-that he would make sure there was not sufficient funding to allow the committee to function. Senator Walsh was taking us back to the days of the Stuart kings whereby he would decide on the capacity of the Parliament to function in the appropriate way.

Having gone through all those painful steps, the President reporting to the Parliament and his report being unanimously adopted, we faced the prospect of the same thing happening this year. The President, anticipating some problems, wrote to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, on 9 July this year. He asked that a well-briefed, informed Minister of the Crown from the Senate, representing the Government, attend the meetings and the deliberations of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee so that he could express the views of the Government-whether it be in detail or in general policy-and understand the reasons for determinations and deliberations of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee. Senator Button appointed Senator Bolkus, who came along for his sins and who gave me the impression-I hope that I was not hoodwinked-that he was across the broad issues that were confronting the Committee. He raised a number of matters which were discussed in an amicable, sensible and appropriate way and the resolution for the level of funding came to pass without any acrimony or disagreement from Senator Bolkus or various members of the Committee. Those meetings took place on 5 and 7 June. Against my better judgment, the Committee cut $800,000 from the first bid. That shows the naivety, or perhaps the decency-or perhaps a combination of both-of members of that Committee. As I recall it, that $800,000 came from the creation of positions that had not been filled. We resolved that we would seek appropriations only at levels at which we were certain they would be expended and the outlays absorbed in a very tangible way.

On 16 June, just a week or so later, about two months before the Budget was to be introduced, the President wrote to the Minister for Finance setting out the resolution of the Committee and giving him very considerable detail as to the determination of the appropriations. On 2 August, some six weeks after the President had written to the Minister for Finance, the Minister for Finance wrote back-it was his first direct, or, I suspect, indirect, communication with the Committee-simply saying that he did not agree with the determination of the Committee and was lopping off a hulking $1.8m. This was on 2 August, the very eve of the introduction of the Budget-at the eleventh hour. At that stage it was totally impossible for the Committee to have any meaningful discussions or consultations with the Minister or his Department. It was a fait accompli; we were being told by the Minister that that was it.

So the whole mechanism, the whole pro- cess, failed again, notwithstanding the fact that voluminous correspondence had been entered into between the President, the Minister for Finance and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. It was as if the whole process had not taken place. Senator Walsh simply wrote back six weeks later saying, `$1.8m is coming off', for all sorts of obscure reasons. The President, with indeterminable patience, responded by writing to the Minister for Finance, reminding him of the resolution of the Senate. We got no proper response to the resolution of the Senate of 2 December 1985 because the Minister for Finance had already expressed his attitude, which was one of contempt and total disregard. Presumably he was representing the views of the Government. Nothing further happened.

But in an almost farcical sense of goodwill, spirit of cooperation and absurd naivety the Committee determined to meet the Minister for Finance and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. A number of members of the Committee sought to go along and the Secretary of the Committee, Mr Terry Brown, was given the responsibility of arranging a date on which the Committee could meet with the Minister for Finance. Notwithstanding numerous phone calls and, as I recall it, numerous letters, the Minister for Finance refused-there is no other way of putting it-to meet the Committee. He was just unavailable. The lights were on but nobody was home. He was just not interested in meeting the Committee.

I think Senator Button then prevailed in some way or another. I wrote to the Secretary of the Committee and said, `On my behalf please withdraw any further communications as I do not propose to be a member of a committee that is treated with the contempt that we are or a committee that has to seek, in this absurd and benign fashion, to make communications with the Minister for Finance, only to be treated with contempt'. The same day as I delivered my letter to the Secretary he told me that the Minister for Finance had agreed to a meeting. That was between six weeks and two months after the Committee had first sought to have a meeting with the Minister.

I suppose it could be said that that meeting was of some benefit because at least it seemed to settle the Department of Finance, which clearly did not understand how part of the calculations had been done. I think one of the matters raised by the Minister for Finance was the question of inflation. We had accommodated inflation in a different way. But at the end of the day there was no satisfactory resolution as to the bottom line figure. The Minister for Finance persisted with the view that his chosen level of funding was appropriate for the Department of the Senate. I, for my part, at least will be watching the Supplementary Estimates with a great deal of care to see whether they take up the difference, in small or large part, or totally, between the determination of the Minister for Finance and that of the Committee. The Minister has proposed a new mechanism for establishing funding which includes setting a baseline figure. I know of no reason why it has taken all this time-except for the contempt the Minister has for the Committee-to come up with that determination.

There appears to be a lack of understanding by the Minister or his departmental officers as to how the Department of the Senate can arrive at a real, practical, permanent and ongoing baseline figure, given that the Department has only recently moved into a new building. There is simply no point in setting last year's figure as the base figure if it bears no relationship to the additional encumbrances and added costs associated with this building, or if last year's figure-as it was-was simply an arbitrary figure chosen by the Minister for Finance in respect of certain items. For instance, it was judged by the Appropriations and Staffing Committee that it was not unreasonable that each senator of the Commonwealth Parliament ought to have a facsimile machine in his office-a simple, normal piece of equipment for communications that middle management in private enterprise would have. We were advised by the Minister for Finance that machines had not been requested by the House of Representatives; therefore, they were inappropriate and unnecessary for senators.

When I inquired as to how the funding levels were arrived at by the House of Representatives I discovered that it does not have an appropriations and staffing committee; it has consultations between the Speaker and the Minister for Finance. If the Minister for Finance tells the Speaker that members of the House of Representatives are not to have facsimile machines, they are not included in the Budget. The base figure for the House of Representatives is arrived at by the Minister for Finance; so it is absolutely absurd for him to say that, because the House of Representatives does not need facsimile machines, they are inappropriate for the Senate. It has been the arbitrary decision of the Minister for Finance, not the decision of members of the House of Representatives.

More particularly, in terms of our problems, the real difficulty is to establish a baseline figure which is real and relevant to the functioning of the Department of the Senate in this building-a figure which is at appropriate, proper and reasonable levels, certainly levels that do not bear a relationship to past circumstances. In the eight or nine years that I have been in this Parliament it has been my view that the Department of the Senate has always struggled on a budget decidedly less than necessary for ordinary and reasonable functioning of the Department, and not least the functioning of the chamber.

I do not know where this will lead us next year. It might simply be that more than half of the senators will amend the Appropriation Bill-which they are entitled to do-and Senator Walsh will find out who ultimately determines the level of funding. But let us hope that, for once, commonsense will override arrogance and we will get a level of funding which is not only appropriate but also highly desirable for the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Second Conference of Australian Delegated Legislation Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report deals with the proceedings of the Second Conference of Australian Delegated Legislation Committees, held in Parliament House from 26 to 28 April this year. Honourable senators will recall that, at its conclusion, Senator Patterson and I reported to the Senate on the conference, which was opened by His Excellency the Governor-General, who was introduced to delegates by the President. This was the first time that the Governor-General, in his capacity as Governor-General, conducted a function in this Parliament House. I also reported on the conference in the usual statement to the Senate at the end of the previous sittings.

My clearest memory of the conference was the intensity of activity required by members of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. This involved looking after some 50 delegates from the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory and all States, except Tasmania-whose delegates had to withdraw due to the State election-and three overseas countries. As well as the speech by the Governor-General, major speeches were delivered by speakers of the calibre of the Legal Adviser to the Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan; the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor Dennis Pearce; the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, His Honour Justice Trevor Hartigan; the chairmen of two State delegated legislation committees, Ken Jasper, member of the Legislative Assembly, from Victoria and Bob Hetherington, member of the Legislative Council, from Western Australia; and a former Chairman of the Senate Committee, Senator Austin Lewis. Each speech was followed by lively discussion. Both the Deputy Chairman, Senator Bronwyn Bishop, and I conducted several working sessions. Other members of the Committee-Senators Giles, McMullan, Patterson and Stone-conducted working sessions, led discussions, introduced speakers and hosted functions. The report includes a transcript of the entire proceedings of the conference and the text of papers received. It also distils the main issues and questions which emerged. I commend the report to honourable senators as an affirmation of bipartisan commitment to the parliamentary process. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a tabling statement.
Leave granted.

SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES TABLING OF REPORT ON SECOND CONFERENCE OF AUSTRALIAN DELEGATED LEGISLATION COMMITTEES
Parliament House, Canberra

PROCTEXT.PARA: The First Conference of Australian Delegated legislation Committees, held in Brisbane in 1986, provided Australian parliamentarians who scrutinise delegated legislation with an opportunity to exchange ideas and opinions, and renew their support for each other in the task of bipartisan, technical, legislative scrutiny. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances wished to continue this desirable practice and in December 1988 offered to host the Second Conference in Canberra in April 1989.

The Committee invited the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and all Australian state and territory parliamentary committees involved in scrutiny of delegated legislation to participate in the Conference. The Committee also sent invitations to all Commonwealth Parliamentary Association branches to participate at the Conference as active observers. As a result of these invitations, delegations attended from New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia, and the Northern Territory. (A delegation from Tasmania was unable to attend due to the holding of a State election). Observer delegations attended from the Parliaments of Botswana, the British Virgin Islands and New Zealand. In all 10 Parliaments were represented by a total of 49 delegates.

The Conference was held in the Main Committee Room of Parliament House, Canberra. By the courtesy of the President of the Senate, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, the full facilities of the Commonwealth Parliament were available for the Conference and the delegates.

The President of the Senate, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, welcomed the delegates and introduced the Governor-General, His Excellency the Hon. Bill Hayden. The President emphasised the significance of legislative scrutiny committees given the complexity of executive government and increasing demands on parliamentary time.

The Governor-General, His Excellency the Hon. Bill Hayden, formally opened the Conference. This was, in fact, the first official duty of the recently appointed Governor-General in the new Parliament House since his swearing-in. In his speech to delegates, Mr Hayden stated that, despite fears about the decline of Parliament, the parliamentary institution retained its vigour in the work of its committees. Delegated legislation was an extremely important tool of modern governmental administration and parliamentary scrutiny of it assumed great importance because it helped to ensure that the government and its administration did not exceed the powers given to them by Parliament. Mr Hayden also emphasised that, although delegated legislation did not have to pass the scrutiny of Parliament prior to it coming into force, legislative scrutiny committees remained an effective control because their avoidance of party political issues enabled them to work effectively in a spirit of cooperation and bipartisanship against any misuse of power and authority by government.
The Conference was also addressed on particular topics related to delegated legislation by a distinguished group of parliamentarians and lawyers.

Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan of the Australian National University, Legal Adviser to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, spoke of his experiences as an independent legal adviser.
Senator Bob Collins, Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, spoke about his experiences of bipartisanship in legislative scrutiny committees.
Senator Austin Lewis, a former Chairman of the Senate Committee, spoke on legislative scrutiny as a last hope for the idea of Australian parliamentarianism.

Ken Jasper, MP, Chairman of the Subordinate Legislation Subcommittee of the Legal and Constitutional Committee of the Parliament of Victoria, spoke on the relationship between policy and principle in subordinate legislative scrutiny in Victoria.

Professor Dennis Pearce, Commonwealth Ombudsman and former legal adviser to both the Senate Standing Committees on Regulations and Ordinances and Scrutiny of Bills, spoke on the impact of Parliamentary legislative scrutiny on the quality of public administration.

Bob Hetherington, MLC, Chairman of the Western Australian Joint Standing Committee on Delegated Legislation, spoke on the Western Australian experience of scrutiny, which he described as ``a turning back to parliamentary supremacy''.
Justice Trevor Hartigan, a Judge of the Federal Court of Australia and President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, spoke on the role of delegated legislation as a tool of administration.

Questions and discussions following each of the addresses to the Conference were lively, well informed, and directed to the future development and improvement of parliamentary oversight of executive law-making.

The Conference passed three resolutions. The first two dealt with the holding of the Third Conference in Perth in 1991. The third resolution was that Committees would report at the Third Conference on:

(a) the nature, the extent and the implications for Delegated Legislation Committees of the proliferation, within the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories, of legislative and quasi-legislative instruments which either:
(i) are not subject to parliamentary scrutiny and control, or
(ii) whether so subject or not, represent a developing trend in delegated law-making by virtue of their origins, content, presentation or otherwise;

(b) the extent to which the Parliaments of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories have been able to monitor and scrutinise and where necessary improve by amendment provisions in Bills which confer delegated law-making powers; and
(c) the progress of staged repeal of delegated legislation (where this occurs) and the problems this may have produced for scrutiny committees, and their responses to it.

Several major themes emerged during the Conference. Perhaps the most important of these was the role of parliamentarianism in legislative scrutiny. This topic also influenced discussion of other themes which developed.

Several delegates mentioned the wide bipartisan support that existed in Parliaments for their Regulations and Ordinances Committees. Committees contribute to the parliamentary institution, with an effectiveness that arises from their avoidance of party political issues. The non-partisan approach of committees provides a truly parliamentary perspective and the committees are, therefore, crucial to the preservation of the parliamentary system.

The Conference particularly affirmed the bipartisan nature of relations with ministers and the public service. This was contrasted with the executive and party political threat to parliamentarianism and all that that expression stood for. Senator Austin Lewis concluded that legislative scrutiny committees were the last hope of parliamentarianism because they were possibly the only places where it was still practised. Parliament should be constantly vigilant to protect itself against executive encroachment and executive erosion of parliamentary supremacy.

Delegates agreed that terms of reference of delegated legislation committees which provided for scrutiny on the ground that an instrument may trespass on rights and liberties clearly asserted the authority of Parliament over the executive; Parliament was supreme and it was up to Parliament, not governments, to balance conflicting individual and collective rights.

As the Conference resolution indicated, Australian committees were also concerned about the growth and effect of quasi-legislation. One delegate noted a move away from more formal regulatory instruments and commented on the frequently poor drafting and presentation of less formal instruments. Some kinds of ministerial orders were not subject to parliamentary control. One question raised here was the extent to which delegated legislation committees should recommend changes to enabling Acts. Although purely administrative instruments need not come before committees, statutes should not be undone by administrative guidelines. A decline in parliamentarianism could be illustrated by less substance in Acts, the necessary detail being supplied later in the form of binding guidelines or directions.

The Conference expressed misgivings about the increased use of regulations for policy purposes and the use of non-reviewable, but nevertheless binding, general directions. Whereas previously an Act may have set up broad parameters for regulation, now the regulations were setting up broad parameters for administrative instructions. Provisions should be made for such instructions to come before a committee if it was suspected that the executive was using them to avoid scrutiny. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal looks at instruments which fall short of binding delegated legislative enactments, including departmental practice manuals issued for the guidance of relatively junior officers. The final contributions to the Conference noted a trend to `hollow legislation', where real legislative power was in the regulations and other instruments provided for by an enabling Act (for example the Commonwealth Export Control Act 1982). There was general agreement that effective scrutiny should be expanded over the whole range of quasi-legislation.
The Conference devoted considerable attention to the question of scrutiny both of bills and also of Acts. This problem was often seen as related to that of quasi-legislation.

Discussion emphasised the importance of scrutiny of bills, particularly in relation to legislative delegations that might by-pass delegated legislation committees. In this context, principle (d) of the Senate Committee (that delegated instruments should not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment) was the most subjective of that Committee's principles and, therefore, very difficult to apply ex post facto. The problem could be avoided by more effective limitations on the scope of provisions in bills providing for delegated legislative powers.

There was a co-operative partnership between the two Senate legislative scrutiny committees, one dealing with bills and the other addressing the delegated legislation eventually arising from those bills.

Scrutiny of bills and delegated legislative scrutiny were seen as inter-dependent and not mutually exclusive, although Senator Lewis commented that ``the jury is still out'' on the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, largely because there was still no practice of the Chairman or other committee members moving and supporting amendments on behalf of that Committee or of the Senate supporting the Committee by always agreeing to proposals arising from the Committee's recommendations on matters of civil liberty or parliamentary propriety. It may be desirable to have a separate committee to deal with scrutiny of bills, rather than for this difficult function to be given to a delegated legislation committee.

A deplorable aspect of the preparation and passage of bills was the developing trend towards legislation by `press release' or `legislation by policy statement'. Another problem recurring too frequently was provision in bills for regulations to amend their parent Acts.
It was suggested that the regulation provision of an Act should be so drafted as to limit the scope of delegated legislative powers to stated purposes.

It is usual to state that delegated legislation committees avoid policy issues as part of their bipartisan role, although this obligation does not prevent the Committee challenging a so-called policy that is obviously and directly an infringement of the Committee's principles. The Committee must pursue its primary responsibility to parliamentary propriety and personal rights and liberties. Scrutiny of legislative policy is, for example, central to the operations of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The Committee does not accept as an excluded matter of policy a ministerial policy to legislate in a way that infringes the Committee's terms of reference.

Although it was sometimes difficult to see where policy ended and administration began, the members of the Senate Committee have always avoided party political dispute. The Committee had, however, made important contributions to legislative policy. Some delegates felt that issues of political or paltry policy did not arise when a Committee examined or expressed concern about the regulation-making powers of an enabling Act.

The bipartisan success of the Senate Committee was attributed to avoiding scrutiny of the merits of the instruments before it. Ministers had accepted that the Committee was not a threat to policy. Discussion followed on the various attitudes taken by different Committees towards what may be regarded as a policy matter.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee endeavours to persuade all Ministers that Explanatory Statements should accompany each legislative instrument laid before Parliament. These should explain the background to, and justifications for, the legislation, summarise its provisions and give some indication of the impact of the instrument on those likely to be affected by it. Several of the States, however, have legislative requirements for highly detailed regulatory impact statements and discussion of these was an important topic at the Conference.

The desirability of public impact statements was identified as a `major trend' for the next decade. In particular, there was a need to scrutinise the impact of regulatory laws upon the business community. It was suggested that committees retain the services of economic advisers, as well as legal advisers.

Statutory requirements for regulatory impact statements and associated mechanisms for public consultation led to discussion of exemption procedures for impact statements, the reaction of ministers and executive procedures for impact statements, the reaction of ministers and executive departments to the new requirements and the relation of impact statements to policy.
The closing statements included comments on the costs of producing impact statements, their content and drafting requirements.

Sunset and sunrise provisions and staged review were of major interest throughout the Conference. As with regulatory impact statements, this was an area in which the States have been notably active and innovative.

This general topic, including the concept of total regulatory review, was another identified as a `major trend' for the next decade. Delegates commented on the special unit in New South Wales, separate from the legislative scrutiny committee, which was established to review the number and volume of regulations. The similar Commonwealth Business Regulation Review Unit was also mentioned. The discussion included the reaction of executive departments to sunset provisions.
The final statements included several references to the need for review of outdated delegated legislation.
The role of the media also emerged as a theme at the Conference. A related topic was publicity and education about the operations of delegated legislation committees.

It was suggested that the media were devoting less time to reporting Parliament, the public service and the relationships between them. Parliamentary committees were now a safeguard in areas where the media were formerly more active. Examples were given of the lack of interest from the media.

Seminars to publicise the activities of Committees could be useful in this context. Another proposition was that there should be more educational activity on the role of committees; it was felt that the decline of Parliament would accelerate if the media and the public were uninformed.

Other issues relating to technical scrutiny by delegated legislation committees arose in the speeches and in discussion. The Conference Report expressly mentions a score of additional questions which were raised by delegates.

The Second Conference focused the attention of Australian and visiting Committees on common challenges and problems, particularly the increasing use of quasi-legislation and the need for vigilance in meeting executive encroachments on parliamentary primacy. At the same time, bipartisanship and parliamentarianism were emphasised and confirmed. This emphasis on common threats, common principles and common responses was specially productive and because of the diversity of structures, powers and functions of the different committees whose members met in Canberra to participate at the Second Conference of Australian Delegated Legislation Committees.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND NORTHERN IRELAND AND TO THE REPUBLIC OF IRELAND 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table a report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and to the Republic of Ireland in 1988. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I had the honour to be deputy leader of this delegation. It was a most congenial delegation and we were all surprised to find out that it was the very first parliamentary delegation to go from Australia to England. There have been ministerial visits in the past, but this was the first parliamentary delegation. It was historic in the sense that it took place in our bicentennial year. It was also the year of the international Expo 88 held in Australia; so visits were exchanged, with the Queen of England and the Prime Minister of England coming here for reciprocal functions.

Mr Leo McLeay, now Speaker of the House of Representatives, who was then Deputy Speaker, led the delegation in the absence of the Speaker because she was involved in functions dealing with our Bicentennial. We were looked after very well by our Australian High Commissioner in the United Kingdom, the Hon. Doug McClelland, who occupied the chair of the Senate with great distinction for several years. We were all impressed with the relationships he had built up over there. He was given the honour of meeting the teams and kicking off at the football final at Wembley-an honour usually reserved for the Queen or the Duke of Edinburgh, which was also congenial as they happened to be in Australia. He was invited to that function and he performed his duties very well. We can all understand that, seeing as he is the No. 1 ticket holder for St. George here in Australia-although he might not want that published too widely at the moment.

We met the Foreign Minister of Great Britain which was of interest because honourable senators will remember that the Fijian crisis was at its height at that time. We met the Prime Minister and had discussions with her at No. 10 Downing Street. I must say the setting for Yes, Prime Minister is a very accurate reproduction of the Cabinet room at No. 10 Downing Street. We dealt with important subjects, particularly the detente in eastern Europe and the move towards the Economic Community in 1992 and Australia's position with regard to that. We had discussions with business groups, not only in England but also in Scotland and Ireland, with a view to easing the way for Australian companies to have access to that European Community. It will be an enormous market. There will be 320 million people in a single market by 1992 and it will have enormous effects on world trading.

Highlights of the trip included visits to places such as Sellafield. I am sure honourable senators will be interested to read in the report of the plans that Great Britain has, which are well under way, for the disposal of nuclear waste. Great Britain buys a lot of the nuclear waste from around the world, not only its own. It seals it away for future use, and I am sure it will have the corner on the market when it come to recycling nuclear fuel. I am sure that will be an area of interest to honourable senators. Another area of interest was the development of the City of London on the Isle of Dogs. They call it the London port development. It is like a whole new City of London; it is almost as though the centre of London has been moved eight kilometres east. There is an airport right in the middle of it with silent jets taking off every minute for the capitals of Europe. It is gearing up for the cross-Channel tunnel commuter trade with Europe. There is a move towards a high-tech city full of industries dealing with education, banking and communications. I am sure that that is a development that honourable senators would all be interested to see, but they can read about it in the report.

We went to Ireland, and I must say it is a beautiful country. We had two Irishmen in the delegation-Senator McKiernan, who comes from Cavan, and Mr Ted Grace from the other House. He is not really Irish; he said he was conceived in Wales and born in Ireland. He enjoyed going home. We saw the beauties of Ireland and also some of the horrors of it. We went up to the border areas which were sad to see. We have reported on that. Any honourable senators who want the details of all of that can get them from the Parliamentary Library. I recommend the report because of the information it contains. We went to see why Ireland is famous for its racehorses. That was an eye-opener. The security on those racehorse studs is like that at Fort Knox. Honourable senators will remember the racehorse Shurgar which was stolen. We went to one of those studs that are now under enormous security. I think there were 67 horses on it and not one of them worth less than $10m. It had its own jet strip so that the horses did not get jet lag when they were taking off to the various major racecourses in Europe. It also had simulated straights of all the main racecourses in the world that these horses were being trained to race on. The horses are apparently bred for the races. They never run the distance that they will have to race over; that is supposed to be bred into them. It seems to be the exact opposite of everything we do in Australia. Perhaps, if we want to learn something about racehorses, we should go to Ireland and see how they do their breeding and training.

Finally, I would like to express my thanks for the trip not only to the delegation but also to the staff, Michael Talberg and John Porter. They looked after our every want over there. We made the trip as easy as we could for them, but I would like to pay tribute to them for looking after the delegation. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the honour to be part of the parliamentary delegation to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Perhaps the very first thing I should do in speaking to this report is to immediately refute the words of the previous speaker and deputy leader of the delegation, Senator Sheil, who remarked that there were actually two Irishmen on the trip. In actual fact we were all Australians. I think most of us have documentation to prove that we were certainly travelling on Australian passports on behalf of the Australian Parliament. That is not to say that some of us did not have links with Ireland and the United Kingdom of Great Britain.

SPEECH.PARA: It was an historic delegation. I find it particularly surprising that it was the first official parliamentary delegation from this Parliament to the Republic of Ireland. When one considers the links between Ireland and Australia this is an amazing feat. The first reciprocal delegation from Ireland to Australia occurred just a few years ago when a delegation of Irish parliamentarians, led by the then Speaker of the Dail Eireann, Tom Fitzpatrick, arrived in Australia. Mr Fitzpatrick, incidentally, was actually a member of the Irish Parliament representing the town where I was born. It was a very well received delegation.

Looking back some 18 months now to when the visit to both countries occurred, one tends to remember the warmest things in the first instance-the enjoyable events. This is not to say that the delegation did not do a considerable amount of work while it was in both countries. An examination of pages 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 of the report will give those interested an idea and an indication of the level of discussion and dialogue that took place between the delegation and the various representatives of governments, industry and the communities in both countries. We were grateful that each of the parliaments arranged for us to meet people at the highest levels in government. They included the Prime Minister of Britain, Mrs Margaret Thatcher, the Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Secretary of Trade and Industry, Lord Young, and so on down the list. To save the time of the Senate I will not go through the complete list.

In Ireland we were hosted by and met the Speaker of the Irish Parliament, Mr Sean Treacy, who actually visited Australia for the first time in the second Irish parliamentary delegation last year. We met the President of the Irish Senate. We also met the President of Ireland in his residence in Phoenix Park. We also met the Prime Minister of Ireland, Mr Charles Haughey, who had the honour of being the guest at the first dinner to be held in this new Parliament House. We also met all leaders of the major political parties in Ireland. Part of the delegation broke up and met with representatives of the various political parties in Britain while we were there.

We found a tremendously warm feeling for Australia in our travels throughout Great Britain and Ireland that resulted from a very high degree of publicity about Australia in both countries. The television program Neighbours-I will not give a personal opinion on this-was constantly brought to our attention. I was lucky enough to be able to say that I did not get time to watch television and that, even if I did, I would not watch a program of that nature anyway. I was able to evade questions on that program. It is certainly a very popular program in the United Kingdom and in Ireland.

It was also the occasion of the Australian bicentennial celebrations, which resulted in a vast degree of interest in Australia and Australian life. Everywhere we went we met people who had relatives here and who were inquiring about them. On some lucky occasions various members of the delegation actually knew relatives of the people who are now resident in Australia. On certain occasions we were lobbied to assist with migration applications from people in both Britain and Ireland wishing to come to Australia.

I will not go through each and every matter that is raised in the report, but there are a number I do want to refer to. We had a considerable amount of discussion and dialogue in both countries about the agricultural marketing practices of the European Community. The delegation stressed on a number of occasions whenever possible the damage and harm that those policies were doing to Australian agriculture. We said that we had a very productive culture and industry in Australia, yet were being harmed by the policies of a number of countries in Europe. We were listened to. We did not come away from all our discussions with any real hope that these policies would change in the short term. Nonetheless, the views that we expressed were heard and, I am sure, will be taken into consideration when future policies are being developed and when the present policies are being amended from time to time.

One interesting discussion we had with the British Prime Minister, Mrs Thatcher, related to the question of Australia obtaining the original of the British Act of Parliament which embodies the Australian Constitution. Our request was not received with any great acceptance by the Prime Minister. She indicated that she would be scared of setting a precedent for other such documents held in Westminster or Britain and would be reluctant to accede to our request. We are following that request through in another manner.

Senator Sheil mentioned our visit to Sellafield, the nuclear power generation plant not far from Carlisle in the north-west of England. For me that was a scary experience, probably matched only by the time when we actually went through a border post going from the Republic of Ireland into Northern Ireland and again when we flew in a light aircraft between the City of Derry and Belfast. We were not scared of being shot out of the air, but were scared of a rapidly approaching storm which was buffeting the aircraft around considerably. The pollution that flowed from that Sellafield power plant into the Irish Sea was a matter that we addressed in Britain and when we were in the Republic of Ireland meeting some Ministers of that Government.

A matter that also received quite a deal of attention in London, Dublin, Belfast and Derry was the question of Northern Ireland. The delegation conveyed to both governments the Australian Government's support for the Anglo-Irish accord and the hope that the violence that is on going in that tiny province of Ireland would soon be brought to a conclusion, either by this piece of dialogue or by some other means. It certainly received a great deal of attention. A number of Amnesty International reports on the Northern Ireland situation were brought to the attention of Mrs Thatcher and some of her Ministers. Mrs Thatcher was fairly forceful in her condemnation of what she called terrorist activities within Northern Ireland. Those activities cause sadness to anybody who has a regard for human life. Mr Howe, the Foreign Secretary, called it a crazy conflict between people of the same heritage. At this stage I should like to make a personal observation. It seems crazy but, according to the headlines last week, four prisoners who had been wrongfully gaoled for 15 years were released. Perhaps that is some excuse, but not a total excuse, for the violent activities over there.

There are two other matters that I wish to raise in conclusion. Had we been speaking to this report earlier than 18 months since the conclusion of the delegation, I might seek to speak for much longer but, as I say, there are two further matters that I wish to put into the record. The first is the meeting that we had with Mr John Hume, MP, the Leader of the Social Democratic and Labour Party in Northern Ireland. He is a member of both the Westminster Parliament and the European Parliament. I believe personally that he was the most impressive individual whom I met during the whole of the three-week trip. I know that Mr Hume and his policies and attitudes certainly impressed other members of the delegation, irrespective of their political beliefs.

Mr Hume rose to prominence during the civil rights campaigning in the 1960s and, as I said, is a member of both the Westminster Parliament and the European Parliament. He is the only Northern Ireland member of parliament who actually goes around unarmed or without an armed guard to protect him. As we stood on the spot in the City of Derry where, I think, 16 citizens were killed by British troops in 1971, he told us that the reason for his not needing protection was that he was a man of peace and that he could not be a man of peace if he went around carrying an instrument of death. Some members of the delegation, including me, have approached our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to bring Mr Hume to Australia under the distinguished visitors program so that he can speak with the Australian population on the scene in Northern Ireland and perhaps offer some ideas on the resolution of the conflict over there.

Mr Hume stressed to us that the great perception in the community not only in Australia, which is far distant from the British Isles, but also in the British Isles, that it is actually a religious conflict that is occurring in Northern Ireland is not correct. He refuted that suggestion, saying that it is more of a social problem. He pointed out that part of the social problem as it existed in his home city of Derry was that male unemployment was about 50 per cent while the average unemployment level in Northern Ireland, as a total, was 18 per cent. In the hotel in Belfast the delegation discussed with a number of community leaders matters relating to Northern Ireland. We were shown over the western suburbs of that city and shown areas in which 70 per cent of the population is unemployed. It is no wonder there are conflict and concern in that city.

Senator Sheil mentioned that I originated from Ireland, and it was thanks to the good offices of the Speaker of the Irish Parliament, Mr Sean Treacy, that the delegation visited the town in which I was born. We were very warmly received, despite my initial fright when I saw a policeman waiting at the door of the Town Hall and thought some of the misdeeds of my youth had finally caught up with me, but that was not the case. As I said, we were warmly received by the chairman and members of the Cavan Urban District Council and it was indeed an honour for me to return to the town of my birth as a representative of the Australian Parliament. I thank the representatives of the Australian Parliament for the opportunity to do that. I also thank the Parliament on behalf of those members of my family who remain in Ireland. I have four sisters and a brother, together with their respective spouses and children, still living in Ireland. It was indeed an honour for my family and me that such a reception could be held and that the delegation could be received in such a manner.

Thanks again to the good offices of Mr Treacy, my family members were allowed to join a dinner given for the delegation by one of the Ministers of the Irish Parliament later that night in my home town. Members of my family were allowed to be part of that celebration. Mr McLeay, the leader of our delegation, afforded me the honour of responding to the speech by Mr John Wilson, Minister for Tourism. While we were in Cavan, each member of the delegation was presented with an illuminated scroll, of which I have a copy in my hand, commemorating the visit by us. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table the scroll and incorporate in Hansard the text of the document given to me by the Cavan Urban District Council.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CAVAN URBAN DISTRICT COUNCIL
CIVIC WELCOME
AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION
The Chairman and Members of Cavan Urban District Council, On behalf of the people of Cavan Extend a sincere civic welcome to Senator James Philip McKiernan on the occasion of his visit to the town.
We hope that this visit will strengthen and Further develop the strong historical links and the bond of friendship which already exists between Ireland and Australia.
We are delighted to host this reception and honoured to have you as our guest. We hope that your visit to our historic town will be both fruitful and enjoyable.
Given under Official Seal of the Council This 22nd day of April, 1988.
Town Clerk...Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have spoken for much longer than I intended, but I felt that it was a great occasion for me. The delegation did a lot of hard work during the tour. I hope that other members of the Australian Parliament will have the pleasure of visiting both countries in the near future. With that hope goes the wish that perhaps the conflict that we witnessed in the northern part of the tiny island of Ireland can very soon be resolved to the benefit of all democratic, free-thinking and freedom-loving people throughout the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was part of the delegation, along with Senator Sheil and Senator McKiernan, I would like to make a few remarks on the visit of that delegation to the United Kingdom and Ireland. As has been said, it was a historic delegation. It was the first time for some 17 years that a delegation from this Parliament had visited Britain and it was the first time ever that a delegation from this Parliament had visited the Republic of Ireland. It is important that contact and links are kept with those two countries, or any country for that matter, especially in view of the number of people who migrate to our country.

SPEECH.PARA: We met both the Prime Minister of Great Britain and the Prime Minister of Ireland. We met the Foreign Ministers and a number of senior Ministers of both countries. We also met Ambassador Milne, our Ambassador to Ireland at that time. We also met Doug McClelland, who is well known to us all in the Senate and who is our High Commissioner in Britain, and he arranged very high level contact between the delegation and people in Britain. In conclusion, I believe that the delegation had a very enjoy- able and harmonious visit, and I commend the report to the Senate.
