PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 seeks to make a number of significant revisions to the Banking Act. The first main provision of the Bill is to remove all reference in the Act to trading banks and savings banks, a long maintained distinction in the banking sector of this country but one which has become redundant with the passage of time. The Bill replaces those references with general references to banks. Secondly, the Bill seeks to remove division 3 of the Banking Act, the division which concerns the statutory reserve deposit mechanism, and to replace it with a new division 3 concerning what are called non-callable deposits, a term which we have become rather more familiar with in the past couple of weeks because of other matters which I will come to later in my remarks concerning the actions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). That legislative change will facilitate the phasing down and replacement of the statutory reserve deposits by non-callable deposits.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, the Bill provides specific powers for the establishment of prudential requirements concerning the manner in which banks conduct their businesses. The Reserve Bank of Australia has, throughout its existence I suppose, but particularly in recent years since the deregulation of the financial system and in particular the banking system, exercised a considerable degree of prudential supervision over the banking system. But it has done so basically by way of informal contacts and discussions with the banks. This Bill will, in effect, formalise those existing arrangements and give the Reserve Bank powers which it will probably choose not to exercise unless it is called upon to do so but which at least it can fall back upon if necessary.

Fourthly, the Bill provides the Reserve Bank with powers of investigation into the books, accounts and transactions of banks, including, I should add-and it is an important addition-the ability to obtain information from a bank concerning individual customers. I will come to that point later in my remarks.

The coalition parties do not oppose the Bill. We will give it a second reading. Basically, it seeks to formalise what is already well established practice for prudential supervision of the banking industry. It also makes some other changes which basically pick up recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System. It is important, however, to note that the Opposition will propose amendments when we come to the committee stage.

I note that the Opposition has reservations about those provisions of the Bill, principally clause 16, which provide the Reserve Bank with powers of investigation into the books, accounts and transactions of banks, particularly its proposed ability to obtain information from a bank concerning individual customers where that is required for prudential supervisory reasons. In that respect the Opposition maintains its concern that there are not adequate safeguards in the Bill to prevent the Reserve Bank or its officers from indiscriminately seeking or using information about individual banks or their clients. I will debate that matter at more length when we come to the committee stage. But as I have already foreshadowed, we will move amendments that address that privacy issue. More immediately, we propose to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill which has been circulated. I will mention now the terms of that amendment. We seek to move:
At end of motion, add `but the Senate notes-

(1) That the Hawke-Keating Government's deal with the four major banks to manipulate the interest rates paid on the new non-callable deposits introduced in this legislation so that home mortgage interest rates would not rise higher than the already record high level, is:
(a) another desperate deal by a tired and dying Government; and
(b) does nothing to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.

(2) That, to reduce Australia's high level of interest rates, the Government must depart from its one-dimensional, tight monetary policy and adopt an integrated policy framework as set out in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan.

In last year's Budget it was announced that there would be a phasing down of the statutory reserve deposit requirement over three years and the replacement of that system with a system of non-callable deposits. Recently, in a populist move typical of a tired and dying government, the Treasurer jeopardised the integrity of these reforms when he used them as a cover for a $230m per annum deal principally with, almost entirely with, the four major banks-the deal was certainly conducted with those banks, although the $230m will not quite all accrue to those four banks-so that in return the banks would not raise home mortgage interest rates from their already record levels to which the Treasurer's monetary policies have forced them.

I want to make it quite plain that, so far as the decision to increase the rate of interest payable to banks on the non-callable deposits from their previous rate of 5 per cent to a level equal to 5 per cent below the treasury note rate is concerned, the Opposition does not question the propriety of that policy decision. What it does question is the egregious deal which the Treasurer entered into at the time, with the arms of the four bank chief executives twisted behind their backs, to require them to give a political quid pro quo for a financial policy decision.

That decision, that quite blatant injection of a political consideration into an otherwise purely financial or market operation, has probably done more to damage this Treasurer's reputation and, through him, this Government's reputation in the financial markets not only of Australia but throughout the world than the Treasurer had the slightest concept of at the time he made the deal. He has, of course, obtained a political quid pro quo for it, which I am sure has caused Government members and senators to breathe a sigh of relief because it has assisted in putting off the evil day when, under this Government's policies, this Treasurer's policies, housing loan mortgage rates would otherwise have to be raised even higher than their present 17 per cent. But, in the process, the Treasurer has unsettled conceptions in the markets as to the fiscal or financial integrity of the Government and its policies, and it will pay for that.

I suppose that none of us should have been entirely surprised by the desperation of this move by Mr Keating. After all, it followed similar deals that we have seen from this Government in recent months. We have seen the $60m hand-out to Kodak Inter- national, which has a factory located in the Coburg area of Melbourne. It was previously within the electorate of Wills, but I understand that as a result of the redistribution it is now actually located just outside the electorate of Wills, the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and is in the electorate of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). We have seen that $60 hand-out-without any basis of investigation, review, report or recommendation from the Industries Assistance Commission-to that multinational company, which is competing quite rapaciously with a number of much smaller Australian photographic processing companies, including one within my own area of the Sunshine Coast of Queensland.

Before that, we saw the Prime Minister's gladhanding approach to his friend and long-time associate, Sir Peter Abeles, through the deal done with the airlines. Through that deal the Government is now, in effect, providing taxpayers' money in order that the airlines will forgo standing down employees who, because of the pilots dispute, could not otherwise be offered gainful employment by the airlines. At the time that deal was done, its cost to the Australian taxpayer was estimated at $100m. That was at a time when the Government was assuring the Australian public that the airline dispute would be over within a relatively short time. I do not know that the Government specifically named a final date, but one would be pardoned for thinking it would have been over a month ago, at least. In fact, it is continuing and there seems to be no end in sight. I can only assume that the cost of that deal is continuing to balloon in line with the length of the dispute.

During this period we have also seen the flagrant breaking of the word of the Australian Prime Minister given to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in relation to the right to mine for gold, platinum and palladium at the Coronation Hill deposit in the Northern Territory. Not only will that decision bring great discredit to this Government, but it also puts the whole economic future of Australia in jeopardy. I think it was Sir Arvi Parbo who initially stated-and certainly Mr Hugh Morgan of Western Mining Corporation subsequently repeated it-the obvious truism that in the light of the Coronation Hill decision nobody can trust this Government. So true is that assertion that even a senior Cabinet Minister in the present Government, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), was moved to say, on his recent return from overseas-he was not present at the time the Coronation Hill decision was made, although his views were well known-that we cannot go on scaring away capital all the time like this. That was a total breach of Cabinet solidarity for which, we understand, he was reprimanded by the Prime Minister and by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) but for which, nevertheless, he has not felt it necessary to resign from the Cabinet.

Notwithstanding the magnitude and increasing frequency of these totally ad hoc deals done by the Government, they are deals which merely seek to treat the symptoms. They ignore, and continue to ignore, the fundamental problems. For example, the deal that I referred to initially on non-callable deposits, which is one of the subjects of this Banking Legislation Amendment Bill, sought a respite from higher home mortgage interest rates. But that respite is no cure for the problem of which the increasing pressure of mortgage interest rates is but a symptom. The fact is that the record high interest rates are a direct result of the one-dimensional monetary policy of the Government.

Although we hear a great deal about the level of home mortgage interest rates, and undoubtedly we should continue to hear a great deal about that because it affects a great many people, it should never be forgotten that those interest rates of 17 per cent-I am talking about bank interest rates-are as nothing compared with the height of the interest rates being paid by the 750,000 to 800,000 small businesses in this country. In most cases they are working on overdrafts at anything from 21 per cent to 25 per cent, and they include, but are by no means confined to, many members of the farming community.

Those interest rates are a direct result of the winding up of the ratchet of high interest rates by this Government, which began as long ago as April of last year and still continues, although the Treasurer assured us last week, or the week before, that there will be no further increase in interest rates. How does he know? How can he give such an assurance if, at the same time, he claims that the Reserve Bank of Australia is independent of the Government, which sometimes he does claim and at other times he denies? We will see tomorrow, when we receive the balance of payments figures for the month of September. Of course, I have no idea what those figures will be, but if they are very bad-the figures for the previous month, August, were disastrous-it is by no means out of the question that we will see higher interest rates, despite what the Treasurer says. In the end, if the foreign creditors who are financing this Government with hot money lose confidence in the Government of this country and its administration, no amount of words from this Treasurer will prevent interest rates from rising higher as those funds flee this country, with effects upon the exchange rate upon which I do not wish to dwell.
The Treasurer himself has spoken about these matters from time to time. In April this year an article in the Sydney Morning Herald reported him as saying:
Because we cannot risk demand continuing to run ahead at an unsustainable rate we have targeted it with the most effective instrument we have, monetary policy.

The fact of the matter is, as month after month has gone by, we have seen that that instrument is not perhaps as effective as the Treasurer thought it was in restraining demand. That is not altogether surprising because the Treasurer has been speaking on this matter with both forks of his tongue. On the one hand, he has been saying that he has been pushing up interest rates in order to restrain demand. On the other hand, he has been telling people not to be too concerned whether interest rates will go any higher or whether there will be any sort of recession or hard landing. On the contrary, we will get a soft landing and almost nobody will get hurt, according to the Treasurer. Not surprisingly in the light of that, if people believe it, they continue to enter into the same financial arrangements which, with the other fork of his tongue, the Treasurer is seeking to dissuade them from entering into. In any case, four months after the Treasurer made that statement, the Reserve Bank of Australia went on record publicly to disagree with him. In its annual report it is stated:

On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.
On page 13 of the annual report the bank goes on to state:
Retention of the present stance of policy should produce more significant restraint of spending as 1989-90 progresses.
It should do that. However the bank says:
Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit-
that is, of the balance of payments-
is uncertain; there are risks that it may not.

The Reserve Bank is effectively saying in those passages of its annual report that the current stance of policy with its punishing high interest rates may not even work. But what if it does work? What if, in effect, it brings down total demand within the economy and through that brings down demand for imports and through that brings the balance of payments back-temporarily at any rate-into some better degree of equilibrium than it is displaying at the moment? I remind the Senate that the Treasurer has forecast a balance of payments deficit on current account this year of $18.5 billion. The figures for the first two months-again, I do not know what tomorrow's figures will bring-if one were to take them as any guide to the year, would indicate that that $18.5 billion figure is a serious underestimate.

Nevertheless, if monetary policy is at some time during 1990 successful in bringing about some type of recession-which is what the Budget between the lines predicts because of the forecasts in the Budget on a year-on-year basis which implicitly mean that the level of activity over the year will have to drop back very sharply, particularly in the second half of the financial year-what will the situation be? We will be left with a recessed economy, an economy in which activity has been ground down and as a consequence of that-and only as a consequence of that-imports have fallen off sufficiently to make the balance of payments look momentarily somewhat more respectable. But we will have none of the fundamentals dealt with. So that, beyond that point on the basis of the policies of this tired and dying Government, there is nowhere to go.

In the event that one begins to start up the economy again, back will come the flood of imports, back will come the balance of payments to an ever deeper sea of red ink. We will be back to square one. That is what is in store for this country by, roughly speaking-I do not want to be held to be too precise on the exact time-the middle of next year on the basis of present policies. I suppose that will be the inheritance which the present coalition parties will receive when they win the Federal election. The present Hawke-Keating Government has made the economy extremely vulnerable to the harsh winds of the international economy. Again, I quote from the annual report of the Reserve Bank when it talked about those risks that this vulnerability creates. The report states:
These risks will be much greater if there is a substantial slowing of world growth and a decline in commodity prices.

So far we have not seen either of those developments. There are some people who think they discern some slight slowing in the rate of world growth but that is a matter for debate. So far commodity prices have shown some weakening but I would not describe that, as yet, as being a decline. Nevertheless those risks exist. They are out there. None of this Government's policies has taken the slightest heed of them. The fact of the matter is that fundamental structural change of this economy is required. Again, the Reserve Bank pointed to that on page 8 of its report when it stated:

Australia needs a major shift of resources into the traded goods sector to stimulate increased exports and, more importantly, to replace imports. This cannot be achieved if domestic demand is growing faster than productive capacity; but simply slowing demand is not enough either. There is also a need for greater productive capacity, improved productivity and a better overall price performance, at least as good as our competitors.

The truth is that the Labor Government simply cannot deliver policies of this type because of its close association with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the trade union bosses. Micro-economic reforms, accordingly, under this Government have totally stalled. We have a fiasco on our waterfront. The policies announced recently in that respect by Minister Willis are simply a retreat from reality. We have had some attempt by the Government to look at the disgraceful situation obtaining in our coastal shipping area. Nothing effective has been done.

I might say in the concluding minutes I have available to me that the Opposition has, by contrast in its Economic Action Plan unveiled almost a fortnight ago, clearly stated that these are the areas which will be addressed by the Opposition. We made it quite plain that we will not accept, as this Government has, handing out $150m of taxpayers' money in order to get 3,000 members of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia to retire with golden handshakes averaging $100,000 each in recompense for a life of idleness on the wharves. We will not be content with doing nothing about the situation of cabotage on our coastal shipping. We have given an undertaking that we will phase that out over five years. Some people have criticised us for intending to take five years to do so. I do not back away from that. The Government is doing nothing about it. We have pointed in this area generally not to micro-economic reforms specifically but to the whole area of industrial relations policy-the area which this Government is incapable of tackling because of its incestuous relationship with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

What better illustration of that could there be than the disastrous situation that this country has been subjected to by the pilots dispute? The Government appears to say that it has not even attempted to make any assessment of the economic cost to this country of that now long drawn out dispute which is bidding fair to become the most serious, disastrous industrial dispute in this country's history. We have seen that this Prime Minister's manic determination to smash a particular union-the Australian Federation of Air Pilots-has produced a situation where it is impossible for the employers to talk with the only people who can put the airlines back into the air: namely, their ex-employees, the pilots.

Since 12 October when we released our economic plan we have had from this Treasurer no responses-or none worth noting. First of all we had a week of silence; then we had a conjured up press conference at which the Treasurer released some scrappy papers purporting to show a hole in the Opposition's costing of $835m. Nobody believes that stuff. I do not want to spend time dignifying it by commenting upon it. The latest element-I will close on this note-in our increasingly desperate Treasurer's attempts to denigrate the Opposition's policy in this area is his suggestion that somehow our decision to abolish the capital gains tax will cost the future governments of this country $25 billion. I can only say that we should be grateful to the Treasurer for telling the Australian taxpayers that he proposes to tax them $25 billion by way of capital gains tax. They will be interested to hear that in the days and months ahead leading up to the election campaign. I do not think that it is a big gesture for the Treasurer to be making that point but, whether it is or it is not, we propose to go ahead and put that particular policy into place as we shall our other policies designed to put Australia back to right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone, you foreshadowed an amendment. Do I take it that you have moved it?
—The foreshadowed amendment has been recorded in Hansard. I now formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``but the Senate notes-

(1) That the Hawke/Keating Government's deal with the four major banks to manipulate the interest rates paid on the new non-callable deposits introduced in this legislation so that home mortgage interest rates would not rise higher than the already record high levels, is:
(a) another desperate deal by a tired and dying Government; and
(b) does nothing to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.

(2) That, to reduce Australia's high level of interest rates, the Government must depart from its one-dimensional, tight monetary policy and adopt an integrated policy framework as set out in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the Senate puts in place a number of matters finalising the Government's deregulated bank policy. The Australian Democrats oppose the deregulated model. It has failed, it has played into the hands of banks and it has given rise to the desperate plight of many ordinary Australians at the hands of the banks of this country in their unfettered greed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will oppose the Bill at the second reading stage but the Bill will pass with the Government and the Opposition acting together in the interests of greedy banks and contrary to the interests of ordinary Australians on this issue. They have done this previously. We will propose a significant second reading amendment, which will be moved by Senator Coulter, and a series of vitally important amendments in the committee stage, which will be moved by Senator Powell.

The Bill provides a timely and most welcome opportunity to address on behalf of Australians the question of the state of Australian banking since deregulation in 1984-85. In principle, it would seem obvious that deregulation was about increasing competition between Australian banks and opening up the banking industry to competition from overseas banks that would come on-shore and take their place in this newly deregulated, more competitive market. Instead of that, we have seen the very opposite. We have seen the arrival of relatively few overseas banks into our newly deregulated market. We have seen the situation where the established banking giants in this country have behaved like a cartel, which is in contravention of the Trade Practices Act. Instead of having a more competitive, open market, ordinary Australians are being ripped off unmercifully and bled white by powerful, profit-hungry banks.

The deregulation of the financial system and the admission of foreign banks was supposed to provide, through competition, a better service to bank customers. While it is possible to argue that corporate customers have benefited from being able to borrow overseas via their Australian banks and customers with large amounts of money to invest now have a bigger variety of investments to choose from, the average customer, the ordinary Australian, and those with relatively small amounts in their savings accounts, are dramatically worse off in a deregulated banking situation.

In the name of efficiency or user pays, banks are charging fees on small accounts, while people with lots of money can still get free services. Mortgage interest rates are crippling many home owners, yet the banks complain that these rates are too low compared with the rates paid by corporate borrowers. The banks are also encouraging the Government to drop the 13.5 per cent ceiling for those who borrowed to buy a home under their control. Somehow this is supposed to benefit the home buyer-so it is argued by the greedy banks in the contemporary Australian banking industry.

In the area of home loan interest rates the Government has at least recognised that deregulation does not work. In 1986 a ceiling was put on interest rates paid by those who had already borrowed. In other words, the Government began to intervene and contravene its philosophy of deregulation-rightly so, we believe. We cite as a contradiction the Government's action this year when it bought off the banks with some $200m of taxpayers' money, from people who are already being bled dry as borrowers from banks but who are also taxpayers who are footing the $200m subsidy to banks, to allow them to keep down their mortgage interest rates and to look better, to further con those whom they are already bleeding dry.

This allowed the Government to put a 17 per cent ceiling on the home loan interest rates charged by the four big banks. This is all very well for those who have borrowed from these banks, but it does nothing for people who have borrowed from building societies, credit unions and State banks. I believe that there are more people in the latter category than in the former. However, at least we have an admission from the Government, in the form of this deal with the banks, that financial deregulation is not benefiting the hundreds of thousands of Australians who recently bought a home or cannot afford to buy one.

Surprisingly, given that people have been deregulated out of home ownership, neither the Liberal and National parties nor the Australian Labor Party have been prepared to modify their deregulatory obsessions. Neither the Government's last Budget nor the Peacock alternative addresses this problem. The parties have entered into a competition to produce even bigger Budget surpluses but have produced no policies to help people buy a home. We are told that bigger surpluses are good for the economy, but there is little evidence to support this. Certainly, the Tweedledum and Tweedledee economics of Liberal versus Labor is of benefit primarily to the banks; there is no disputing that reality.

People complain about the bad services provided by these deregulated banks. With plenty of new services-ATMs, EFTs and credit at the drop of a hat-we are being induced to accept what they call credit. Credit is actually debt. We are being conned into a mounting debt, which we then have to service month after month, year after year, decade after decade, which drains the economy and drains the community of the very resources that would otherwise have been used to stimulate growth and remain competitive in the world markets. And we wonder why we are not competitive and why we have our international balance of payments problems!

We are conned into quick fix credit solutions to our monetary problems. What has happened to the concept of saving and the positive aspect of banking? Why over the past two or three decades have we been conned into believing that banks are all about credit-namely, all about debt-and no longer about the positive aspects of banking, the creation of real wealth, namely, saving? What happens when customers complain that they have been billed for something they did not get, that the automatic teller machine has made a mistake, that they do not understand why they have incurred a particular bank charge, or that they have been misled about the rate of interest their savings will earn? People in that position are up against a monolith that has massive legal resources on top and staff who do not understand what services the banks are providing or charging for today. People are confused, bewildered and disillusioned about banking as it exists in the deregulated situation.

Banks are about profit in the deregulated situation, and they are doing it extremely well. They are the great profit makers, in an economic climate which, we are constantly told by governments and oppositions, requires restraint; in an economic climate in which any small business person in Australia will tell us it is virtually impossible to survive. But the banks survive. Under the new ethos of profitability, let us look at how well the banks survive. They describe their profits as super profits; that is their term. It was used by Mr Argus, the manager of finance at the National Australia Bank, in a confidential memo that I tabled in this Senate in April. He used the expression `super profits'. He emphasised the importance of disguising from the public the magnitude of these super profits. But the banks cannot disguise the magnitude of them. They have to declare their profits. For instance, Westpac Banking Corporation had to declare its profit of $594m in 1988. The National Australia Bank Ltd had a profit of $531m and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd a profit of $535m.

In 1988 the Commonwealth Bank had a profit of $365m. This bank-the people's bank-has just announced a 74 per cent increase on that profit of 1988. It obscenely announced that increase in profit in the same week as it accepted its portion of the $200m taxpayers' handouts which it has used to subsidise its mortgage interest rates at a level that made it appear constrained and reasonable. It announced that 74 per cent increase in profit in the same month as it reappointed its Managing Director on a 100 per cent increase in salary-a salary of $250,000 a year. Yet we are whistling through our teeth about pressure from pilots for a 30 per cent increase in salary. Parliamentarians are asked by the same Prime Minister who prevails over this farce to forgo for the sixth time in three years increases in salaries. Mr Don Sanders could give himself a 100 per cent increase in salary from this 74 per cent increase in profits of the people's bank and be paid $250,000 a year.

This is happening at exactly the same time as these banks are arguing that they cannot function on margins between borrowing and lending of 3 to 7 per cent. Yet it has been found that those profit margins are twice those which sufficiently satisfy the needs of international banks overseas. The three major international Swiss banks operate on profit margins which are half of what these greedy, money profit grabbing banks demand in Australia in the so-called competitive deregulated situation into which this Government has put us and which this Opposition would be quite happy to maintain. The banks are running riot in this deregulated Australian bank industry that we have today.

Banks have a three-way privilege. It has been known for a long time, of course, that banks have the greatest power on earth-the power to create money. The first privilege that banks have is the power to create what they call credit. But this is actually a debit entry in the borrower's book in the bank. It is a debt. By the process of creating credit-money-banks entice us into debt. Then they bleed us by servicing those debts. If we happen to have a mortgage, we are bled at the rate of 17 to 18 per cent. If we happen to have an overdraft-and we know the rate at which we are bled in this respect-the rate is somewhere between 21 per cent and as high as 30 per cent. The confidential Argus memo which I tabled in this chamber in April revealed that to be the case. In fact, it revealed that the National Australia Bank did not even know the rate at which we were being bled in terms of overdrafts. It was embarrassed by what it found. But we are being bled white by this second privilege that banks have.

But then comes the crunch. If one cannot service this debt-and hundreds of thousands of Australians cannot now service their interest-if one cannot give any more blood, the bank can move in and foreclose. It can take one's home, farm or business. Having created the debt in the first place, the bank can bleed its customers by servicing that debt and finally it can deliver the ultimate insult by taking the asset away if the debt cannot be serviced. That is power; that is banking. That is the power that gives rise to the obscene profits with which average Australians are confronted in this country today.

I have not even talked about the fact that we do not know what we are being charged by the banks. Let me cite the example of the businessman in Tasmania who operates three bank accounts and has challenged his last 35 miscellaneous bank charges. All of these charges have been withdrawn. Let me cite the case of a large corporate bank account holder which queried an entry of $28,000 for miscellaneous bank charges against its enormous account. The bank said that it had made a mistake-forget it. Let me cite the case of a woman in Tasmania who thought she had made arrangements by phone for an account to be transferred from a Melbourne account to a Hobart account. She actually wrote eight cheques against that account, none of which were more than $40. All of the cheques were bounced by her bank and she was charged $25 on each of them. She was not allowed to enter into a dispute. She had no right of reply. Let me cite the case of a pensioner in Tasmania who was charged $15 because he failed to sign a cheque. He forgot to do so. The cost to the bank was a phone call or a stamp; the cost to the pensioner was $15. Such examples are endless. Bank charges are another way of bleeding us.

Let me cite the case of a woman in Nowra who queried a miscellaneous charge of $174 on a bank account. She was told that it was the premium for the insurance on her mortgaged home. She drew the bank's attention to the fact that she had sold the home three years previously. After further observation she drew the bank's attention to the fact that it had been charging her quarterly for the last three years. She had not noticed what was happening until, all of a sudden, the bank had started to charge annually. People do not know the number of bank charges that are being imposed on them. One Australian persisted for two years to try to find out what bank charges were being levied. Do honourable senators know what happened after two years? He received a letter from his bank, which I have tabled in the Senate, which said that if he kept asking it about the bank charges his letters and queries would be sent to its lawyer. He was told that the legal fee would be put on his bank account and that he would have no right of reply. So it goes on and on.

What does all this indicate? It indicates that we have a banking system that could not care less as long as it is maximising its profits; that we have a Government that has created an environment in which banks flourish; and that we have an Opposition which will vote with the Government to sustain that environment. The message to the average Australian is that we have to blow up a huge storm about banking in Australia today. Some members of the Government actually tried to blow up a storm over the last three or four weeks. In April I proposed a Senate inquiry which was defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government. I was told, `We don't need a Senate inquiry into banking in this country'. Honourable senators should ask people in the street whether we need such an inquiry. Some prominent Labor backbenchers-indeed, a chairman of a House of Representatives committee-recommended to their Caucus and Treasurer (Mr Keating) that there should be an inquiry. The Treasurer's reaction was, `Sure we will think about it. It sounds like a good idea-as long as it is not bank bashing, as long as it does not harm the banks'. In the last two or three days he has backed off that inquiry. Do honourable senators know why? The reason is that he does not want the question of a bank inquiry being discussed in Caucus. If he took the matter in there, his backbenchers would have to scream for an inquiry because they know what the reality is in the community. The main reason he does not want an inquiry is that it would reveal the inadequacies of this extraordinary system that he has created. He was actually the architect of this deregulated banking system, the one that is being propped up by the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill, which is before the Senate at the moment. The outcome of a bank inquiry would be a castigating analysis of deregulated banking.

I have not even mentioned the serious allegations of malpractice and corruption, examples of which I have been tabling in this Senate for nearly a year now. That is another dimension yet again. That is the seamy side, should it be investigated and proved, of what is otherwise a squeaky clean image of banking in this country: if a person gets into a four-wheel drive vehicle and confidently drives off into a desert, provided he has his Bankcard with him, all is well. That sort of garbage image is financed in the advertisements which we fund through the super profits of banks.

This Bill provides an opportunity for us to focus upon the extraordinarily negative implications of deregulated banking. There are those within Labor ranks who have quite serious reservations about deregulated banking. I imagine that we would accept that Mr Halfpenny is on the Left of Labor. Recently in an article in the Australian Financial Review entitled `Banking in the `90s' Mr Halfpenny stated:
The reality is that financial institutions and the people who also control them are not capable of socially responsible management in a deregulated environment.

In other words, he is saying that they are socially irresponsible-and I would agree with him. John Cain, who is not on the Left but on the Right, proposes that the banks should discriminate actively against customers who seek loans to buy imported goods, especially imported cars and consumer goods, and that discrimination should be in the form of higher interest rates for the purchasers of imports than for buyers of local products. He states:
I would like to see rates that reflect what this society's philosophy ought to be about-the relative importance of purchases that are made across the society . . .

What I am saying is that there is money abundant to buy those sorts of goods such as imported cars and electrical goods and computers . . . I believe there ought to be a different rate applicable . . .

He is trying to suggest that deregulation has induced irresponsibility and that there needs to be intervention in such a manner that it will give rise to responsibility within deregulated banking. I do not believe that that is possible. I agree with Halfpenny that deregulated banking is, by nature, finally and inherently socially irresponsible. They are contradictions in terms.

One of the most important things this debate provides is the opportunity to cite the impotence and the ineffectiveness of the Reserve Bank of Australia. Somehow or other we have an image that, if we deliver the banking system into the hands of the Reserve Bank of Australia and its Board of very heavy, very sophisticated, very experienced and very responsible people, all will be well. After all, they are charged with quite specific responsibilities on our behalf. What are the duties of the Board of the Reserve Bank of Australia? It has three duties. Clause 10 (2) of the Reserve Bank Act states:
It is the duty of the Board, within the limits of its powers-
oh boy, is that an escape clause!-

to ensure that the monetary and banking policy of the Bank is directed to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia and that the powers of the Bank under this Act, the Banking Act 1959 and the regulations under that Act are exercised in such a manner as, in the opinion of the Board, will best contribute to-
referring to those who control the banking system, the board of management of the Reserve Bank that controls the banking system-
(a) the stability of the currency of Australia;
(b) the maintenance of full employment in Australia; and
(c) the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia.

That is all motherhood stuff, but I do not believe that there is one skerrick of doubt that the banking system today is not fulfilling those three duties of its controlling body. The board of management of the Reserve Bank of Australia is failing us. It is allowing to prevail a system which simply services the needs of the greediest banks in the world. We know that they are the greediest banks in the world because we are able to measure how much more greedy they are than, say, the three top international Swiss banks. We can actually measure the margins by which they operate against those of other world banks-and they are the greediest banks in the world. Do honourable senators know what the Australian Bankers Association responded yesterday when this sort of criticism was offered? The best it could say was that banks were not making such good profits in a deregulated market as they were in the regulated market. The banks are really saying, `If you think you are being ripped off now'-and I have cited the figures to elaborate the extent to which we are being ripped off-`this is nothing in comparison with the way we were ripping you off'. This is the ethos of banking in Australia in 1989.

When I move a motion in this chamber on Friday to investigate the matter it will, for the second time, be defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition with the Government. It will happen because we have not yet blown up a big enough storm about banking. But, by jove, the storm has built up dramatically since April, when I first proposed that the whole question of banking be referred to a Senate standing committee. We will continue to whip up the storm at public meeting after public meeting because there is a determination on the part of the Australian Democrats that banking be an election issue. There are all sorts of distractions being put in our way, such as the creation of an Australian bank council and the appointment by the banks of an ombudsman to investigate the banks, paid by the banks, and responsible to the banks. I do not suppose that is a bad thing if one believes and has confidence in self-regulation. As Senator Stone enunciated here a moment ago, if one has confidence in that model that is all right. We do not have confidence in that model. We say that that is the model that has allowed the rape by a banking industry of ordinary Australians attending to their everyday needs.

The Australian Democrats are opposed to this Bill because it represents a continuation of a model which is not serving the best interests of Australia or of Australians. We will be proposing observations about it as second reading amendments and we will be proposing constructive changes in the form of committee stage amendments. Banks are running riot in this country, and the riot squad has to be called out to bring them under control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 seeks to make some quite significant revisions to the Banking Act, some ancillary changes to other Acts and some amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act and the Reserve Bank Act. As a result, it strikes at the very heart of one of the major issues in front of the Australian people at the moment-that is, the massive interest rate policies deliberately being pursued by the Federal Government. Basically, the Reserve Bank of Australia is in charge of monetary policy. As a result of the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Reserve Bank is now seen to be more and more under his direct personal control. The appointment of the head of the Treasury to be the Governor of the Reserve Bank rather than someone who has a background in the Reserve Bank itself has been seen by the business community as evidence of bureaucratising the bank and its functions, no matter how outstanding and effective a public servant the Secretary to the Treasury has been.

SPEECH.PARA: The task of the Reserve Bank is to provide an independent economic analysis and independent advice to the Government-advice coming not from the bureaucratic centre of Australia, Canberra, but from an organisation which exists in the business heart of this nation, Sydney, with some input from Melbourne. The fact that the Government has chosen to appoint someone who is much closer to the bureaucratic structure of Canberra to be Governor of the Reserve Bank, the fact that the Treasurer has chosen to state-as he did earlier this year-that the bank does what he tells it, and the fact that the latest annual report of the Reserve Bank indicates a refreshing independence of spirit, by inference clearly attacking the Government's lack of action in the key areas of economic need, demonstrate that there is now to be a change in the manner in which the Reserve Bank conducts itself. I believe that that change will be a change for the worse.

When we are discussing this legislation it is important for us to look at what is happening to monetary policy in this nation at the moment. It is particularly appropriate that we should be discussing that at a time when, in many instances, some of the high-fliers in Australian business-the people who have borrowed heavily, particularly from overseas; the people who, in some cases, appear to have been encouraged by this Government, some of whom certainly appear to be close mates of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), if being jointly showered in champagne is an indication of mateship-have been seen to be in major difficulties. Ironically enough, those difficulties are now being worsened by the Government's continuing to rely so heavily on high interest rates. There is no doubt that there are problems facing many Australian companies-not simply those that have become so heavily indebted but also the many corporations that are now facing enormous interest bills-just as home buyers are facing enormous interest bills under this Government's policy. Many employees are dependent on the survival of those businesses. I fear that a continuation of this Government's policies, of massive over-reliance on monetary policy and huge interest rates, will bring about a substantial increase in unemployment in the new year. In fact, there is a real risk of recession.

Earlier today the shadow Treasurer, Dr John Hewson, said in the other place that what is happening in Australia at the moment underlines the fact that we desperately need strong leadership. In particular-and I stress this-we need a Treasurer like Dr Hewson who knows what he is doing, who can identify what needs to be done and who can act quickly and decisively to put things right. That is certainly in contrast with the extraordinary behaviour of the Treasurer in recent times. A week after the Opposition's economic policy statement he has been floundering around trying to find some way in which to attack it while refusing to come up with any method his Government can find to resolve these crises, which continue to get worse and have certainly worsened since the Budget came down in August-a Budget which was supposed to help resolve these problems but which, as the Reserve Bank pointed out, did not address any one of the major issues of economic policy facing Australia.

I believe that the annual report of the Reserve Bank is required reading for anyone who wants to find out what this Government is failing to do and what it ought to be doing. I remind the Senate that the Reserve Bank in its annual report used such phrases as:
. . . it is imperative that there be a return to progress on reducing both the rate of inflation and the current account deficit . . .

Of course, this Government's Budget will not achieve that. The Reserve Bank continues to use strong decisive words in its report. When talking about micro-economic reform it says, `Changes there are essential'. It then goes on to say that we are unlikely to get that kind of reform if we have high interest rates. In fact, it says:
Restructuring is much more difficult, even impossible, in a high inflation environment . . . Altering this situation must have top priority.

The Government has totally ignored all these imperative words. The Treasurer, having established his lack of credentials in this area, having failed abysmally in this regard, has been saying that under a Peacock government interest rates would be higher. That is absolute nonsense. As I have said, the Treasurer's credibility in this area has been destroyed, and destroyed by the Reserve Bank itself. This kind of nonsensical attack has been shown to be total hypocrisy. He is the man who is responsible for the present record mortgage rates and the huge commercial lending rates which are hitting the level of business investment and, therefore, our prospects of ever getting out of the disastrous balance of payments problems that we are now in. It is incredible that the man who is responsible for record interest rates is the same man who went round trying to blame everyone else, particularly the banks. Of course, as we heard from Senator McLean, the banks are the fall guys for anyone who has an axe to grind, but Mr Keating said that the banks were to blame for high interest rates. This is absolute bunkum, as we can see when we look at what is actually happening to interest rates.

Strangely enough, I must say that, even though these interest rates are huge, at the moment there is still no evidence of demand slowing. Of course, it is that excessive demand in relation to our inadequate volume of export earnings that is causing the balance of payments crisis that will dominate Australia's economic situation and politics at least until the mid-1990s. It is not just me, but other respected people who are saying that. Even the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Government's own body, has pointed to the length of time for which this massive balance of payments problem will remain.

We have seen retail sales continue at a fairly healthy rate. Credit aggregates are still very high and imports and employment are showing no sign of slowing. The Treasurer has tried to pretend that the surge in imports and the high balance of payments deficit are due to increased purchasing in investment goods. That is nonsense. The Business Council of Australia recently pointed out that capital goods imports rose by $2 billion in 1988-89. But this was at a time when the current account deficit deteriorated by $5.5 billion-almost three times as much. So, even if capital goods had remained unchanged, the current account deficit would have deteriorated substantially due to increased consumption and intermediate goods imports. That is what the Business Council said.

If one looks at the capital goods imports category, one sees that very little is going into the traded goods category. There has been a large surge in imports of computer equipment, motor vehicles and odd items such as video cassette recorders, record players and medical equipment. But it is very hard to pin down equipment going into the import replacement or export industries. That is where we need investment. That is where we would be prepared to wear a fairly high level of imports if it would lead to some correction, ultimately, of the inadequate level of exports and the excessive level of imports presently plaguing Australia and presenting us with the problem that the Government probably has little alternative, in view of its other policy failures, to maintaining a disastrously and destructively high level of interest rates.

Things are clearly getting worse on the monetary policy front. That seems clear from the hint that the Treasurer gave last week, I think, on 2GB on the John Laws program when he said that he could not guarantee that interest rates would not rise. The world's greatest Treasurer, who supposedly has all the answers, has led Australia into a massive interest rate regime and is now saying that he cannot guarantee that interest rates will not rise even further. I understand why he cannot guarantee that; it is because his policies have failed. It is clear that we are heading for an even worse economic situation in Australia. Last week the treasury note rediscount rate was lifted to 17.7 per cent and the Reserve Bank of Australia acted to tighten up the cash market last Friday. Yesterday treasury notes traded at 17.8 per cent. That is well above the last tender. The market is pretty widely of the view that the $1 billion note tender will go off at close to 18 per cent, which could mean another lift in the rediscount rate. Is that not incredible? The Government talks about 18 per cent for its own paper yet criticises the banks for daring to raise interest rates to 17 per cent-one per cent less than the Government pays for its money. The level of hypocrisy involved in the Treasurer making that sort of attack on the banks in this situation is self-evident.

The Treasurer has sought to soften the impact of his policies by doing a deal with the banks to hold down some mortgage rates to 17 per cent for some lucky borrowers. Just as the Government apparently believes that some uranium is acceptable and can be mined but some is not and cannot be mined, so some home borrowers have to be protected--

Some are to be thrown to the wolves. We saw that happen with the pegged 13 1/2 per cent mortgage rate. We now see it with those people who have borrowed from building societies. They are to receive no benefit from the deal that has been done-at public expense-with the banks. I remind the Senate that the public expense involved in doing a deal on interest rates-something which at the right time in the right way I would totally favour-that is, getting rid of the discriminatory rate at which the Government required the banks to have deposits with the central bank, will be $200m a year. But I remind honourable senators that the change already in the legislation we are looking at today, requiring that instead of having a statutory reserve deposit one would have a non-callable deposit, will involve a cost to revenue of about $20m in the current financial year and $200m annually.

SPEECH.PARA: Public money is being required to try to soften the blow of the Government's high interest rate policy which has emerged because of its inadequate and incompetent running of fiscal policy. What the Government is doing in a sense is basically easing fiscal policy and at the same time making the monetary impact and the need for higher interest rates in other areas even greater. The massive high commercial interest rates from the Government of 18 per cent in the marketplace are threatening the existence of many Australian businesses, particularly small businesses, at a time when the Government is hitting their cash flows by this extraordinary requirement that 85 per cent of a company's corporate tax be paid by 15 July, in other words, two weeks into the new financial year.

What does the Government do for businesses? It brings forward the date on which they have to pay their tax. In the majority of instances it is long before the company has earned its full profits for that year, before it has actually got the money. Most businesses operate on at least 30 days payment. In the Senate Estimates Committee the other day we heard that an enormous proportion of the creditors of the Australian Government Publishing Service have to wait longer than 30 days before they get paid by the Government. So, the Government does not pay on time, yet it requires companies, which have not received the cash on which they have allegedly earned profits, to pay their tax before they have even got the money.

This Government is bringing about major problems for the business community and, I believe, a significant risk of a recession in the new year. That is one of the reasons that there has been so much speculation about the possibility of an election this year. I have some more concerns about this Government's economic policies. TALK.START.PARA: —This table shows what has happened to the broad money supply since June 1988. In just 14 months it has gone up from 12 per cent to 19.4 per cent, for the 12 months to August. There are all sorts of reasons and justifications for this. The Government used continually to fail to meet its target, when it set a target, for greater money supply. It said, `This is because deregulation has so altered the game that in fact the components of money supply now are involved in some double counting because of flows in and out of Australia'. When Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, was last attacking Senator Short in this place because he dared to mention this blow-out in money supply Senator Walsh said that it was now irrelevant and did not count. We have yet to see or hear Senator Walsh or any other Government Minister quantify just how wrong-if they are wrong-these money aggregates are. Are they 50 per cent wrong? If the Government does not know it should. How wrong are they if we can no longer, as Senator Walsh says, take any notice of them whatsoever?

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank is staffed with people of great competence. I refuse to believe that there is available no indication as to how we should interpret broad money supply figures that are now available. It is not good enough for this Government to duck behind the excuse that they are no longer relevant because they include some figures that do not suit the Government. The fact is that we are seeing a massive blow-out in broad money. That is bringing exactly the sorts of consequences that are almost classic in every economy where the money supply blows out because of incompetent governmental management of the economy. This is one essential point that seems to have been totally ignored in the economic debate in recent times: this huge blow-out from 12 per cent in the year to June 1988 to 19.4 per cent now.

It is fascinating to look at what has happened not just coincidentally but as a natural consequence. In June 1988, when the broad money growth was 12 per cent, savings bank interest rates were 13.5 per cent. When broad money had grown to about 15.9 per cent by December savings bank interest rates had gone up from 13.5 per cent to 15 per cent. I can go further down the list. By March 1989 broad money had risen from 12 per cent to 18.3 per cent. Savings bank interest rates had gone up a further 1 per cent to 16 per cent. In August 1989 broad money increased to 19.4 per cent, and savings bank interest rates went up to 17 per cent and would have been higher but for the deal done by the Government, at public taxpayers' expense basically, in order to hold home loan interest rates down. We have had this parallel: the money supply has got bigger and bigger, interest rates have got bigger and bigger and this Government is doing nothing-apart from doing a one-stop deal with the banks which involves no guarantees and cannot be held together-to stop that inevitable course which will lead to a recession.

What has happened to inflation while this has been going on? Here again we have a classic link. In June 1988, when we had broad money at 12 per cent and savings bank interest rates at 13.5 per cent, the gross domestic product (GDP) deflator was showing inflation at 8.1 per cent. Naturally, inflation has risen since that time. By June this year it was 9.6 per cent-far higher than the Treasurer had forecast, far higher than the Budget had indicated, far higher than this Government thought and certainly far higher than the health of this country can sustain. This nation cannot live with an inflation rate so much higher than its trading partners. As has been pointed out by the Reserve Bank, the prospect of any kind of effective restructuring of our economy to cope with the problems we face internationally, and particularly with our disastrous balance of payments figure, is made far worse. We cannot effectively restructure, according to the Reserve Bank, while we have these massive inflation rates. What has brought this about is this Government's reckless approach to economic growth.

Once again we can look at almost classic figures. In September 1988, when broad money was around 11.2 per cent and savings bank interest rates were 14.5 per cent and inflation was 8.9 per cent, we had a GDP growth of about 2.7 per cent. It is now up to 3.9 per cent, far higher than the economic indicators can sustain. The reason for that is that the Government has placed far more emphasis on creating jobs at any price. I am all in favour of creating jobs. The question is: Do we create jobs at any price? The price of this Government's economic policies-we keep hearing that it has created so many jobs-has been a huge rise in the money supply, massive increases in interest rates, a huge rise in inflation and, above all, sitting like an albatross around the neck of this economy, a huge international debt which is still going up and which this Government has done nothing to stop.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ninety billion dollars it has increased by.

The Government has no policy to face this problem. It has done and is doing absolutely nothing. The shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, has suggested that the Government might try to say what it is going to do. After all, it has been critical of the Opposition's policy. SPEECH.PARA: By reducing inflation and shifting the weight off monetary policy, we will be able to bring about a sustainable reduction in interest rates, including home mortgage rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said during the debate, particularly by my colleague Senator McLean, the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 comes before us at a time when the banking sector is recording record profits due at least in part to the increases in interest rates and banking charges in recent years. In this environment, bank consumers, the ordinary people in the street, have come to view those profits with less than favourable eyes.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator McLean has outlined the situation with bank profits. Only the Commonwealth Bank of Australia has so far released its annual report up to June 1989, showing that its profit increase is 74 per cent. The figures up to the end of March 1989 show that the profits of the National Australia Bank Ltd and Westpac Banking Corporation increased by 52 per cent and those of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd by 60 per cent.

The basic problem is the Hawke Government's deregulation approach to the financial system in general and banks in particular. This Bill takes that process a step further and, as Senator McLean said, is opposed by the Australian Democrats on the basis of that deregulation which has been damaging to the community and to the economy, in the same way that the Australian Democrats so often have opposed other deregulation and privatisation measures introduced by this Government, encouraged from the sidelines by the Opposition.

The Hawke Labor Government promised results from deregulation. It promised the magic of the marketplace, and the same promise has been made by the alternative Peacock coalition government. It is a case of Tweedledum and Tweedledee or, as David Potts said in the Australian last week at the end of his analysis of the Peacock package-and I did not think I would be quoting David Potts-`Well done, Tweedle brothers'.

We were promised the magic of the marketplace-more competition; better service; a better deal for the people in the street, for the users of banking services, basically for all Australians. And what did we get? We got higher charges and higher interest rates. As for increased competition, we got amalgamations of banks resulting in gigantic institutions with which the little people have to deal and which offer a lesser level of service-do it yourself banking; a proliferation of plastic; promotion of credit which, in effect, as Senator McLean said, is debt; an increase in bankruptcies; particularly promotion of credit debt to our young people; and easier access to overseas money, aided and abetted of course by the continuing policy of allowing negative gearing for foreign borrowings and a policy not opposed by the potential alternative government. That increased access to and increased use of overseas money by the rich and the entrepreneurs has had its damaging, disrupting impact on our community in the form of pressure on the balance of payments, which has found its way down to pressure on the individual families trying to put a roof over their head.

The consumer movement in Australia is among the most strident critics of banking deregulation. As I said, the Opposition is green with envy over what this Government has done. As Treasurer, John Howard wanted to do it but he could not push the coalition far enough down that track. The Opposition is consistent in knocking the consumer movement when it complains, as it knocks the Australian Democrats when we complain.

Consumer unrest has grown. We have shared the concerns and we have voiced those concerns in this place and in the community. As social security spokesperson for the Australian Democrats, I have had cause to be concerned about a constituency that has been damaged by the approach taken: a constituency of low income people, pensioners and beneficiaries, including the unemployed.

There was outrage in the community when the people's bank, the Commonwealth Bank, was placing charges on unemployment beneficiaries in particular. The result of that pressure was that, finally, the Commonwealth Bank exempted them along with other pensioners and beneficiaries. But it took community pressure to get that change. It is the low income people who have had to suffer considerably from the bank charges.

A report partly funded by the Victorian Government and issued last week headed, `Bank deregulation. Is the consumer clearly winning?' pointed that out. It outlined that the charges on many bank accounts were higher than the interest earned, which meant that consumers were finding less in their accounts as a result of those charges.

An article in the Age of 17 October outlines that 37 deposit accounts in nine banks were surveyed in the report. In 19 cases, people who made 25 withdrawals a quarter from an account with an average balance of $1,000 and a minimum balance of $200 would have to pay the bank; 13 accounts paid between 0 and 2 per cent under the same conditions; and only one account paid more than 10 per cent interest. For some people, the gain was less than zero.

The banks defended themselves by saying that many of the accounts were service accounts, not savings accounts. I do not know how the banks could determine that that was the case. They might have assumed it, but they offered no evidence at all that that was the case. They argue that this is all very reasonable and, in a nice, deregulated user pays system, nobody should be worried about it. Consumers are worried about this sort of situation. It is the people with the small accounts, the low income people, who are concerned.

Again, as social security spokesperson for the Australian Democrats, I point to our concern for the way in which the Government and the banks, in their cosy relationship, have operated in relation to pension payments. Two or three years ago, the Government determined that pension payments should be made directly to banks. Following that, the banks took it upon themselves to directly confiscate parts of those payments wherever they could claim that the customer owed money from another account or had overdrawn an account.

We have all been very concerned about this, some of us believing that, under the Social Security Act, those social security payments are absolutely inalienable. We have been concerned that the banks should confiscate this money without having to prove the debt in the first place. Along with other community bodies, we have called upon the Government to redress this situation in relation to which the Department of Social Security actually sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department. In yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, it was revealed in an article by Margo Kingston that, in fact, the Government has been told by the Attorney-General that it is acting illegally in forcing pensioners and other welfare beneficiaries to have their cheques paid directly into bank accounts.

That opinion states that payment by the Commonwealth into a bank account is unauthorised unless made in response to a voluntary request by the client. That is far from what has been operating for these few years. The Attorney-General's opinion was that the Social Security Act does not permit the Department to make direct deposits except voluntarily.
