TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was referring to one of the several disturbing aspects-disturbing, at least, to the Australian Democrats and to others in the community-of the Government's obvious and lucrative cosy relationship with the banks, that is, the fact that the Department of Social Security has been making direct deposits of social security payments into banks. The Attorney-General's Department has now offered an opinion that that has been an illegal action, this at a time when it has been proposed that an agreement be forged between the Department and the banks which would set a limited proportion which the banks could take from welfare recipients by way of confiscation.

SPEECH.PARA: The opinion raises, as Margo Kingston said in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, the prospect that clients whose benefits have been confiscated in the past may be able to sue the Department for illegally depositing their money. It must be the case, given that we have legislation coming to us which is currently in the House of Representatives-social security amendment legislation-which attempts to legitimise that currently illegal system. I would imagine that the Government is somewhat scratching its head at this point. Certainly that legislation will be opposed by the Democrats. We have always said that pensioners and beneficiaries ought to have choice in that situation and that the Government should not be forcing people to have their payments made directly to banks, particularly not when banks are going ahead and confiscating what, according to the Act, are inalienable payments.

As I have said throughout, the consumer's voice against the activities of the banks in this highly deregulated environment has been strong. To overcome some of the consumer unrest, the Australian Bankers Association announced its intention to establish a banking ombudsman scheme, which we certainly hope will result in some level of internal regulation of banking activities. It was launched yesterday by Senator Bolkus and received some media publicity today. It is a scheme which the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations has welcomed, recognising it as arising from the general level of dissatisfaction in the community with the financial sector's complaints handling mechanisms and the difficulties faced by the ordinary consumer in resolving such problems.

There is to be a board comprising members of the banking organisations which will then appoint a council which brings in representatives both from banking and from public interest and consumer groups. That council will appoint an ombudsman. We expect that appointment by the end of the year, according to Senator Bolkus yesterday. The scheme is based on one developed in the United Kingdom. My colleague Senator McLean has expressed our strong reservations about it. We have no option, of course, not having the numbers in this place, on re-regulation. A recent report by the Chancellor of the Exchequer in the British Parliament, known as the Jack report, contained quite serious criticisms of the British banking ombudsman scheme. We-and, I am sure, the consumer organisations in this country-will be working to ensure that those problems do not arise in the system here in Australia.

As part of this legislation we have decided to begin that work. As a result I will be moving in the committee stage to establish a bank consumers' assistance fund. We want to make sure that within this banking ombudsman scheme the consumer's voice is strong and that it is able to be independent and autonomous. So I shall move amendments which will establish a fund by virtue of a levy on banks so that consumer groups can indeed be independent in this exercise. We are listing several organisations-well established and well regarded community organisations-which would be eligible to receive funds from that fund: The Australian Financial Counsellors, the Credit Reform Association, the Australian Consumers Association, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, the National Council of Women of Australia, the Australian Pensioners Federation, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia and the Australian Council of Social Service. We also have provision for other bodies to be prescribed under this legislation.

We believe that this will help the banking ombudsman scheme to be seen to be above reproach. I do not believe that the banks, the Government or the Opposition should oppose the credentials of these organisations, although I am sure that the Opposition will. I believe that, if we are to have a credible, self-regulatory system established, then the voice of the community must be very strong. I say that I am sure that the Opposition will call into question the credentials of at least some of those organisations listed because in previous debates in this place it has done just that, most notably, Senator Short, in a debate on 5 May of this year. He made some considerable criticisms of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations and the Australian Consumers Association. The major part of his complaints seemed to be that too much government funding was going to those organisations. I commend these amendments to the Opposition, particularly on the basis of Senator Short's remarks, because, clearly, what we are doing is attempting to get some money to these consumer organisations that is not government money.

By the establishment of the banking ombudsman scheme we are putting an extra burden on organisations in this community whose burdens are increasing daily as deregulation runs rampant and which will be critical to the interests of ordinary people in the community should we have a change of government and should deregulation become privatisation. The Opposition should welcome an opportunity to provide some funds other than out of the public purse unless, of course, it is more concerned to keep on side with the banks in much the same way as the Government has done in recent times, with a $400m windfall in 1985 to keep interest rates for current home loans at 13 per cent and then the recent $200m windfall in an attempt-it is yet to be seen whether it is effective-to keep interest rates at 17 per cent. So we commend these amendments to the Opposition.

The levy that we will be proposing will be made up of 2 per cent of the banking sector's expenditure on advertising for the preceding financial year. That is the formula. It will mean that consumers will have, at least in the next year, some $800,000 with which to support banking consumers in possible disputes and in the general consumer area, as well as undertaking any necessary research projects which would support their work and thereby support the ordinary people of this country. It will allow the banks the opportunity to prove to their customers what they have been claiming, at least in their advertising campaigns.

Perhaps we ought to have a look at the response to the banks' advertising campaigns recently. On 11 October the Australian ran a story about some findings on advertising generally of a group of analysts at Advertising Diagnostics Pty Ltd who said that they found that consumers found bank advertising unconvincing. The researchers found that advertisements portraying banks as the caring victims of government monetary policies were seen as non-genuine, exaggerating, unconvincing, often confusing, generally uninteresting and lacking a call to action. All banks, except Advance and Westpac, registered weak to negative reactions from prospective customers. What we are saying is that 2 per cent of the money spent on all that ineffective hype that is going out to the wider community would be better spent in supporting the interests of consumers.

The successful passage of these amendments would therefore ensure that the genuine needs and interests of the banking sector's long-forgotten customers, who are feeling neglected and abused, would be met. As Senator McLean said in his contribution, the banks operate with a `monolith of legal advisers' at the top, a fairly daunting prospect for an ordinary consumer at the bottom to take on, even under the bankers' ombudsman scheme. The strain and expense of carrying the millions of consumers in this country ought to be supported financially, we think, by a levy on the banks. I carry the primary industry portfolio for the Australian Democrats and am accustomed to the passage of multitudes of levy Bills at the end of every session, and I do not think we should restrict levies to the primary industry sector by any means at all.

I would like to comment on the up-and-down fortunes of an inquiry into the banking industry. As Senator McLean has said, the Democrats will persist with our longstanding call for such an inquiry, and we insist that banking is an election issue. I believe that the Government already acknowledges this. I believe that Mr Steve Martin's hype on this issue during the two weeks away from this place was really an exercise in insurance on the part of a government that was still contemplating an election towards the end of this year and wanted to be seen to be doing something about a significant community issue. Therefore, the chairman of the appropriate House of Representatives committee obliged-and I have some concerns about the use of a Senate committee if that is the reason why this all happened. But the inquiry was ditched a couple of days ago because, I would say, the Government has also ditched its idea of having an election towards the end of this year. It has been dropped with a lot of excuses that much is being done. Mr Martin was quoted in the Melbourne Age of last Saturday as saying:
The creation of a banking ombudsman, Federal Government progress in sponsoring uniform credit laws by state governments, improvements being fostered in customer relations. . .

He is saying that because all that is happening, an inquiry is not needed, yet none of that has happened since Mr Martin first made his proposal. Mr Keating must have told him, `Don't worry, we don't have to smooth things over in the area of banking because we are not having an election this year'. Mr Martin said that his inquiry was intended to focus on consumer issues. He is quoted in the same article as saying:
Credit card charges, customer relations, electronic funds transfers and the like and their contribution to bank profits were the matters most raised by constituents. . .

Yes, they are, as we have said time and again in this place. Even if the Government does not support an inquiry-and Senator McLean has said he does not hold out much hope that it will do that in the Senate any more than in the House of Representatives-the very least it can do is look seriously at our proposal for a bank consumers assistance fund. I commend our amendments to the Government on that basis also. Here is a chance for the Government to do something on the banking issue, even if it is not having an election towards the end of this year. Let us see some real action on behalf of consumers and not just leave banking in this deregulated system to the bankers themselves.

I want to comment, finally, on some aspects of the Opposition's contribution so far in this debate, in particular the contribution from Senator Michael Baume, which I heard almost in full. As usual, he berated the Government for the economic mess that we are in. I thought he rather skirted around the specific banking legislation before us, but his contribution certainly raises the question of how the Opposition will fix up the economy. The Opposition has said from time to time that one way is to reduce the money supply. How? By re-regulating? By reactivating the powers of the Reserve Bank of Australia? Not Senator Stone, Senator Michael Baume, Senator Alston, Senator Bishop and that bunch of privateers, surely? Alternatively, as David Potts said in the Australian on 18 October, is the scrapping of Medicare part of the secret agenda in an economic policy which has to be based on big cuts in government spending, no doubt as part of reducing the money supply? David Potts suggests that that is the case. He goes on to condemn aspects of the Opposition's policy such as negative gearing and speculative gains tax and finishes up referring to the Tweedledum and Tweedledee policies of the Government and the Opposition, and the exhortation, `Good one, Tweedle brothers'. All I can say is hear, hear!

Has the Opposition determined, in its opinion poll scanning, that `self-interest is ahead of compassion by several lengths'? Paul Lyneham will have to be forgiven, as he is writing in a Melbourne newspaper in the middle of the spring racing carnival, but that is all he will have to be forgiven for in this article. . . . Liberal President, John Elliott, spelled out the new Rambo politics with a strong defence of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan-
in those now immortal words-
``I heard Hawke say that it's taking from the poor and giving to the rich. Absolute nonsense. It's taking from the bludgers and giving to the workers''.

As I say, there is unfortunately this ideological belief that deregulation of the banking industry would somehow lead to more competition and, through that, would lead to cheaper money. The price of money of course is interest. It is quite clear that deregulation has not led to cheaper money. One of the reasons for its introduction in the first place has simply not been borne out by the history of deregulation. Since deregulation interest rates in Australia have more than doubled. If one looks for the source of this interest rate increase it is not all that difficult to find, because more competition has led on the input side to more competition for funds to be borrowed by the banks themselves-the funds against which the banks lend money. So the competition for funds pushes up the interest rates on the bank borrowing side and because the banks have to pay higher rates of interest it follows that they must lend at higher rates of interest. It is at least plausible to argue that the increase in competition has not led to a decrease in interest rates, but has led directly to an increase in interest rates. Moreover, because the banks are borrowing larger amounts of money and paying higher rates of interest this necessarily leads to an increase in money flow into the Australian economy.

Senator Messner is arguing that it is necessary to control the money supply. I ask: How in a deregulated system is either the Government or the Opposition going to control that money supply under those conditions of deregulation? It follows logically that one needs, at least in some measure, to regulate the system if one is going to control the inflow of money. Of course, the high interest rates being paid by banks and other lending institutions are directly related to the inflow of money. TALK.START.PARA: —What are the figures like?
—I am referring to M3. There has been a substantial increase, as Senator Stone's colleague pointed out a moment ago. That in itself is directly increasing the inflation rate.

The central German bank has essentially sterilised capital inflow into Germany and it allows much less credit creation against deposits. The Japanese Government prevented the Japanese banks from underwriting the purchase of United Airlines shares. That situation directly led to the hiccup in the share market the other week, indicating the degree of control which the Japanese exercise in relation to Japanese banks buying what they regard as-it is a beautiful term-`junk shares'. It is unfortunate that, while the Japanese see the United States as a cowboy economy, we tend to follow the United States example. We send people over there to its business schools and we bring back those ideas. The United States economic model is one which is far more laissez faire with far more short time horizons, whereas the Japanese quite clearly have much longer time horizons and keep much tighter control in their banking. One need only pose the question: How would any company in Australia take a 15 or 20 year time horizon with interest rates as they are at present? It would simply be quite impossible.

Coming back to the point about credit creation, it is not generally recognised that banks in this country lend approximately 10 times as much as they have on deposit. If one goes in to a bank and borrows $60,000 for the part purchase of a home costing $100,000 in most instances the bank is simply creating a couple of book entries. One is a debit entry which it makes against one's account and the other is a credit entry which it makes to itself. The point is that, as one pays off that loan, one pays with real money and the bank acquires a real asset.

We are told that at present we have an acute shortage of housing in Australia, yet housing interest rates are now extremely high. With the possible exception of Hobart, one sees cranes festooning almost every city skyline. The finance companies and the banks are building at a prodigious rate. Of course, banks can simply create credit for themselves; they can build banks and, at the end of the building period, simply demolish that debt to themselves through the stroke of a pen. As I have indicated already, the banks creating this credit are a major source of inflation in Australia.

Credit creation by government was the intention of the Labor Party with the creation of the Commonwealth Bank. I remind honourable senators sitting opposite that the policy of the Labor Party at its inception was that the government should be the credit-creating body in the country. One can only bemoan the fact that the Labor Party has moved away from that policy. Of course, if it were government controlled, government could determine that it went into productive enterprises. SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to implement a number of revisions to the Banking Act 1959. It simply formalises in large degree an already well-tried and well-established practice for the prudential supervision of the banking system. Two of the specific changes were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget in 1988: first, the removal of the distinction between trading banks and savings banks and, secondly, the phasing out of the statutory reserve deposits arrangements and their replacement by what are to be called non-callable deposits which banks will be required to maintain with the Reserve Bank as part of their obligations as authorised banks. Both of those steps go towards achieving a more effective, stable and efficient banking system. Therefore, the Opposition does not oppose them.

I note in passing for the record-it is an important noting for the record-that both these changes flow not initially from this Government but from the days and the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, which was established by the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government in 1979. It was commissioned by the then Treasurer, Mr John Howard, in 1979. Through his commissioning of the Campbell Committee and through the recommendations and findings of the Campbell Committee in its final report, I believe John Howard was, quite unequivocally, in many ways the architect of the deregulation of the financial system in the 1980s, although it would obviously be churlish not to give credit to the Hawke Government for having followed through and actually put in place many of those reforms.

I am astounded, though perhaps I should not be surprised, in this debate by the vehemence of the Australian Democrats against the banking system of this country. Obviously it is born of massive ignorance, a lack of fundamental understanding of what the banking system in this country is all about, the role that it plays in commerce and industry in this nation, and the extent to which the banks are subjected not only to internal competition but also, through deregulation and freeing up of the financial system, competition from overseas. To deny the role that the banks play in the overall functioning of our whole economic system seems to me to be as indicative as any other point could be of the extent to which the Australian Democrats are bereft of even the most basic understanding of economic management and the economic functioning of an economy such as ours.

I have just given the Treasurer and the Hawke Government the credit for having put in place many of the changes which flowed through from the recommendations of the Campbell Committee. However, in his pronouncement in the second reading speech in introducing this Bill and in other comments in this place and outside, he has attempted to rewrite history with the regrettably highly exaggerated claims about his role in certain important respects. For example, it was not this Government but the Fraser Government that in June 1982 removed quantitative controls on bank lending. I accept that the Hawke Government abandoned monetary targets in January 1985. Mr Keating has claimed that the Government abandoned them some considerable time before that-another notable exaggeration. But he omits to mention that the reason this Government abandoned monetary targeting was that its economic management was so deplorable and its targeting made so inaccurate by the actual monetary aggregates that it was forced through that pressure to abandon monetary targeting because it had allowed monetary growth to get out of control in a way that helped and continues to help to fuel the inflationary pressures which have been one of the more notorious hallmarks of this Government's economic mismanagement.

I have mixed views about the abandonment of monetary targets. I do not see any theoretical reason why they need to be abandoned in a deregulated system. They imposed a useful discipline even if that was essentially a psychological discipline. With their abandonment came an apparent abandonment of debate and consideration of monetary aggregates. That is regrettable because it has led to the view in many quarters, and seemingly within important councils of the Government, not least the Treasurer, that monetary aggregates are somehow not important, that the rate of change in these aggregates is not important, that the earlier concepts of money supply and money supply growth are no longer relevant and that monetary policy is therefore not important. But of course it is. Under this reckless, hopelessly mismanaged Government, monetary policy is the only arm of economic policy on which it allows itself to rely.

The Government abandoned fiscal policy long ago. It forfeited any ability to use wages policy through its spineless, obsequious subservience to the trade union movement, through its abject but unsuccessful attempts to buy industrial peace through the accord and through its total capitulation to the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the details of the Industrial Relations Bill. I believe this capitulation has been responsible for the total failure of the Government to provide any leadership whatsoever towards the resolution of what is arguably the most crippling dispute in Australia's history, namely, the pilots dispute. This dispute has been prolonged by the hysterical and erratic gyrations of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by the reprehensible abuse, misuse and misappropriation by the Government of taxpayers' funds in the form of a bribe to the Government's mates in the airline industry to continue the dispute in order to prop up and preserve the accord and therefore the relationship between the Government and the trade unions. What a way to run an airline, let alone run a country! The expected cost of that bribe is not yet known, but reasonable estimates put it at $100m or more.

So the Government has thrown two potential arms of macro-economic policy out of the window. It has thrown out fiscal policy and wages policy. What of the other two, namely, exchange rate policy and monetary policy? Exchange rate policy has been effectively sabotaged as a result of the torpedoing of fiscal policy and wages policy. That leaves the Government with only monetary policy. How has the Government used monetary policy? It has used it very simply. It has used it in an entirely political way, not in terms of rational economic policy or effective monetary management but in a cold, cynical, opportunistic political way at a very great cost to the economy and at great cost to practically all Australians. It has done this on numerous occasions. It did it in late 1984 as we ran up to the early election of 1 December 1984. It did it in 1987 and running into the early part of 1988 in a last ditch, desperate attempt to save the Unsworth Government in New South Wales. Thankfully it was an unsuccessful attempt but it was a very costly attempt for Australians. Now in an equally desperate last ditch attempt to save its own political skin the Government has done a quite reprehensible deal, engineered through the Reserve Bank, to bribe the major trading banks to the tune of some $200m in order to get them to refrain from further housing loan interest rate increases, regardless of whether the situation demands or would warrant those increases or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you undo the deal?

—I say to the Minister that that is the theory of the level playing field, as John Hewson, Andrew Peacock and Senator Stone have said. The Opposition agrees that the concept of the interest rate on non-callable deposits being more a market rate is unexceptionable but two things are highly exceptionable and reprehensible. The first is the timing of taking that action now when all the circumstances facing the economy would argue against it at this stage, and the second is tying to a shabby deal with the banks to forgo what may be necessary housing loan interest rate increases not only in the interests of home lenders and the economy as a whole but in the interests of small business and all those other sectors of the economy that rely on borrowed funds. That is reprehensible, shabby and politically and cynically opportunistic and I believe it is going to cost the Government a great deal in votes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has shown that it is bereft of new ideas. It is a very tired government. It is becoming an increasingly opportunistic government. That political opportunism and the populism for which the Prime Minister has been notorious throughout his whole career are costing Australians, particularly Australian taxpayers, dearly. I have mentioned the outrageous decision to subsidise the airlines. I have mentioned the deal with the banks. Then we have the proposal to succumb to a $60m virtual blackmail threat by Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd to preserve the jobs of people who live in the Prime Minister's electorate. Looking at populist indefensible decisions we come next to the indefensible decision to prevent mining at Coronation Hill. Some people may see these decisions as clever politics. That is all they are. They are absolutely bereft of any semblance of rational or responsible government. Some people may see these decisions as clever politics; obviously the Government does. I am absolutely certain that the Australian population is more intelligent than that. It will see through that opportunism and that tiredness and will reject this Government at the polls whenever the election may be held.

There is an enormous contrast between the policy position of the Government and that of the Opposition at this point. The Government has run out of ideas. It is clutching at straws in a desperate effort to retain power. In the last couple of weeks the Opposition has produced a policy package of enormous importance and of major dimensions. It is not just a change at the margin of the policies of this Government. It is a policy of fundamentally different dimensions in economic terms and in social terms and in terms of the whole role of government in our society and our community. For a start it brings down the level of government spending and revenue. It produces smaller government on both sides. In doing that it provides an incentive for people to get back into the work force if they are not in it already and, more importantly, it provides incentives for people who want to have a go at doing their own thing and using their own initiatives and it rewards them for the effort that they put in. The policy package that the Opposition has brought forward is all about creating a more productive Australia, a more efficient Australia and a more competitive Australia and, therefore, a fairer Australia for all people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly families.

—And particularly families-the section of the Australian community that has been most hurt by the policies of this Government over the last seven years, policies which have produced in every year a rate of inflation for this country in excess of virtually every other Western nation. That is a record we have never had in this country before. We have a government that has produced a quadrupling of the debt that this nation owes the rest of the world, a government that has produced a level of interest rates that would have been absolutely incomprehensible in this country five to 10 years ago-interest rates which are now far and away the highest in the Western world-and a government whose policies have resulted in this country going into hock to the rest of the world, through our inability to pay our way in the world, by the order of $2 billion per month.
—With some more bad figures due tomorrow.

—As my colleague Senator Michael Baume says, some figures that will almost certainly be bad are due tomorrow-in fact, on each of the next two days, with the balance of payments figures and the consumer price index figures coming out. We have a government which has established some notable records. All of those records have been at a great cost to our society and economy and therefore to every person, regardless of his or her walk of life or socio-economic status. They have been at great cost to every Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is putting forward to the Australian people a set of proposals that are balanced, economically responsible, and socially highly desirable and that attempt to give back to families and individuals in our society some greater integrity, self-esteem and status. At the same time this package will get government off our backs, not just through lower taxation but also through less regulation and giving back to the private sector of this country-and in some cases for the first time ever-some of the assets that ought to be used much more productively to make a more efficient, fairer and more productive Australia.

There will be a program of privatisation, with a modest start in the first year. This Government, despite the wishes of some of its senior members-not the least perhaps the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-has not had the political will, courage or ability to get through such a program. Instead it has been continually controlled by the extreme left of the political spectrum in this country, which has said to the Government, `Thou shalt not sell one productive asset in this country that is now owned by the Government. Therefore, let's condemn it to continuing inefficiency and stultification'. They are the differences between this Government and the Opposition. Whenever the election is held, be it in the next six weeks or in the next six months, the Australian electorate will see the absolutely fundamental difference between the approach of the Government and that of the coalition parties.

After seven years of falling living standards, with this country dropping in the space of six to eight years from being the seventh or eighth wealthiest country on a per capita income basis to being something like twenty-seventh or twenty-eighth, despite our having had over the past couple of years the biggest commodity price boom for decades, despite a world economy that has been more buoyant over recent years than at any other time in the post-war period and despite everything going for us in terms of the external environment, we have stuffed it up; we have gone backwards. By `we' I mean Australia, and 99 per cent of the blame for that having happened can be laid solely at the door of the massive mismanagement of the resources of this country. It is an indictment of the Government.

The Bill is about banking, but banking goes to the whole heart and soul of the economy of this country. As I said, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. However, we will be moving an amendment in the Committee of the Whole, and a second reading amendment has been moved by Senator Stone on behalf of the Opposition in the following terms:
At end of motion, add: ``but the Senate notes that:

(1) the Hawke-Keating Government's deal with the four major banks to manipulate the interest rates paid on the new non-callable deposits introduced in this legislation so that home mortgage interest rates would not rise higher than the already record high levels, is:
(a) another desperate deal by a tired and dying Government; and
(b) does nothing to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.

(2) to reduce Australia's high level of interest rates, the Government must depart from its one-dimensional, tight monetary policy and adopt an integrated policy framework as set out in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan''.

I endorse and support entirely the amendment moved by the Liberal and National parties because it encapsulates the fundamental problems of this country; the approach by this Government; and, as I said before, the major and fundamental difference between a tired, desperate, out of steam, out of ideas government and an Opposition that has come forward with a living, effective, responsible package that will be of enormous benefit to every person in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill is an important piece of legislation. All honourable senators who have spoken in this debate have conceded that. It seeks to remove the distinction between the trading and saving banks, replaces the statutory Reserve Bank requirement and provides for the Reserve Bank to monitor and investigate certain aspects of banking operations. The Opposition supports the thrust of the legislation because it relates to a process of reform of the financial sector that dates back to the Fraser years. Due credit has been given to the Treasurer of the time, the honourable member for Bennelong, John Howard, for the process that he put in train, for which he fought hard in those times in the Cabinet.
—Which the Labor Party opposed.

—And which the Labor Party opposed not only in the other House but also in the Senate. We back it for those reasons. We know the origin of this piece of legislation. It dates back to the Fraser years and it originates from the Treasurer of that time. As has been pointed out by my colleagues, the Opposition has moved a second reading amendment, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ``but the Senate notes that:

(1) the Hawke/Keating Government's deal with the four major banks to manipulate the interest rates paid on the new non-callable deposits introduced in this legislation so that home mortgage interest rates would not rise higher than the already record high levels, is:
(a) another desperate deal by a tired and dying Government; and
(b) does nothing to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.

(2) to reduce Australia's high level of interest rates, the Government must depart from its one-dimensional, tight monetary policy and adopt an integrated policy framework as set out in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan''.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you may well have been in the chair when the Australian Democrats' economic supremo, Senator Coulter, presented his case and the case for the Democrats with all the economic wisdom that the Democrats could muster. It was a dog's breakfast and we all know it. We know that the Democrats have absolutely no economic credibility not only in this chamber and in this Parliament but also in the community.

Senator Coulter spoke of the German banks. He would not specify whether he meant East Germany or West Germany. After listening to him, I believe that he meant East Germany. Senator Messner's accusations about the Democrats this evening were spot on. They are the old time socialists. They live back in the days of the 1960s and the 1950s when it was believed by the academics, and they were trying to sell the idea, that socialism was a legitimate alternative, that the Eastern bloc nations were economically on the move. We all know today that that is a farce. Today we are witnessing historic events in the Eastern bloc countries. For Senator Coulter to align himself with those sorts of operations is nothing short of a disgrace. Certainly, the people inside those countries would have a thing or two to say about Senator Coulter's idea of economics.

Senator Coulter's wild assertions-that is all they were-about banks being able to write off their investment projects would take me all night to work out. I cannot see how that could possibly happen. What Senator Coulter fails to understand is that a bank is nothing more than a shell. It has other people's money. Has he not seen the advertisements? It is our money. When a bank goes out to invest under its own banner, it does so in the same manner as anyone else. It gets its money from other people. It is a financial cycle. Banks cannot write off their own loans. What idiotacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why they are called financial intermediaries.

—Senator Stone did not quite make the point, so let me make it for him. The Democrats are verging on being imbeciles when it comes to talking in the financial sector. The banks are nothing but financial intermediaries. That is all they are and that is all they have ever been through time. Senator Coulter's senseless accusation that a bank will invest in a $100m skyscraper in Collins Street, Melbourne-indeed, it would cost more than that-and then write that debt off is senseless and unworthy of presentation during this very serious economic debate. Its presentation is certainly unworthy of a public representative. He should stick to what he assumes he knows, which is Aboriginal affairs and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation. Senator Coulter will have a very heavy burden to carry in the years to come for the part he played in the passage of that legislation. To give him credit, he did a good deal of homework on it, but in the final analysis he lacked the wisdom to know which way to vote. He will have to wear that over the years. He should stay out of economics. He should stay away from preaching about the financial sector. He should watch how that legislation unfolds because he has done in this chamber a grave disservice to the people of Australia, let alone the Aboriginal people, and he has to wear that. He dares to dabble in other areas when he has already been a disaster in one. I will now move on to the substance of the legislation before the chamber, the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989.
—Please do.

—We have not heard a whimper from Senator Tate about economic matters, and his State is on its knees. What a disgrace. More than any other State, Tasmania is suffering as a result of the airlines dispute.
—His party has entered into this infamous accord in Tasmania.

—The infamous accord has destroyed his State. He knows it. He has said nothing. He is allowing it to happen. So Senator Tate should allow me some leverage in this debate and not interject. I know that he is a man with the greatest credibility. He has been stifled from time to time for wanting to speak out on such matters as X-rated videos. The honourable senator always disappears when that issue comes up. Heaven knows where they lock him up. I will speak for Tasmania on behalf of the honourable senator if he wishes, if he is too mute to do so for himself.

SPEECH.PARA: In an attempt to keep a lid on interest rates, as has been said by my colleagues, a deal has been entered into, via the Reserve Bank, with the commercial banks. It is a clear indication that this Government will go to any lengths to interfere politically with the proper operations of the Reserve Bank. It is a desperate move. It completely throws out the Government's monetary policy, once the centrepiece of its economic policy. Now the Government must tackle this nation's growing economic crisis, including its current account crisis. In reality, the deal with the banks will not stick. It will be lucky to stick beyond Christmas, because of the growing current account deficit. It is a discriminatory deal. It distorts the market. It is very selective. It does not include the non-banking sector, the credit unions and the building societies, which have already put up their home loan interest rates. It discriminates against small business and other borrowers, who will derive absolutely no benefit from it. Indeed, it will disadvantage them, as prime overdraft interest rates will rise to compensate to some degree for the subsidising of home loans. So the banks have joined an array of desperate deals that this Government has set up to prevent the economy from falling apart, hopefully until the election.

The deal with the banks will cost taxpayers about $200m. The Kodak deal will cost taxpayers $60m. As Senator Stone pointed out in his speech, in his State of Queensland and in my State of Victoria this deal has rubbed small business up the wrong way because Kodak has direct competition in the domestic market. It is another very selective deal. The airlines deal will cost taxpayers about $100m. Who knows how much it will cost if it keeps going the way it is? The latest prediction is that it will go beyond Easter. What a disgraceful set of circumstances. Every honourable senator who has spoken in this debate on my side of the chamber has pointed out that the dispute is destroying the tourism industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Peter Abeles has told the tourist industry it will go till Easter.

—Senator Stone mentions Sir Peter Abeles. We must walk a fine line in this chamber if we are not to abuse our parliamentary privilege when such names and such relationships, that may or may not exist between Sir Peter Abeles and the Prime Minister, are raised. It is well known that their relationship is not a business relationship. The relationship goes back further than this strike. Sir Peter Abeles has an advantage over ordinary Australian families. That is the way it is turning out and that is the way it is being seen in the electorate-that there is favouritism. The Prime Minister must come out and say that any deal he has done with Sir Peter Abeles has not been done on the basis of friendship. It would not hurt him to come out and say that, but he has not done so.

SPEECH.PARA: The waterside workers deal costs an estimated $150m. Tas Bull, the head of the Waterside Workers Federation, is dictating the reforms on the waterfront. The reforms will be nil. We will have another three years of talkfest. No-one should hope that under this agreement there will be substantial reforms. The taxpayers will subsidise the $150m pay-out. The Kakadu deal will cost a massive $7 billion. Coronation Hill, which could cost as much as $7 billion, is another deal done with a very selective group and with an eye towards the election. After all these deals-the banking deal, the Kodak deal, the airlines deal, the waterside workers deal and the Kakadu deal-when an unfortunate pensioner approached the Prime Minister and asked him for a better deal on pensions or at least for an explanation, the Prime Minister called him a `little bugger'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, a silly old bugger.

—He called him a `silly old bugger'. That is the measure of the Prime Minister. Sir Peter Abeles can knock on his door and walk in at any time or get him on the phone at any time, but when a pensioner approaches our Prime Minister he is called a silly old bugger. He was probably looking for no more than a dollar or two rise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer is nothing more than a little man standing at the dyke with his fingers in all the holes as the tidal wave approaches. The Government has no policies except to make a deal. The Government is finished, and the Minister in the chamber knows it. Each deal that it does is selective. It in no way contributes to the fundamental restructuring of the economy. Why does the Treasurer not do a deal with Australian families? Families have carried the burden of high interest rates and high inflation rates with the promise of a light at the end of the tunnel. All Australian families have had in the six years of this Government is a train coming the other way.

In stark contrast, the coalition's policies in the run-up to the election are all in place. The coalition will reduce interest rates and inflation. It will achieve a major shift of resources into production, and export and import replacement. Coronation Hill will be the first step in getting our exports going and releasing the mineral wealth of this nation. The waterfront is equally important. Crushing the waterside workers' monopoly on the waterfront is important in making our exports more competitive.

The public sector will not escape from the dynamic enterprise policies of the coalition. There is no reason why the Government should be providing goods and services which the private sector can provide just as efficiently. The coalition's privatisation paper lists certain enterprises such as Medibank Private, Australian Airlines, Australian National Line and Aussat. What is the policy of the Government on privatisation? It is a split Cabinet and a split party. Meanwhile, enterprises such as Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways are starved of valuable capital.

The coalition's Economic Action Plan has not forgotten the Australian family. Reforms in the economic package include: the provision of substantial child tax rebates, estimated at around $1 billion; assistance to working mothers with tax rebates for child-care; easing of the income test for dependent spouse rebates; and the commitment to hand back the increase in tax caused by bracket creep. These measures are all fully funded as outlined in the Economic Action Plan document. It is the most comprehensive and detailed plan ever produced by an Opposition in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hewson-Stone package.

—The Hewson-Stone package. Senator Stone, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, has contributed a great deal to this economic package and, as a member of the National Party, I am very proud that he has. He has come to this Parliament with a great deal of experience. He has an enormous range of knowledge across all subjects, but his knowledge of economics, of course, is his most valuable asset for our party and the coalition as a whole.
—Thank you.

—You are welcome, and you owe me lunch! The coalition has placed its credentials on the table. It is now the Government which is without policy. It is now the Government which is without credibility. We call upon the Government now to put its policies on the table. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) was unable to demolish our economic package. Heavens, I do not know why we ever thought he would.
—He did not lay a glove on it.

—He did not. He went into the basement for a week and when he came out nothing happened. He has embarrassed his own Government and his own Party. Next week the latest current account deficit figures will be coming out, and the inflation figures this week. Is that right?
—Tomorrow.
—The following day.

—They are two very important statistics for this economy. The Australian dollar is undoubtedly shaky, the sharemarket is gyrating, the Government is shaken and sending out the wrong signals to the market, and we have an airline dispute which is just not going to end. All of these things produce very unfortunate figures for this country. But even if one set out to destroy this country-which the Labor Government has, by its own incompetence-it is such a great country that it is a very hard thing to do. We do live in a very lucky country. We are not a South American country. We have a great untapped wealth in this country that can be turned around very quickly, but only with dynamic policies and a dynamic coalition. We have those policies and have put them on the table, and the Government should not underestimate the determination of this coalition to put them in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate, but I would be an absolutely smarmy hypocrite if I did. Anyone reading the Hansard of this second reading debate would find nothing very illuminating and nothing of which the Senate can be proud. First of all, the second eleven of the Liberal Party made their Appropriation Bill speeches on a banking Bill. I wondered what the common theme was when I saw that it was Senator Michael Baume, Senator Messner and Senator Short speaking for the Liberal Party. Of course, the common theme is that they have all been relegated to the back bench. I suppose the banking Bill is seen as a vehicle to get back to the front bench. Most of the contributions included the pilots strike and meandered like Snake River over a whole range of things, and I do not intend to respond to those irrelevancies.

While I found the performance of the Liberal Party somewhat meandering, I could at least divine what its members were saying. When it comes to the Australian Democrats, I am totally and absolutely bemused as to what they were getting at. Senator McLean can occasionally make rational criticism of banks, but it is so mixed up with paranoia and irrational hate of banks at the moment that it is hard to follow. Senator Powell takes what we call the soft underbelly approach each time, talking about the little people and how much she wants to help them. And Senator Coulter-well, Senator Coulter was Senator Coulter. Finally, we heard from Senator McGauran, who introduced a couple of new words to the English language. I would like to congratulate him on `idiosocracy', or whatever it was. That was a fascinating one.

The theme of the criticism was a general criticism of the Government. I understand, although one could not tell it from the debate, that most people in the chamber will probably support the substance of the Bill, with maybe a couple of amendments being moved during the committee stage. Senator Short and Senator McGauran pointed to the wonderful economic policy released by the Opposition last week. I listened to their Federal President talk three or four days ago about taking from the bludgers and giving to the workers. I picked up today's newspaper and saw what he is about-a $50,000 per week pay rise for the person who made that comment. I do not think anyone on the Opposition benches is crass enough to be as crass as John Elliott-that he could make that statement about taking from the bludgers and giving to the workers when he got a $50,000 a week pay rise is absolutely staggering. I am certain that Senator McGauran, even though he took seven years to get his economics degree, would have to agree with me that it is absolutely staggering that the Federal President of the Liberal Party could do that.

In conclusion, I normally try to be gracious and thank honourable senators for their contributions. I am sorry the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not here to handle this Bill, as he could do it a lot more competently than I can. I think the substance of this Bill is accepted by most people in this chamber. I take it that the Democrats' opposition to the Bill would have been opposition no matter what was in the Bill. As long as it had the word `bank' in it they would oppose it because of the populism which they are trying to develop. It is akin to the know nothing movement of the 1850s in the United States of America, which Senator Cooney has probably studied. It is crass populism. It always goes down the drain in the end, but it always peaks; and if one can ride the wave at the right time it is very good.

`(3) There are to be paid into the Fund such amounts as are appropriated by the Parliament from time to time for the purposes of the Fund.
Payments by banks

`54. (1) Where there is in force an Act imposing on banks, for the purposes of this section, a tax on the advertising expenditure of banks (in this section called the ``banks promotional advertising expenditure tax'') each bank is required to pay to the Commonwealth, at the end of each month after the commencement of this section, an amount equal to one twelfth of the annual amount of that tax.

The substance of the second amendment is, as I have already outlined in the second reading debate, to insert a new part VIa into the Bill which will establish a bank consumers assistance fund. As I said in the second reading debate, if the self-regulation approach of the banking ombudsman scheme is to work and is to be seen to work then it is important that the voice of consumers in the banking industry is heard. We have heard time and time again from Opposition members that they object to consumer organisations being funded from government funds. There have even been some voices from the Government occasionally-Senator Walsh among them-making similar objections. Therefore we think these amendments should be quite acceptable, at least to the Opposition, since the source of funding is the industry itself.

I also pointed out in the second reading debate that the basis for the funding as a formula is the money spent by the banking industry on advertising, that is, promoting its wares and, as my colleague Senator McLean said in his speech at the second reading stage, largely promoting debt in this community and advertising which the community is now saying is ineffective, confusing and irritating. Nevertheless, that is the formula base that we have chosen. In this amendment we have outlined a number of significant and reputable organisations in the community that could be the recipients of these funds. I have already listed groups in my speech at the second reading stage. The list is able to be extended by prescription. The discretion on payments is in the hands of the Minister, but one part of the amendment makes it clear that no less than 90 per cent of moneys would have to be paid out during the financial year to the bodies listed in the amendment.

It is acknowledged by the Australian Democrats and by consumer organisations that some attempt is being made, through the establishment of the banking ombudsman scheme, to address the concerns in the community. We do not have enormous confidence in the scheme and we have said that we will be watching its progress closely, but it is timely that the day after the scheme was officially launched by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) the chamber has the opportunity to materially-and I use the word advisedly-support the genuine operation of that scheme in the interests of the community.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal Deaths in Custody-Mr A. Miller: Death-Sir Henry Parkes: Speech on Federation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 10.30 p.m, under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 September, during the presentation of papers, I spoke briefly on a paper dealing with deaths in custody of Aboriginal people. At that stage I chose to talk about some deaths in custody of non-Aboriginal people. I have subsequently had the opportunity to go back and visit the Prison Medical Service at Long Bay, to examine some medical records there and to receive some briefing. Following this further information provided by Dr Frank McLeod of the Prison Medical Service, I wish to correct some errors in my first account. They are not large errors, but I think that I should put the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to the death of Daniel Victor Taylor in custody. It turns out that Daniel Victor Taylor died from an acute fungal meningo-encephalitis due to candida albicans. That is a fairly common form of fungus, but it is very unusual to have it affect the brain. I am told by Dr McLeod that there have been only 28 recorded cases. The question arose as to whether there had been any negligence by the Prison Medical Service, and that is the crux of the problem.

I also drew attention to the fact, as it had been put to me, that Mr Taylor's methadone maintenance-he was addicted to heroin-had been reduced by half as a disciplinary measure. I now learn from Dr McLeod that it is true that Mr Daniel Victor Taylor had had his methadone reduced in dosage by half, but it transpires that there was no temporal relationship between that event-the reduction of his methadone-and the illness which killed him; in fact, they were separated by some four or five months. His methadone had been halved four or five months earlier and it bore no relation to his death.

I would say that those who have put this claim up would not have had access to the records and would not have known that fact. He died after an illness of some 10 days, I think, but for the last three or four days had been clinically brain dead. He was admitted to the prison hospital at Long Bay with some very difficult, nondescript symptoms. After going back and getting a briefing I must say that I would not have been able to make a diagnosis and I certainly could not have made the diagnosis of the illness from which he died. I do not believe that the prison medical service could have made that diagnosis. The diagnosis was not made at Prince Henry Hospital. I believe that as there have been only 28 recorded cases it is almost impossible to have made a diagnosis.

The question then arises as to whether he was admitted at an appropriately early time to Prince Henry Hospital. Soon after he was seen the medical officer in the Long Bay prison hospital determined that Mr Taylor should receive an urgent referral to a specialist physician-that was on 4 September-but his condition deteriorated very rapidly. I believe that he was in the hospital very soon after, on 5 September, and he was clinically brain dead by 11 September. I just want to put the record straight and say that there was no temporal relationship between the reduction in his methadone and the illness.

The other person whose clinical circumstances I mentioned in the Senate was Mr Malcolm Hatch. His story was that he became ill at Cessnock gaol, was eventually transferred from Cessnock to Prince Henry Hospital via the prison hospital, and died of acute meningitis. It turns out that an inadequate recording system was operating at Cessnock prison. That has since been corrected. I will describe the recording system that Cessnock prison had. It was similar to the sort of system that one would have in casualty. When each person came in for attention, his name was written down and some clinical note was made. The problem with that recording system was that, if one person came back six or seven times, one might not be immediately aware that that person had come back six or seven times. At the time Malcolm Hatch became ill there had been a flu-like epidemic at Cessnock. I am told that between 3 and 10 July, which were relevant dates, there had been 557 visits to the clinic by people in Cessnock prison, all complaining of flu or flu-like symptoms. Mr Hatch was one of those people who had been to the Prison Medical Service in Cessnock on succeeding days. His symptoms seemed to be like those of other people who were attending the clinic at Cessnock gaol. On each occasion he was seen by one of the nurses, although he was treated symptomatically. Using what we call in medicine the retrospectoscope-Mr Acting Deputy President, you would understand that it provides perfect vision-one would say that a clinical error was made, but if one had been on the spot at the time one would have understood that people at the clinic were treating his illness as it seemed to occur.

He presented first on 3 July 1988 and his symptoms then included the classic flu-like symptoms-rigours, aches, pains, cough and fever. One would have thought that this was just like every other illness. It was not until some days later that he started to develop any kind of central nervous system symptoms. On 8 July he was seen twice by the nurses. At this stage he had pain behind the right eyelid and in the head, but his headache, although getting worse, did not suggest that he had meningitis. In fact, he played touch football that day and he did not fail to attend muster every day in the prison. On 9 July he was seen again with more headaches and more pain in the right cheek and eye and he was again given symptomatic treatment. In hindsight, one might have become a little suspicious at this stage.

On 10 July, which was a Sunday, he was seen in his cell because the correctional services officer was worried about his condition. He was seen by one of the nurses and at that stage, I am told, a clinical error was made. In retrospect, he then had a fever and a rapid pulse and he was slightly delirious. A decision was then made to get a doctor to see him early in the morning, whereas in retrospect a decision should have been made to move him at that stage. The next morning he was moved to the Long Bay prison hospital and from there to Prince Henry Hospital, where he was found to have a meningeal infection which rapidly deteriorated, and he died.

The interesting thing is that one would have thought that, with pain in the right cheek and X-rays suggesting that he had a blocked sinus, the clinical diagnosis that was eventually made of meningitis, secondary to sinusitis, would have been a reasonable diagnosis. In fact, at autopsy something quite unexpected was discovered. He certainly had meningitis but he did not have right maxillary sinusitis at all: he had a quite unsuspected chronic osteomyelitis of the inner ear on one side, of which there had been absolutely no symptoms and which bore no relation to the illness from which he had suffered.

I believe that there is a lot to be learned from that case. I understand that the Prison Medical Service, which is anxious to try to look after its charges, has made some changes in its recording system. In fact, one of the nurses looking after Mr Hatch has suffered grievously in a professional sense: she has felt remarkably upset by what happened. However, having now made several visits to Long Bay hospital and seen the work done there, I want to place on record my appreciation of Dr McLeod and his officers. I believe that they try, in a serious and consistent way, to look after the prisoners under their care. They are doing a number of things to address some of the major issues that occur in prisons, which I think it proper not to set out in the Senate or to go over in some detail. They are very concerned to look after the welfare of their charges.

Senator Jenkins will know that we were concerned with three or four people. Dr McLeod made no reference, in his notes, for example, to the case of young Mr Searcy, another prisoner who died and about whom Senator Jenkins was concerned. I can make no further comments about that incident, but I must say that, in the case of Daniel Victor Taylor, the reduction of the methadone dosage was quite unrelated in time to the episode which killed him-an episode of an extremely rare fungal meningo-encephalitis.

Finally, in my previous speech I inadvertently said that Jamie Partlic-and some honourable senators would know about Jamie Partlic-had been bashed during his time in prison hospital. Of course, I did not mean that; he had been bashed during his time in prison. I said that he was a fine defaulter, but Hansard recorded it as a `find defaulter'. I ask Hansard to note that he was a fine defaulter who was in prison for a few days. That is what made both his case and the case of young Searcy so tragic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today a report entitled Report of the Inquiry into the Death of John Raymond Pilot by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody was tabled in the Senate. Senator Peter Baume, who was speaking before me on another matter, referred to an inquiry by this same Commission. At the time of the tabling of this report earlier today I believe that Senator Jenkins also spoke. We can all be distressed at the profound activities revealed in the findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The report that was tabled earlier today regarding the death of John Raymond Pilot is a very tragic report; in fact, it raises an awful sequence of events that resulted in that death, including many instances of neglect. I wish to quote from the introduction to that report by Commissioner Wyvill, where he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Pilot who had died alone was a 33-year old unemployed, homeless, Aboriginal man with a serious history of alcohol abuse. The cause of death was asphyxia brought about by a fit following a complete withdrawal of alcohol.
His death in the watch-house was a consequence of official neglect.
Throughout the report Commissioner Wyvill spends a lot of time looking at the various circumstances and makes a number of recommendations as well. Let me quote from some other comments:

Pilot was at the time known to the police at the watch-house as an alcoholic and it was inevitable that at some time in the near future he would once again be in their custody and they would be responsible for his welfare.
The report also states:

Indeed, unless adequate preventive measures are taken, alcoholics incarcerated within hours of a drinking bout and without adequate supervision, or persons otherwise prone to epileptic seizures, are at risk in lock-ups and watch-houses throughout Queensland.

As I have said, this report makes awful reading. In fact, it records some tragic and unnecessary circumstances. In chapter 14 of the report Commissioner Wyvill outlines a series of underlying and other issues relating to the circumstances of Pilot's death. Let me give the particular points that Commissioner Wyvill covers. They are:
14.1 The Establishment of Detoxification Units and Rehabilitation Centres
14.2 The Acquisition and Use of Medical Information by Police
14.3 Coronial Inquiries
14.4 Reserve/Community Upbringing

Those circumstances have been well set out by Commissioner Wyvill and relate to the underlying issues and causes of Aboriginal deaths. In this circumstance it related to the death of John Raymond Pilot. The Government has found it necessary to appoint a commissioner in Western Australia to undertake a series of other investigations into the underlying causes of Aboriginal deaths in custody in Western Australia. Mr Pat Dodson, a former Deputy Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and a former director of the Central Land Council in central Australia, has been appointed the commissioner to undertake this task.

What concerns me about the appointment of Commissioner Dodson is the very unrealistic expectation that the underlying causes of Aboriginal deaths will obviously not be addressed by the other commissioners charged with the responsibility of investigating these causes as part of their inquiries. As I have said, Commissioner Wyvill has covered this very satisfactorily in the report tabled today into the death of John Raymond Pilot. In our investigation of the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services yesterday I was able to pursue questioning relating to the order of costs for the special inquiries that have now been put in place for Mr Pat Dodson.

While Mr Dodson will be looking at these Western Australian instances, I seriously question the allocation of $1m for his series of investigations. They will take place over a 15-month period. Of course, Commissioner Dodson will not be looking at individual cases; he will be reviewing the underlying causes. I will just go through that order of costs that has now been determined. It is quite well known that Commissioner Dodson's salary is about $100,000. His travel allowance and fares will be $33,000; his staff and staff travel costs, $283,000; his consultants, including a former ADC commissioner with whom he shared status on the ADC, Mr Peter Yu, who I was able to ascertain in the course of my questioning had very little expertise in this area, $71,000; the set-up costs of an office in Broome for Mr Dodson, $80,000; the provision of four-wheel drive vehicles, $36,000; office requisites for Commissioner Dodson, $40,000; and office rental costs in this financial year, $53,000-in all a total of almost $700,000 in the financial year. If that is extrapolated through for the other three months to when the letters patent will be returned at the end of September next year, the order of costs for the running of Commissioner Dodson's office, to investigate 33 cases in Western Australia of which 11 are up in the north-west region, is extraordinarily high.

We are well aware that the costs of this Royal Commission have blown out from the original estimate of $2.2m when it was set up to a total cost now of some $30m. But I seriously question the qualification of Commissioner Dodson to undertake this work, particularly at such a high cost for the result. I believe the outcome of Commissioner Dodson's report in this area of investigation will be predictable. Given the nature of the consultant he has appointed, Mr Yu, it will probably also be very questionable. I am fearful that it will be just another glossy magazine or glossy report to be put on the shelves. I would have preferred that $1m to have been expended in preventative measures, particularly in the area of alcohol rehabilitation, alcohol being a problem that underpins so many of these tragic cases of deaths in custody. As is so often the case with expenditure in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, it is a pity that the Government just throws money at the problem rather than seeking out proper solutions. It is also very important to question why mates of the Minister are given these responsibilities. Through investigations of the ADC, particularly since Minister Hand appointed Mr Dodson to the Board of the ADC in May 1988, we are well aware of the problems and complications that continually confounded the ADC in its various activities with regard to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

I am hopeful that the reports of the Royal Commission can be quickly brought to bear. Just as this one today on John Raymond Pilot by Commissioner Wyvill deserves and demands the attention of the Parliament, I hope that the other commissioners' reports into the individual deaths can be quickly brought to finality. I hope that they will all contain chapters relating to the underlying and other issues inherent in each and every case and will prove the totally unnecessary nature of the $1m consultancy that this Government has handed out on a platter to Mr Pat Dodson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling has raised the question of the cost of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I will not detain the Senate very long in what I want to say about it. Honourable senators interested in this matter will know that I have spoken on this matter on a number of occasions and have also written a number of fairly lengthy newspaper articles about it. Honourable senators may recall what was probably the most recent address I gave to the Senate on the question of Aboriginal deaths in custody when I canvassed, in the same way as Senator Tambling has done with this report, what I think at that time were the seven reports by the Commission into the deaths of seven people. I expressed then my concerns about whether the interim recommendations of then Commissioner Muirhead would be implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I rise to speak in the adjournment debate tonight is to note, with a considerable degree of frustration, anger and sadness, the death in Maitland prison-this was referred to earlier today by, I think, Senator Jenkins-of Dermot Pidgeon, a 17-year-old kid who, apparently at his request, had transferred from a juvenile detention centre to an adult prison. It appears that some time on Saturday night of last weekend he took his life by hanging. Tonight on television news I watched an interview with the responsible New South Wales Minister who did not dispute what appears to be the case, that this young boy died at about 9 p.m. on Saturday and his body hung dead in his cell until 7.15 a.m. on Sunday, that is, for 10 hours. Of course, it is unknown at this stage how long he had been locked in that cell without supervision before his death. I was also interested to note that it was stated and confirmed by the Minister in the television interview this evening, that he was confined in an observation cell at Maitland prison.

I have pointed out in a number of speeches that I have made previously in the Senate that some of the more interesting and pertinent statistics that have been produced by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody relate to the horrible fact that a very large number of young people take their own lives in Australian prisons. The number of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people who kill themselves in Australian prisons is almost precisely in proportion to their percentage of the prison population. That proportion is almost exact for any age range. For every 21-year-old Aboriginal person who kills himself in an Australian prison five 21-year-old non-Aboriginal prisoners take their own lives as well. I raise that-it is relevant that I raise it-for a reason. As I pointed out at the time, the recommendations-I am simply stating the obvious now in respect of what Senator Tambling has said earlier in the adjournment debate-of this very expensive royal commission will be of benefit not simply to Aboriginal prisoners but to all prisoners, no matter what their racial origins are, particularly those prisoners who are intoxicated when they are taken into custody.

It is with some degree of despair-that is not too strong a word for how I feel about it-that I note the death of a 17-year-old boy in a New South Wales prison, Maitland prison, shortly after being transferred there. He apparently hung dead in his cell, an observation cell, for 10 hours without his body being discovered. I dare say that the inquiry-no doubt there will be a coronial inquiry held-will determine how long he had been confined in this cell without supervision of any kind.

I make the obvious point that before Commission Muirhead left the Royal Commission he brought down a comprehensive set of interim recommendations. That was not accidental. Commissioner Muirhead did that deliberately in order to get down in black and white a number of measures to try to stem this dreadful loss of life, particularly of younger people, in Australian prisons. Some of those recommendations were certainly controversial-for example, the ones about screening out racism and so on in police forces or prison services which I said at the time I thought would be very difficult to implement.

The reality is that the great majority of those recommendations were sane, sensible and urgent. In terms of Government resources, there is no question at all that the urgent need at this point in time is for Muirhead's recommendations to be implemented in Australian prisons. We should all feel angry about the continuing role which I think is properly being played by the Royal Commission into Deaths in Custody when young Australians, in this case Aboriginal kids, are continuing to kill themselves in Australian prisons under circumstances that indicate that even the most basic of Muirhead's recommendations have not been followed.

There does not appear to me to be the slightest point in the Commonwealth spending $20m or $30m on an inquiry to produce a report if the final result of that product is for that report to sit on a shelf somewhere gathering dust. The reason I make that point is that the Commonwealth is responsible for setting up and administering the Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody but it is not responsible for administering the prison systems in Australia; nor, in my view, should it be. That is clearly and properly the responsibility of the State governments. I simply rise to make the point that there does not appear to be much point at all in the Commonwealth allocating such large sums of public money to conduct what I think is an extremely necessary and warranted inquiry-an inquiry producing what the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs said in a recent press release have been extremely useful and pertinent reports into the deaths investigated so far-if the most basic of the recommendations regarding supervision that were brought down by Commissioner Muirhead are not implemented by the State prison services. If that is not done this is an exercise in total and very tragic futility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend a few minutes of the Senate's time tonight to pay tribute to a constituent of mine who, sadly, died last week from asthma. Ironically Tony Miller, from Culcairn in New South Wales, died from this ailment in the very month that the Asthma Foundation had chosen to publicise the dangers of asthma attacks. It was because of his involvement in overseas aid projects that my office first came to meet him several years ago. My most recent involvement with him was in relation to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. This time last year he appeared before the Committee to discuss his work with sheep and goats in arid areas of Australia.

He had great expertise in the behaviour of animals, particularly sheep and goats, and had acted as a consultant to large companies on welfare aspects of transporting sheep and goats, particularly in the Middle East live sheep export industry. He was concerned that sheep in arid and semi-arid areas of Australia suffered in drought times and he devised a water trough for use in outback areas.
