SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak because I do not know whether many people are aware of the fact that today is the centenary of the speech made by Sir Henry Parkes at Tenterfield on 24 October 1889 which called for the federation of Australia. That speech is considered amongst historians as the turning point that began the process which just over 11 years later led to the federation of Australia and to the establishment of this chamber and the House of Representatives. I think it would be remiss of us if there were not some acknowledgment in the Senate and in the Parliament of Australia that we are here today as a result of the vision of Sir Henry Parkes, who on this day 100 years ago called for the federation of Australia.
—His speech was incorporated in Hansard this morning.

—I was unaware of that. I was at an interminable Senate committee meeting-something which federation has inflicted upon us as well as the Senate. I also want to pay tribute to the Tenterfield community. Only a couple of weeks ago I received a letter asking for support for Tenterfield's attempts to promote the celebration in the local community and the significance of that speech in Tenterfield 100 years ago. I think that we should put on the record that a small town in northern New South Wales is the place where a great speech was made.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to use this opportunity to point out that I believe it is time for the Australian community and the governments of Australia to start preparing for the celebrations of our centenary of federation on 1= January 2001. That is a long way off but I point out that we took 10 years to prepare for the celebration of our bicentenary. To me, the centenary of Federation is much more significant than the bicentenary, which was a celebration of 200 years of European settlement of Australia. It did not establish Australia as a separate or distinct nation; it celebrated the beginning of European settlement.

The most important celebration in my lifetime, and I hope I live that long, will be the centenary of Federation celebration. It will be the centenary of our becoming a nation. The centenary of Federation will be able to be conducted without the controversy and the agony particularly of our Aboriginal citizens who believed that the bicentenary was a celebration of an event that began 200 years of their exploitation. The centenary of Federation will celebrate the foundation of Australia as a nation and the Aboriginal people, as well as many other diverse sections of our community, will be able to celebrate their participation in our country despite the agony of their experience of the previous 200 years, or what will be 213 years by the time of the centenary of Federation.

I note that, already, the Federal Government has established the continuation of the bicentenary road funding and that it is now called the centenary of Federation road funding. That is the first I have heard of any government moving to commemorate the centenary of our Federation. That should be only the very beginning of our preparations for that centenary.

As the 1890s were the great ferment in Australian political affairs concerning what sort of constitution we should have in Australia to achieve Federation, I hope that the 1990s will be a decade to match the 1890s, enabling people in Australia to discuss maturely the need for constitutional change so that what Sir Henry Parkes and others called for in the 1890s to achieve Federation can be updated and we can go into the twenty-first century having made appropriate amendments under which Australia can govern itself and meet all of the challenges of the twenty-first century, which will be so different from what people perceived in 1890.

Despite the long record of opposition in the Australian community to constitutional change, there could be some opportunity for the community to discuss maturely and reach some consensus on the need to change and adapt the Constitution for the next century. That, in conjunction with the centenary of Federation, would be very appropriate to the memory of Sir Henry Parkes. I do not believe that, when he made his speech in 1889, he would have expected the Constitution of Australia, which was adopted in 1901, to remain almost unchanged for the next 100 years. I believe that the founding fathers would have believed that constitutional change could have been achieved in this country much more readily. The Constitution is not a dead document. It should be a living document open to discussion leading to change.

As part of that process, referring again to the Aboriginal people, it should be possible to achieve a treaty between the descendants of European settlers of Australia and the Aboriginal people. It should be possible to obtain agreement between those peoples that we both share this continent, that we both have rights in this country and that we both understand where we came from.

I believe that, in our history, there is a void in this area and, until it is resolved, we will always have a deficiency in the moral sense about the standing and establishment of our country. There is a case for the establishment of a treaty between the Aboriginal people and their descendants and the European people and their descendants concerning the nature of our country.

My final point on constitutional change is that, during this period of the 1990s, though it is not popular in both countries at the moment, constitutional change leading to the political merging of Australia with New Zealand will become more popular. I was in New Zealand recently and I believe that anybody who raised this matter in New Zealand at the moment would be run out of the country very quickly. However, recent indications from polling in New Zealand show that the majority of New Zealand people believe that there should be a common economic policy between our countries, that there should be a common defence force between our countries and that there should be such things as a common currency in our countries. Those are already acceptable but political merger is absolutely rejected by a majority in both countries. Once we start moving towards merging economic and defence matters, people will, by evolution, see some advantages in the merging of both countries in a political way. That should be part of the process.

Again we should pay tribute to the founding fathers because the Constitution contains a clause that allows New Zealand to be considered as part of the Australian Federation. I agree that, if Australia and New Zealand did merge, we may have to consider adapting the name `Australia' to take account of New Zealand. In the past, the two countries have been referred to as Australasia and Oceania. Those names may be appropriate in the future.

Above all, we ought to pay tribute to Sir Henry Parkes tonight for his foresight. If it were not for his commitment and ability to proselytise the Federation, it would not have occurred. The great tragedy is that he died in 1896, just under five years before Federation was achieved. So many visionaries who called for change in affairs did not live to see what they set out to achieve. That was a great tragedy and a great disappointment for many of the supporters of Sir Henry Parkes at that time.

During the 1990s we should not forget the memory and vision of Sir Henry Parkes and we should have the courage, as a community wider than parliament, to consider further constitutional change. I say thank you to Sir Henry Parkes. If it were not for him I, like all the other senators, would not be here today to participate in a Federation as we know it. It has achieved much for Australia. It has established us as a distinctive country, and that is a great achievement to the memory of a great man.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 7 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to broadcasting Federal Parliament, what is the range of each transmitter now being used for parliamentary broadcasts.
(2) What was the range of each transmitter used for the purpose when Radio National carried parliamentary broadcasts.
(3) Does the discrepancy between (1) and (2) indicate that some country areas are disadvantaged at present compared with their previous capacity to receive such broadcasts.
(4) What plans does the Government have to extend the range of parliamentary broadcasts more widely.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to give a single figure for the ``range'' of transmitters used for medium frequency radio transmissions. The area within which a service can be received satisfactorily is usually irregular in shape, depending on geographic location, physical topography etc; reception quality also varies from day to night.

(2) The interim Parliamentary Network has been established using the standby transmitters of the Radio National Network. These standby transmitters, which were used as a back-up in case the Radio National transmitters failed, are generally not as powerful as the main Radio National transmitters which carried the Parliamentary broadcasts. In addition, in order to carry the interim network, the standby transmitters must be operated using standby antennas, which are less effective than the main Radio National antennas. This means that the area covered by the interim Parliamentary Network is smaller than the area covered by the Radio National transmitters. It is estimated that audience reach of the interim network is approximately 10% below that of the Radio National Network.

(3) The number of potential Radio National listeners who will be outside the range of the new Parliamentary broadcasts is estimated to be 50,000 Australia-wide. However, only a small proportion of these Radio National listeners would be Parliamentary broadcasting listeners.

The following population centres, which were able to pick up Parliamentary broadcasts under previous transmitting arrangements, may no longer receive them on the interim network introduced on ABC stand-by transmitters (ie 2PB Sydney, Canberra and Newcastle, 3PB Melbourne; 4PB Brisbane; 5PB Adelaide, 6PB Perth and 7PB Hobart).

Many people living in these areas would have received a marginal or poor grade of service under the previous transmission arrangements. In most cases the broadcast signal would not have met the Department of Transport and Communications' Planning Guidelines for an adequate service.

However, there is still a significant degree of fortuitous reception of transmissions on the stand-by network in regional areas, particularly in South Australia. Reception in and around Perth is actually an improvement on the Radio National transmissions.

(4) The Parliamentary network will transfer to new frequencies on a permanent basis in the context of the AM/FM conversion plan in the mainland state capital cities. This will occur in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and Adelaide later this year, and in Brisbane in 1991. Canberra, Hobart and Newcastle will need to be considered separately in the context of AM/FM conversion policy in multi-station regional markets.
The transfer of Parliamentary Broadcasts to the interim network and later to the permanent network was approved by the Joint Committee on Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings.

In its 1986 Report on `Television and Radio Broadcasting in Both Houses of Parliament', the Joint Standing Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, recommended that the range of Parliamentary broadcasts should be extended to provide a service to 100% of Australians. The recommendation is still to be decided upon by the Government. Matters for consideration include the means of distribution and the cost.
